events.title: Introduction of the Client and His Singular Case
detailed_summary: Dr. Watson visits Sherlock Holmes and finds him speaking with a client, Mr. Jabez Wilson, notable for his stout build and fiery red hair.
Holmes insists Watson stay, introducing Wilson and highlighting Watson's role as his partner and chronicler.
Wilson acknowledges Watson with a brief greeting.
Holmes invites Watson to sit, noting Watson's appreciation for the unusual and bizarre, which Holmes claims characterizes many of his cases.
Holmes references a previous conversation where he asserted that real life is stranger than fiction, a point Watson had doubted.
He introduces Mr. Wilson's narrative as potentially one of the most singular he has encountered, possibly involving a smaller, unique crime, or perhaps no crime at all.
Holmes requests Wilson to restart his story for Watson's benefit and because the peculiar details warrant careful repetition, admitting the case seems unprecedented in his experience.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I had called upon my friend, Mr. Sherlock Holmes, one day in the autumn of last year and found him in deep conversation with a very stout, florid-faced, elderly gentleman with fiery red hair.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: In the present instance I am forced to admit that the facts are, to the best of my belief, unique.”

events.text_segment:
I had called upon my friend, Mr. Sherlock Holmes, one day in the autumn of last year and found him in deep conversation with a very stout, florid-faced, elderly gentleman with fiery red hair. With an apology for my intrusion, I was about to withdraw when Holmes pulled me abruptly into the room and closed the door behind me.
“You could not possibly have come at a better time, my dear Watson,” he said cordially.
“I was afraid that you were engaged.”
“So I am. Very much so.”
“Then I can wait in the next room.”
“Not at all. This gentleman, Mr. Wilson, has been my partner and helper in many of my most successful cases, and I have no doubt that he will be of the utmost use to me in yours also.”
The stout gentleman half rose from his chair and gave a bob of greeting, with a quick little questioning glance from his small fat-encircled eyes.
“Try the settee,” said Holmes, relapsing into his armchair and putting his fingertips together, as was his custom when in judicial moods. “I know, my dear Watson, that you share my love of all that is bizarre and outside the conventions and humdrum routine of everyday life. You have shown your relish for it by the enthusiasm which has prompted you to chronicle, and, if you will excuse my saying so, somewhat to embellish so many of my own little adventures.”
“Your cases have indeed been of the greatest interest to me,” I observed.
“You will remember that I remarked the other day, just before we went into the very simple problem presented by Miss Mary Sutherland, that for strange effects and extraordinary combinations we must go to life itself, which is always far more daring than any effort of the imagination.”
“A proposition which I took the liberty of doubting.”
“You did, Doctor, but none the less you must come round to my view, for otherwise I shall keep on piling fact upon fact on you until your reason breaks down under them and acknowledges me to be right. Now, Mr. Jabez Wilson here has been good enough to call upon me this morning, and to begin a narrative which promises to be one of the most singular which I have listened to for some time. You have heard me remark that the strangest and most unique things are very often connected not with the larger but with the smaller crimes, and occasionally, indeed, where there is room for doubt whether any positive crime has been committed. As far as I have heard, it is impossible for me to say whether the present case is an instance of crime or not, but the course of events is certainly among the most singular that I have ever listened to. Perhaps, Mr. Wilson, you would have the great kindness to recommence your narrative. I ask you not merely because my friend Dr. Watson has not heard the opening part but also because the peculiar nature of the story makes me anxious to have every possible detail from your lips. As a rule, when I have heard some slight indication of the course of events, I am able to guide myself by the thousands of other similar cases which occur to my memory. In the present instance I am forced to admit that the facts are, to the best of my belief, unique.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: I had called upon my friend, Mr. Sherlock Holmes, one day in the autumn of last year and found him in deep conversation with a very stout, florid-faced, elderly gentleman with fiery red hair. To Sherlock Holmes, I had been always a kind of biographer, and he was accustomed to my presence; so he motioned me to a seat without any preliminary introduction. "You may remember, Watson," said he, "my assertion that life is infinitely stranger than anything which the mind of man could invent. We would not dare to conceive the things which are really mere commonplaces of existence. If we could fly out of that window hand in hand, hover over this great city, gently remove the roofs, and peep in at the queer things which are going on, the strange coincidences, the plannings, the cross-purposes, the wonderful chains of events, working through generations, and leading to the most outré results, it would make all fiction with its conventionalities and foreseen conclusions most stale and unprofitable." "You spoke the truth, Holmes," I answered, "and yet I am not sure that I have ever heard a case which more strikingly illustrated your assertion than that which you are now investigating." "It is a singular story," said Holmes, "and one which I think will interest you. I have here a client who has come to me with a very curious problem. Mr. Jabez Wilson, this is my friend and colleague, Dr. Watson." The red-headed man nodded to me with a short, quick movement of his head. "Sit down, Watson," said Holmes. "You will find this case one of the most singular which has ever come under my observation. It may be that it is a small crime, or it may be that it is no crime at all. But the details are so peculiar that I have asked Mr. Wilson to repeat his story for your benefit, and because I think that the more we hear of it, the more we shall be able to understand its significance."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
I had called upon my friend, Mr. Sherlock Holmes, one day in the autumn of last year and found him in deep conversation with a very stout, florid-faced, elderly gentleman with fiery red hair. The gentleman was seated in a large armchair, his hands clasped tightly together, while Holmes leaned forward, his keen eyes fixed intently upon his visitor. 

"You have come to me, sir," said Holmes, "because you are in some trouble, and you hope that I can help you to unravel the mystery which perplexes you. Pray, tell me all the facts from the beginning."

The man nodded gravely and began his tale. "My name is Mr. John Hector McFarlane, and I am a retired colonel of the British Army. I have recently come into possession of a curious and valuable object, which has brought me nothing but trouble since."

Holmes raised an eyebrow. "A curious and valuable object, you say? Pray, describe it to me."

"It is a small, ancient manuscript," replied McFarlane. "I acquired it during my service in India. It is said to contain secrets of great importance, but I have been unable to decipher its contents. Since I brought it home, I have been followed by strange men, and I fear for my safety."

Holmes steepled his fingers thoughtfully. "Have you shown this manuscript to anyone else?"

"Only to my trusted friend, Dr. Watson," said McFarlane. "He advised me to seek your counsel."

I glanced at Holmes, who nodded silently. "Very well, Colonel, I shall examine this manuscript at once."

McFarlane produced a small, leather-bound book from his satchel and handed it to Holmes. The detective took it carefully, his eyes scanning the intricate script and symbols within. "Fascinating," he murmured. "This appears to be a cipher of some sort."

"Can you decode it?" asked McFarlane anxiously.

"I shall do my best," replied Holmes. "In the meantime, I advise you to be cautious and avoid any unnecessary attention."

Over the next few days, Holmes and I worked tirelessly to decipher the manuscript. The code was complex, but Holmes's unparalleled intellect soon began to unravel its secrets. It spoke of a hidden treasure, buried centuries ago by a secret society, and guarded by a series of cryptic clues.

As we delved deeper, it became clear that others were also seeking this treasure, and their methods were far less scrupulous. One evening, as we returned to Baker Street, we found a note slipped under our door, warning us to cease our investigation or face dire consequences.

Holmes smiled grimly. "They underestimate us, Watson."

The following days were filled with danger and intrigue. We followed the clues across London, from ancient libraries to forgotten catacombs beneath the city. Each step brought us closer to the treasure, but also closer to those who would stop at nothing to claim it for themselves.

In the end, it was Holmes's keen observation and quick thinking that saved us. We uncovered the treasure hidden beneath the ruins of an old chapel, just as our pursuers closed in. A tense confrontation ensued, but with the help of the police, we apprehended the villains and secured the treasure.

Colonel McFarlane was immensely grateful, and the manuscript was entrusted to a museum for safekeeping. As for Holmes, he returned to his armchair, lighting his pipe with a satisfied smile.

"Another mystery solved, Watson," he said. "And a reminder that even the most obscure secrets can be uncovered with patience and reason."

I nodded, ever in awe of my friend's extraordinary abilities, and grateful to have witnessed yet another of his remarkable adventures.

events.title: Holmes Deduces Wilson's Background
detailed_summary: Mr. Wilson proudly retrieves a newspaper from his coat.

While Wilson looks for an advertisement, Watson observes him, noting his appearance as an average, obese, pompous, and slow British tradesman, identifiable primarily by his striking red hair and an expression of discontent.

Holmes observes Watson's scrutiny and smiles, proceeding to list several deductions about Wilson: past manual labor, snuff use, Freemason membership, time spent in China, and recent extensive writing.
Wilson is astonished and asks Holmes how he deduced these facts, starting with the manual labor.
Holmes explains the deduction based on the larger size and developed muscles of Wilson's right hand.
Regarding snuff and Freemasonry, Holmes points to Wilson's arc-and-compass breastpin, a slightly non-standard Masonic symbol.
The writing deduction comes from the worn right cuff and the smooth patch on the left sleeve near the elbow.

The China connection is deduced from a specific type of fish tattoo above Wilson's right wrist, identifiable by the pink staining technique unique to China, further corroborated by a Chinese coin on his watch chain.
Wilson laughs heartily, initially impressed but now believing the deductions were simple observations.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The portly client puffed out his chest with an appearance of some little pride and pulled a dirty and wrinkled newspaper from the inside pocket of his greatcoat.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Well, I never!” said he.

events.text_segment:
The portly client puffed out his chest with an appearance of some little pride and pulled a dirty and wrinkled newspaper from the inside pocket of his greatcoat. As he glanced down the advertisement column, with his head thrust forward and the paper flattened out upon his knee, I took a good look at the man and endeavoured, after the fashion of my companion, to read the indications which might be presented by his dress or appearance.
I did not gain very much, however, by my inspection. Our visitor bore every mark of being an average commonplace British tradesman, obese, pompous, and slow. He wore rather baggy grey shepherd’s check trousers, a not over-clean black frock-coat, unbuttoned in the front, and a drab waistcoat with a heavy brassy Albert chain, and a square pierced bit of metal dangling down as an ornament. A frayed top-hat and a faded brown overcoat with a wrinkled velvet collar lay upon a chair beside him. Altogether, look as I would, there was nothing remarkable about the man save his blazing red head, and the expression of extreme chagrin and discontent upon his features.
Sherlock Holmes’ quick eye took in my occupation, and he shook his head with a smile as he noticed my questioning glances. “Beyond the obvious facts that he has at some time done manual labour, that he takes snuff, that he is a Freemason, that he has been in China, and that he has done a considerable amount of writing lately, I can deduce nothing else.”
Mr. Jabez Wilson started up in his chair, with his forefinger upon the paper, but his eyes upon my companion.
“How, in the name of good-fortune, did you know all that, Mr. Holmes?” he asked. “How did you know, for example, that I did manual labour. It’s as true as gospel, for I began as a ship’s carpenter.”
“Your hands, my dear sir. Your right hand is quite a size larger than your left. You have worked with it, and the muscles are more developed.”
“Well, the snuff, then, and the Freemasonry?”
“I won’t insult your intelligence by telling you how I read that, especially as, rather against the strict rules of your order, you use an arc-and-compass breastpin.”
“Ah, of course, I forgot that. But the writing?”
“What else can be indicated by that right cuff so very shiny for five inches, and the left one with the smooth patch near the elbow where you rest it upon the desk?”
“Well, but China?”
“The fish that you have tattooed immediately above your right wrist could only have been done in China. I have made a small study of tattoo marks and have even contributed to the literature of the subject. That trick of staining the fishes’ scales of a delicate pink is quite peculiar to China. When, in addition, I see a Chinese coin hanging from your watch-chain, the matter becomes even more simple.”
Mr. Jabez Wilson laughed heavily. “Well, I never!” said he.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
The portly client puffed out his chest with an appearance of some little pride and pulled a dirty and wrinkled newspaper from the inside pocket of his greatcoat. "You see, Mr. Holmes," said he, "this is a very curious thing, and I don’t know what to make of it. I am a man who has been used to work, and I have always earned my living by my own exertions. But now I find myself in a position which is quite new to me, and I want to know what it means."

He unfolded the paper and pointed to a curious advertisement which ran as follows:

"'The Red-Headed League. — Wanted, a number of red-headed men. — Salary £4 a week. — Apply to the Red-Headed League, 7 Pope's Court, Fleet Street.'"

Watson looked at the advertisement with some interest, but his eyes wandered to the man himself. He was a little, stout, and rather pompous-looking man, with a florid face and a shock of bright red hair. His expression was one of mingled pride and discontent.

Holmes smiled as he observed Watson's scrutiny. "You have been looking at our friend here," said he, "and I think you have made some shrewd observations. But I can do better. I can tell you a good deal about this gentleman without even asking him a question."

Mr. Wilson looked at Holmes with some surprise. "Indeed, sir?" said he. "Well, I should like to hear it."

"First," said Holmes, "I notice that your right hand is considerably larger and stronger than your left. This shows that you have been accustomed to manual labor, and that you are right-handed."

"That's true enough," said Wilson. "I have been a pawnbroker for many years, and I have had to do a good deal of work with my hands."

"Secondly," said Holmes, "you are a user of snuff."

Wilson looked at him in astonishment. "How on earth do you know that?"

"Your left nostril is slightly stained, and there is a faint smell of snuff about you."

"Well, I do take snuff," said Wilson, "but I never thought anyone could tell it."

"Thirdly," said Holmes, "you are a Freemason."

"How do you know that?" asked Wilson.

"You wear a Masonic breastpin, but it is a little out of the ordinary. The compass and square are reversed."

"Yes," said Wilson, "I am a Freemason, but I never thought anyone would notice my pin."

"Fourthly," said Holmes, "you have spent some time in China."

Wilson laughed. "How on earth do you know that?"

"There is a tattoo of a fish on your right wrist, and the pink staining is a method used only in China. Also, you have a Chinese coin on your watch chain."

"Well, I must say you are a wonderful man," said Wilson, "but I think you have been looking very closely."

"Lastly," said Holmes, "you have been doing a good deal of writing lately."

"How do you know that?"

"Your right cuff is worn, and there is a smooth patch on your left sleeve near the elbow, which shows that you have been resting your arm on a desk."

Wilson laughed heartily. "Well, I must say you are a wonderful man, Mr. Holmes. I am quite amazed at your powers of observation."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The portly client puffed out his chest with an appearance of some little pride and pulled a dirty and wrinkled newspaper from the inside pocket of his greatcoat. "You see here, Mr. Holmes," he began, pointing to a small paragraph in the corner of the page, "this is the very matter that has brought me to your door. It concerns the disappearance of my dear friend, Mr. John Hector McFarlane."

Holmes adjusted his position in the chair, his keen eyes fixed upon the man before him. "Pray, continue," he said, his voice calm but eager.

"Mr. McFarlane was last seen at the Langham Hotel, where he had been staying for the past week. He was a man of some means, a gentleman of leisure, and yet he vanished without a trace. The police have been of little assistance, and I fear foul play."

Watson leaned forward, intrigued by the tale. "Did he have any enemies?"

"None that I am aware of," the client replied. "He was well-liked, though somewhat reserved. But there is more. Before his disappearance, he received a series of letters, all unsigned, warning him to leave London at once."

Holmes tapped his fingers thoughtfully. "Letters, you say? May I see them?"

The man nodded and produced a small bundle of envelopes, each bearing no return address. Holmes examined them carefully, noting the peculiar handwriting and the choice of words.

"These letters are indeed curious," Holmes remarked. "They suggest a threat, yet are couched in polite terms. It is as if the sender wishes to warn rather than harm."

"Precisely," the client agreed. "But Mr. McFarlane took no heed and remained in the city. Then, one evening, he vanished."

Holmes rose and began to pace the room. "Tell me, did Mr. McFarlane have any particular habits or routines?"

"He was fond of evening walks along the Thames and often visited the British Museum."

"Interesting," Holmes mused. "And his disappearance coincided with any notable events?"

"Not that I know of, but I have heard whispers of a secret society operating in London, one that Mr. McFarlane might have stumbled upon."

Holmes's eyes gleamed. "A secret society, you say? This case grows more intriguing by the moment. I shall take the matter in hand at once."

The client expressed his gratitude, and as he departed, Holmes turned to Watson. "We have before us a puzzle that promises to test our wits. Let us prepare for a journey into the shadows of London, where secrets lie hidden and danger lurks at every corner."

Thus began another adventure in the chronicles of Sherlock Holmes, a tale of mystery, intrigue, and the relentless pursuit of truth.

events.title: The Mysterious Advertisement for the Red-Headed League
detailed_summary: Holmes remarks to Watson that explaining his methods diminishes their mystique and potentially harms his reputation.
He asks Wilson if he has located the advertisement.
Wilson confirms, pointing to it in the newspaper column, stating it's the origin of the whole affair.
He hands the paper to Watson.

Watson reads the advertisement aloud: it announces a vacancy in the Red-Headed League, offering £4 per week for nominal services to eligible red-headed men over twenty-one, funded by the late Ezekiah Hopkins. Applicants are directed to apply in person at 7 Pope’s Court, Fleet Street.
Watson expresses bafflement at the strange announcement.
Holmes chuckles, agreeing it's unusual, and prompts Wilson to narrate his story from the beginning, including details about his household and the advertisement's impact.
Holmes instructs Watson to record the newspaper's name and date.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “I begin to think, Watson,” said Holmes, “that I make a mistake in explaining.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: You will first make a note, Doctor, of the paper and the date.”

events.text_segment:
“I begin to think, Watson,” said Holmes, “that I make a mistake in explaining. ‘Omne ignotum pro magnifico,’ you know, and my poor little reputation, such as it is, will suffer shipwreck if I am so candid. Can you not find the advertisement, Mr. Wilson?”
“Yes, I have got it now,” he answered with his thick red finger planted halfway down the column. “Here it is. This is what began it all. You just read it for yourself, sir.”
I took the paper from him and read as follows:
“TO THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE: On account of the bequest of the late Ezekiah Hopkins, of Lebanon, Pennsylvania, U.S.A., there is now another vacancy open which entitles a member of the League to a salary of £ 4 a week for purely nominal services. All red-headed men who are sound in body and mind and above the age of twenty-one years, are eligible. Apply in person on Monday, at eleven o’clock, to Duncan Ross, at the offices of the League, 7 Pope’s Court, Fleet Street.”
“What on earth does this mean?” I ejaculated after I had twice read over the extraordinary announcement.
Holmes chuckled and wriggled in his chair, as was his habit when in high spirits. “It is a little off the beaten track, isn’t it?” said he. “And now, Mr. Wilson, off you go at scratch and tell us all about yourself, your household, and the effect which this advertisement had upon your fortunes. You will first make a note, Doctor, of the paper and the date.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
"I begin to think, Watson," said Holmes, "that I make a mistake in explaining to you my reasons for things. Nothing clears a case so much as stating it to another person, and yet the very object of a mystery is to be inexplicable and mysterious. If you explain it, it ceases to be a mystery. I am afraid, therefore, that I shall have to disappoint you in many of the cases which I have solved."

"I am quite content to be disappointed," said I.

"Then I will tell you what I have done in the present instance. Have you found the advertisement?"

"Here it is," said Mr. Jabez Wilson, pointing to a paragraph in the middle of the column.

I took the paper from his hand and read as follows:

"'Red-Headed League. — Wanted, a number of red-headed men. To do small clerical work for two hours each day, and receive £4 a week. Apply to the Red-Headed League, 7 Pope's Court, Fleet Street.'"

"That is the origin of the whole affair," said Mr. Wilson.

"It is certainly very strange," I remarked.

"Very," said Holmes, chuckling. "Now, Mr. Wilson, I want you to tell me the whole story from the beginning."

"Well, sir," said the man, "I am a pawnbroker, and I have a small shop at 7 Pope's Court, Fleet Street. I am a red-headed man myself, and I have a very red head."

"Yes, I see that," said Holmes.

"Well, sir, one day I was sitting in my office when a gentleman came in and handed me a notice which he said was an advertisement. He told me that the Red-Headed League was formed for the purpose of employing red-headed men, and that I was eligible."

"And you applied?"

"Yes, sir, I did. I went to the office at 7 Pope's Court, and I was engaged at once."

"And what did you have to do?"

"Why, sir, I had to copy out the Encyclopaedia Britannica for two hours each day, and I was paid £4 a week for it."

"That is very curious," said Holmes. "Watson, you had better note down the name of the paper and the date of the advertisement."

“I begin to think, Watson,” said Holmes, “that I make a mistake in explaining. The more I explain, the less you seem to understand.”

“On the contrary, Holmes,” I replied, “your explanations are always clear, but this case is particularly perplexing.”

Holmes smiled faintly. “Very well, then. Let me start from the beginning. It all began with a visit from a distressed young woman, Miss Violet Hunter, who sought my assistance regarding her new position as a governess at a remote estate called Holdernesse. She was troubled by strange occurrences and the mysterious behavior of her employer, Mr. Rucastle.”

I nodded, recalling the details. “Yes, the case of the 'Copper Beeches.' The peculiar instructions Miss Hunter received about her attire and conduct were indeed unusual.”

“Precisely,” Holmes continued. “The key to the mystery lay in those instructions and the secret that Mr. Rucastle was desperate to conceal. Through careful observation and deduction, I discovered that the family was hiding a dark secret involving a missing daughter and a sinister plot to secure an inheritance.”

Holmes leaned back, his eyes gleaming. “It was a case that tested my powers of reasoning, but ultimately, justice prevailed. The truth, as always, was stranger than fiction.”

I sighed, impressed by Holmes’s insight. “Your methods never cease to amaze me, Holmes.”

He smiled modestly. “Elementary, my dear Watson.”

events.title: Mr. Wilson Describes His Pawnshop and Assistant
detailed_summary: Watson notes the newspaper is The Morning Chronicle from April 27, 1890, about two months prior.
Wilson begins his narrative, explaining he owns a small pawnbroker's business near the City, which barely provides a living.
He mentions he now employs only one assistant, having previously had two.
The current assistant, Vincent Spaulding, works for half wages to learn the trade.
Holmes inquires about Spaulding.
Wilson describes Spaulding as smart and capable, likely able to earn more elsewhere, but seemingly content.
Holmes remarks on the rarity of finding an employee willing to work below market rate, finding the assistant as noteworthy as the advertisement.
Wilson concedes Spaulding has a fault: an obsession with photography, often developing pictures in the cellar when he should be working, but otherwise considers him a good, vice-free worker.
Wilson confirms Spaulding is still employed.
He adds that his household consists only of himself (a widower with no family), Spaulding, and a young girl who handles cooking and cleaning.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “It is The Morning Chronicle of April 27, 1890.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: We live very quietly, sir, the three of us; and we keep a roof over our heads and pay our debts, if we do nothing more.

events.text_segment:
“It is The Morning Chronicle of April 27, 1890. Just two months ago.”
“Very good. Now, Mr. Wilson?”
“Well, it is just as I have been telling you, Mr. Sherlock Holmes,” said Jabez Wilson, mopping his forehead; “I have a small pawnbroker’s business at Coburg Square, near the City. It’s not a very large affair, and of late years it has not done more than just give me a living. I used to be able to keep two assistants, but now I only keep one; and I would have a job to pay him but that he is willing to come for half wages so as to learn the business.”
“What is the name of this obliging youth?” asked Sherlock Holmes.
“His name is Vincent Spaulding, and he’s not such a youth, either. It’s hard to say his age. I should not wish a smarter assistant, Mr. Holmes; and I know very well that he could better himself and earn twice what I am able to give him. But, after all, if he is satisfied, why should I put ideas in his head?”
“Why, indeed? You seem most fortunate in having an employé who comes under the full market price. It is not a common experience among employers in this age. I don’t know that your assistant is not as remarkable as your advertisement.”
“Oh, he has his faults, too,” said Mr. Wilson. “Never was such a fellow for photography. Snapping away with a camera when he ought to be improving his mind, and then diving down into the cellar like a rabbit into its hole to develop his pictures. That is his main fault, but on the whole he’s a good worker. There’s no vice in him.”
“He is still with you, I presume?”
“Yes, sir. He and a girl of fourteen, who does a bit of simple cooking and keeps the place clean—that’s all I have in the house, for I am a widower and never had any family. We live very quietly, sir, the three of us; and we keep a roof over our heads and pay our debts, if we do nothing more.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
It is The Morning Chronicle of April 27, 1890.

"You will observe that the date is nearly two months back. It was just two months ago that this curious affair took place, and I have been asked to relate it to you in my own words."

"I am a pawnbroker," said Mr. Jabez Wilson, "carrying on my business at No. 7, King’s Road, Red Lion Square, in the City. It is not a very profitable business, and I have to work very hard to make both ends meet. I have had two assistants in my time, but now I employ only one."

"My present assistant is a young man named Vincent Spaulding. He is a very smart fellow, and I have no doubt that he could earn more money elsewhere, but he is content to work for half wages in order to learn the trade."

"I see," said Holmes. "And what sort of a man is this Spaulding?"

"He is a very capable lad, and I have no fault to find with him, except that he has a mania for photography. He often goes down into the cellar to develop his pictures when he ought to be attending to the shop. But otherwise, he is a good, steady, and sober lad, and I have no reason to complain."

"Is he still with you?"

"Yes, he is."

"And who else is in your household?"

"Only myself, a widower with no family, Spaulding, and a young girl who does the cooking and cleaning."

“It is The Morning Chronicle of April 27, 1890. The paper is quite old, the edges yellowed and the ink slightly faded, but the headlines are still legible. The main story details a curious case that has gripped London society—a mysterious disappearance that has left the police baffled. The article describes the sudden vanishing of a prominent gentleman, Mr. John Hargreaves, who was last seen leaving his home late at night under peculiar circumstances. Witnesses reported hearing strange noises and seeing shadowy figures near his residence, but no concrete evidence has been found.

Sherlock Holmes, ever the keen observer, has taken a particular interest in the case. The article mentions that Holmes was seen at the scene, examining footprints and questioning neighbors. Dr. Watson, his faithful companion, is also quoted, expressing confidence in Holmes's ability to unravel the mystery. The piece highlights the detective's reputation for solving the most perplexing cases, often relying on his unparalleled powers of deduction and keen attention to detail.

Further down the page, there is a smaller column discussing recent developments in forensic science, including the use of fingerprint analysis and chemical tests, which Holmes is said to employ in his investigations. The article suggests that these advancements may prove crucial in solving the Hargreaves case.

The newspaper also features advertisements for various products and services, from patent medicines to the latest fashion trends, providing a glimpse into the daily life of Victorian London. A serialized story captures readers' imaginations, while letters to the editor reveal public opinion on current events.

As I fold the paper and set it aside, I am reminded of the enduring allure of mystery and the relentless pursuit of truth that defines the work of Sherlock Holmes. Each case, no matter how confounding, is an opportunity to apply reason and uncover the hidden threads that connect seemingly unrelated clues. It is this dedication to logic and justice that continues to captivate readers and inspire those who seek to understand the complexities of human nature.”

events.title: Applying for the Red-Headed League Position
detailed_summary: Wilson recounts how Spaulding brought the newspaper advertisement to his attention eight weeks prior, wishing he were red-headed himself.
Spaulding explained the League offered a fortune for little work and implied vacancies outnumbered qualified applicants.
Wilson, being largely homebound due to his business, was unaware of the League and asked for details.
Spaulding expressed surprise at Wilson's ignorance, pointing out Wilson's own eligibility.
He estimated the position paid a couple hundred pounds a year with minimal interference with other work.
Wilson, whose business was struggling, became interested in the extra income.

Spaulding elaborated, based on the ad, that the League was founded by a peculiar American millionaire, Ezekiah Hopkins, who sympathized with red-headed men and left his fortune to provide them easy jobs.
Wilson worried about immense competition, but Spaulding claimed it was limited to Londoners and men with truly fiery red hair, suggesting Wilson would easily qualify.
Confident in his hair color and spurred by Spaulding's knowledge, Wilson closed his shop for the day and went with Spaulding to the address.
Wilson describes an astonishing scene: Fleet Street packed with red-headed men of every shade responding to the ad.
Despite Wilson's despair at the competition, Spaulding energetically pushed him through the crowd to the office entrance.
They joined the flow of hopeful applicants going up the stairs and dejected ones coming down, eventually reaching the office.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “The first thing that put us out was that advertisement.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: There was a double stream upon the stair, some going up in hope, and some coming back dejected; but we wedged in as well as we could and soon found ourselves in the office.”

events.text_segment:
“The first thing that put us out was that advertisement. Spaulding, he came down into the office just this day eight weeks, with this very paper in his hand, and he says:
“‘I wish to the Lord, Mr. Wilson, that I was a red-headed man.’
“‘Why that?’ I asks.
“‘Why,’ says he, ‘here’s another vacancy on the League of the Red-headed Men. It’s worth quite a little fortune to any man who gets it, and I understand that there are more vacancies than there are men, so that the trustees are at their wits’ end what to do with the money. If my hair would only change colour, here’s a nice little crib all ready for me to step into.’
“‘Why, what is it, then?’ I asked. You see, Mr. Holmes, I am a very stay-at-home man, and as my business came to me instead of my having to go to it, I was often weeks on end without putting my foot over the door-mat. In that way I didn’t know much of what was going on outside, and I was always glad of a bit of news.
“‘Have you never heard of the League of the Red-headed Men?’ he asked with his eyes open.
“‘Never.’
“‘Why, I wonder at that, for you are eligible yourself for one of the vacancies.’
“‘And what are they worth?’ I asked.
“‘Oh, merely a couple of hundred a year, but the work is slight, and it need not interfere very much with one’s other occupations.’
“Well, you can easily think that that made me prick up my ears, for the business has not been over good for some years, and an extra couple of hundred would have been very handy.
“‘Tell me all about it,’ said I.
“‘Well,’ said he, showing me the advertisement, ‘you can see for yourself that the League has a vacancy, and there is the address where you should apply for particulars. As far as I can make out, the League was founded by an American millionaire, Ezekiah Hopkins, who was very peculiar in his ways. He was himself red-headed, and he had a great sympathy for all red-headed men; so, when he died, it was found that he had left his enormous fortune in the hands of trustees, with instructions to apply the interest to the providing of easy berths to men whose hair is of that colour. From all I hear it is splendid pay and very little to do.’
“‘But,’ said I, ‘there would be millions of red-headed men who would apply.’
“‘Not so many as you might think,’ he answered. ‘You see it is really confined to Londoners, and to grown men. This American had started from London when he was young, and he wanted to do the old town a good turn. Then, again, I have heard it is no use your applying if your hair is light red, or dark red, or anything but real bright, blazing, fiery red. Now, if you cared to apply, Mr. Wilson, you would just walk in; but perhaps it would hardly be worth your while to put yourself out of the way for the sake of a few hundred pounds.’
“Now, it is a fact, gentlemen, as you may see for yourselves, that my hair is of a very full and rich tint, so that it seemed to me that if there was to be any competition in the matter I stood as good a chance as any man that I had ever met. Vincent Spaulding seemed to know so much about it that I thought he might prove useful, so I just ordered him to put up the shutters for the day and to come right away with me. He was very willing to have a holiday, so we shut the business up and started off for the address that was given us in the advertisement.
“I never hope to see such a sight as that again, Mr. Holmes. From north, south, east, and west every man who had a shade of red in his hair had tramped into the city to answer the advertisement. Fleet Street was choked with red-headed folk, and Pope’s Court looked like a coster’s orange barrow. I should not have thought there were so many in the whole country as were brought together by that single advertisement. Every shade of colour they were—straw, lemon, orange, brick, Irish-setter, liver, clay; but, as Spaulding said, there were not many who had the real vivid flame-coloured tint. When I saw how many were waiting, I would have given it up in despair; but Spaulding would not hear of it. How he did it I could not imagine, but he pushed and pulled and butted until he got me through the crowd, and right up to the steps which led to the office. There was a double stream upon the stair, some going up in hope, and some coming back dejected; but we wedged in as well as we could and soon found ourselves in the office.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“The first thing that put us out was that advertisement. It was a curious one, and not at all in the usual style of the newspapers. It read: ‘Wanted, a gentleman to go to the country for a few weeks. Must be a man of good character and discretion. Apply to Mr. John Clay, 221B Baker Street.’

My friend Sherlock Holmes and I were sitting in our rooms at Baker Street when this advertisement caught our attention. It was unusual, and the wording was so vague that it piqued Holmes’s curiosity immediately. He was always on the lookout for a new case, and this seemed to be an invitation to something out of the ordinary.

We decided to investigate further. Holmes, with his keen eye for detail, noticed that the advertisement had been placed in a very obscure newspaper, one that was not widely circulated. This suggested that the person behind it wanted to keep the matter discreet.

The next day, we visited the address mentioned in the advertisement. It was a modest house in a quiet part of the city. We were greeted by a man who introduced himself as Mr. John Clay. He was a gentleman of about thirty, with a calm demeanor and an air of confidence.

Mr. Clay explained that he was organizing a small expedition to the countryside and was in need of a trustworthy companion. He emphasized the importance of discretion and good character, which explained the nature of the advertisement.

Holmes was intrigued and agreed to accompany Mr. Clay. We set off the following morning, traveling by train to a remote village several miles from London. The countryside was serene, a stark contrast to the bustling city we had left behind.

Upon arrival, we were met by a local guide who led us to a quaint cottage nestled among the rolling hills. The cottage was charming, with a garden full of blooming flowers and a view that stretched for miles.

Over the next few days, we explored the area, enjoying the fresh air and the peaceful surroundings. However, Holmes remained vigilant, observing the behavior of Mr. Clay and the locals.

One evening, as we sat by the fireplace, Mr. Clay confided in us that he was searching for a hidden treasure rumored to be buried somewhere in the vicinity. The treasure was said to have been left by a wealthy nobleman who had lived in the area centuries ago.

Holmes’s eyes lit up at the mention of a treasure hunt. He was a man of logic and deduction, but he also appreciated the thrill of a good mystery. We agreed to assist Mr. Clay in his quest.

We began our search by examining old maps and documents that Mr. Clay had collected. Holmes used his analytical skills to piece together clues from the historical records, leading us to believe that the treasure was hidden in an ancient ruin nearby.

The ruins were a series of stone structures, overgrown with ivy and moss. They held an air of mystery and history, and as we explored them, we felt a connection to the past.

After several days of searching, Holmes discovered a hidden compartment beneath one of the stones. Inside, we found a small chest containing gold coins, jewels, and a letter explaining the nobleman’s intentions to preserve his wealth for future generations.

The discovery was thrilling, and we felt a sense of accomplishment. Mr. Clay was grateful for our help and promised to use the treasure wisely.

Our adventure in the countryside was a reminder of the unexpected mysteries that life can present. It was a pleasure to work alongside Holmes, whose intellect and determination never ceased to amaze me.

As we returned to London, I reflected on the journey and the lessons learned. The world is full of secrets waiting to be uncovered, and with a keen mind and a brave heart, one can unravel even the most perplexing enigmas.”

events.title: Securing the Position and Learning the Strange Duties
detailed_summary: Holmes encourages Wilson to continue his interesting story after Wilson pauses.
Wilson describes the sparse office containing only two chairs and a table, behind which sat a small man (Duncan Ross) with hair even redder than his.
Ross briefly interviewed candidates, finding fault with each until Wilson's turn.
Ross was immediately favorable towards Wilson, closing the door for privacy.
Spaulding introduced Wilson as an applicant.
Ross declared Wilson perfectly suited, admiring his hair.
As a precaution against wigs or dye, Ross grabbed Wilson's hair and pulled hard, causing pain but confirming its authenticity.
Ross shouted out the window that the vacancy was filled, eliciting groans from the crowd below.
He introduced himself as Duncan Ross, also a beneficiary of the fund.
Ross inquired if Wilson was married with a family, expressing disappointment upon learning he was a bachelor, stating the fund aimed to propagate red-heads.
Wilson feared losing the position, but Ross decided to make an exception due to Wilson's exceptional hair.
When asked about starting, Wilson mentioned his existing business.
Spaulding assured Wilson he could manage the pawnshop.
The required hours were ten AM to two PM, which suited Wilson as his pawnshop was busiest in the evenings.
The pay was confirmed as £4 per week for 'purely nominal' work.
The work involved being present in the office continuously during the specified hours, with any departure resulting in forfeiture of the position.
The task was to copy the Encyclopædia Britannica, starting with Volume One. Wilson had to provide his own supplies, but a table and chair were provided.
Wilson agreed to start the next day.
Ross congratulated Wilson again, and he left with Spaulding, overjoyed.

events.text_segment:
“Your experience has been a most entertaining one,” remarked Holmes as his client paused and refreshed his memory with a huge pinch of snuff. “Pray continue your very interesting statement.”
“There was nothing in the office but a couple of wooden chairs and a deal table, behind which sat a small man with a head that was even redder than mine. He said a few words to each candidate as he came up, and then he always managed to find some fault in them which would disqualify them. Getting a vacancy did not seem to be such a very easy matter, after all. However, when our turn came the little man was much more favourable to me than to any of the others, and he closed the door as we entered, so that he might have a private word with us.
“‘This is Mr. Jabez Wilson,’ said my assistant, ‘and he is willing to fill a vacancy in the League.’
“‘And he is admirably suited for it,’ the other answered. ‘He has every requirement. I cannot recall when I have seen anything so fine.’ He took a step backward, cocked his head on one side, and gazed at my hair until I felt quite bashful. Then suddenly he plunged forward, wrung my hand, and congratulated me warmly on my success.
“‘It would be injustice to hesitate,’ said he. ‘You will, however, I am sure, excuse me for taking an obvious precaution.’ With that he seized my hair in both his hands, and tugged until I yelled with the pain. ‘There is water in your eyes,’ said he as he released me. ‘I perceive that all is as it should be. But we have to be careful, for we have twice been deceived by wigs and once by paint. I could tell you tales of cobbler’s wax which would disgust you with human nature.’ He stepped over to the window and shouted through it at the top of his voice that the vacancy was filled. A groan of disappointment came up from below, and the folk all trooped away in different directions until there was not a red-head to be seen except my own and that of the manager.
“‘My name,’ said he, ‘is Mr. Duncan Ross, and I am myself one of the pensioners upon the fund left by our noble benefactor. Are you a married man, Mr. Wilson? Have you a family?’
“I answered that I had not.
“His face fell immediately.
“‘Dear me!’ he said gravely, ‘that is very serious indeed! I am sorry to hear you say that. The fund was, of course, for the propagation and spread of the red-heads as well as for their maintenance. It is exceedingly unfortunate that you should be a bachelor.’
“My face lengthened at this, Mr. Holmes, for I thought that I was not to have the vacancy after all; but after thinking it over for a few minutes he said that it would be all right.
“‘In the case of another,’ said he, ‘the objection might be fatal, but we must stretch a point in favour of a man with such a head of hair as yours. When shall you be able to enter upon your new duties?’
“‘Well, it is a little awkward, for I have a business already,’ said I.
“‘Oh, never mind about that, Mr. Wilson!’ said Vincent Spaulding. ‘I should be able to look after that for you.’
“‘What would be the hours?’ I asked.
“‘Ten to two.’
“Now a pawnbroker’s business is mostly done of an evening, Mr. Holmes, especially Thursday and Friday evening, which is just before pay-day; so it would suit me very well to earn a little in the mornings. Besides, I knew that my assistant was a good man, and that he would see to anything that turned up.
“‘That would suit me very well,’ said I. ‘And the pay?’
“‘Is £ 4 a week.’
“‘And the work?’
“‘Is purely nominal.’
“‘What do you call purely nominal?’
“‘Well, you have to be in the office, or at least in the building, the whole time. If you leave, you forfeit your whole position forever. The will is very clear upon that point. You don’t comply with the conditions if you budge from the office during that time.’
“‘It’s only four hours a day, and I should not think of leaving,’ said I.
“‘No excuse will avail,’ said Mr. Duncan Ross; ‘neither sickness nor business nor anything else. There you must stay, or you lose your billet.’
“‘And the work?’
“‘Is to copy out the Encyclopædia Britannica. There is the first volume of it in that press. You must find your own ink, pens, and blotting-paper, but we provide this table and chair. Will you be ready to-morrow?’
“‘Certainly,’ I answered.
“‘Then, good-bye, Mr. Jabez Wilson, and let me congratulate you once more on the important position which you have been fortunate enough to gain.’ He bowed me out of the room and I went home with my assistant, hardly knowing what to say or do, I was so pleased at my own good fortune.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
"Your experience has been a most entertaining one," remarked Holmes as his client paused and refreshed his memory with a huge pinch of snuff.

"I am afraid that I have kept you here too long," said Wilson apologetically. "I will be as brief as I can."

"Pray do so," said Holmes.

"Well, then, the office was a small room, with only two chairs and a table in it. Behind the table sat a little man, with a face like a rat, and hair redder than any I had ever seen."

"What! redder than yours?" asked Holmes.

"Yes, indeed, and that is saying a good deal."

"Go on."

"He was a very sharp man, and he looked me over from head to foot. He asked me a few questions, and then he said, 'You are the very man we want.'"

"Did he say why?"

"No, but he looked at my hair again and again. Then he said, 'You will have to come in to-morrow morning at ten o'clock.'"

"Did he give you any address?"

"Yes, he gave me the address of the office."

"And what happened then?"

"I went home, and the next morning I was at the office at ten o'clock sharp."

"Did you see the little man again?"

"Yes, and he introduced himself as Duncan Ross."

"Did he say anything about the League?"

"Yes, he told me that I was to be a member of the Red-Headed League, a society which had been formed for the benefit of red-headed men."

"What was the object of the society?"

"To give red-headed men employment and to help them in their business."

"Did he say what your duties would be?"

"Yes, he said that I was to copy out the Encyclopædia Britannica."

"Copy out the Encyclopædia Britannica!" exclaimed Holmes.

"Yes, every day from ten to two, and I was to be paid four pounds a week for the work."

"Did you have to bring your own materials?"

"Yes, I had to bring my own ink and paper, but there was a table and a chair for me in the office."

"And did you do the work?"

"Yes, I did it for several weeks."

"Did you ever see the other members of the League?"

"No, I never did."

"Did you ever see the man who introduced you?"

"No, he was always away when I was there."

"Did you ever see the man who brought you to the office?"

"Yes, that was Vincent Spaulding, my assistant in the pawnbroker's shop."

"Did you ever suspect anything?"

"No, I was quite content with my work and my pay."

"And then?"

"Then one day the League was suddenly dissolved, and I was turned out of the office."

"That is the story in brief," said Wilson, "and now I have told you all I know."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“Your experience has been a most entertaining one,” remarked Holmes as his client paused and refreshed his memory with a huge pinch of snuff. “But I am afraid that it is not one which will help us much in the present case.”

Mr. James Windibank, a tall, thin man with a nervous manner, had come to Holmes with a peculiar problem. He was the secretary to a wealthy gentleman, Mr. John Hector McFarlane, who had recently been the victim of a strange theft. A valuable emerald, a family heirloom, had disappeared from the safe in Mr. McFarlane’s study, and no one could explain how it had vanished.

“I have examined the safe myself,” said Windibank, “and it is a most secure one. It was locked when I left the room, and when I returned, the emerald was gone, but the safe was still locked. There is no sign of forced entry, and the key has never left my possession.”

Holmes nodded thoughtfully. “And what of the other servants? Have they been questioned?”

“All of them,” replied Windibank. “But none of them saw or heard anything unusual. The house is large, and the staff are numerous, but no one noticed any stranger or any suspicious activity.”

Holmes leaned back in his chair, steepling his fingers. “This is indeed a curious case. The emerald has vanished from a locked safe, with no sign of entry or exit. It suggests that the thief is someone with intimate knowledge of the house and its inhabitants.”

“Precisely,” said Windibank. “That is why I came to you. Mr. McFarlane is most anxious to recover the jewel, and he trusts your abilities.”

Holmes smiled. “I shall do my best. Now, tell me, Mr. Windibank, have you noticed anything unusual about the safe or the room in which it is kept?”

Windibank hesitated. “Well, there is one thing. The safe is built into the wall, and there is a panel nearby that seems to be loose. I thought it might be a secret compartment, but I did not investigate further.”

Holmes’s eyes gleamed. “A secret panel, you say? That may be the key to our mystery. I should like to see the room at once.”

They proceeded to Mr. McFarlane’s study, a spacious room lined with bookshelves and adorned with fine paintings. Holmes examined the safe carefully, noting its make and the mechanism of its lock. Then he turned to the panel Windibank had mentioned.

“Let me see that,” he said, pressing his fingers against the wood. The panel gave slightly under his touch, and with a gentle push, it swung open to reveal a narrow passage.

“Aha!” exclaimed Holmes. “This is most interesting. A secret passage leading from the study to another part of the house. Do you know where it leads?”

Windibank shook his head. “No, I was not aware of it until now.”

Holmes took out his lantern and peered into the darkness. “I shall explore this passage. You, Mr. Windibank, will remain here and await my return.”

He disappeared into the passage, the lantern casting flickering shadows on the walls. After a few minutes, he returned, his face alight with excitement.

“The passage leads to the cellar beneath the house,” he said. “And I have found the emerald.”

Windibank’s eyes widened. “You have? How is that possible?”

Holmes held up the jewel, its green facets sparkling in the lamplight. “The thief used this secret passage to remove the emerald from the safe and hide it in the cellar. It was a clever plan, but not clever enough to escape my notice.”

“But who could have done such a thing?” asked Windibank.

Holmes smiled. “That is the question we must now answer. And I believe I have a good idea.”

He turned to Windibank. “Tell me, have you noticed anything unusual about the behavior of the other servants recently?”

Windibank thought for a moment. “Well, the butler, Mr. Grimes, has been acting strangely. He has been nervous and evasive.”

Holmes nodded. “I thought as much. Let us confront him.”

They found Mr. Grimes in the kitchen, polishing silverware. Holmes approached him calmly.

“Mr. Grimes, I have reason to believe that you are involved in the theft of the emerald.”

The butler’s face paled. “I—I don’t know what you mean, sir.”

Holmes fixed him with a steady gaze. “The secret passage, the hidden jewel, your nervous behavior—it all points to you.”

Grimes broke down and confessed. He had been in debt and had planned to steal the emerald to pay off his creditors. He had discovered the secret passage and used it to remove the jewel without detection.

Mr. McFarlane was grateful to Holmes for recovering the family heirloom and resolving the mystery. As for Holmes, he was pleased to have once again demonstrated the power of observation and deduction.

“Another case closed,” he said, lighting his pipe. “And a reminder that even the most secure places can be vulnerable to those who know their secrets.”

events.title: The Copying Task and the League's Sudden Dissolution
detailed_summary: Wilson recounts his initial doubts after securing the job, suspecting a hoax due to the implausibility of the will and the simple task.
Spaulding tried to reassure him, but Wilson remained skeptical.
The next morning, Wilson decided to investigate, bought supplies, and went to Pope's Court.
To his surprise, everything was legitimate: the table was ready, and Duncan Ross was present to start him on his work copying the encyclopedia from 'A'.
Ross checked on him periodically at first, then less frequently, eventually not appearing at all.
Wilson diligently copied the encyclopedia daily from ten to two, never daring to leave, and filled nearly a shelf with his writings.
He received his payment of four gold sovereigns each Saturday.
After eight weeks of this routine, having worked through entries like Abbots, Archery, Armour, Architecture, and Attica, the situation abruptly ended.
That very morning, Wilson arrived to find the office door shut and locked.
A small cardboard sign was tacked to the door.
Wilson presents the cardboard sign to Holmes and Watson.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Well, I thought over the matter all day, and by evening I was in low spirits again; for I had quite persuaded myself that the whole affair must be some great hoax or fraud, though what its object might be I could not imagine.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Here it is, and you can read for yourself.”

events.text_segment:
“Well, I thought over the matter all day, and by evening I was in low spirits again; for I had quite persuaded myself that the whole affair must be some great hoax or fraud, though what its object might be I could not imagine. It seemed altogether past belief that anyone could make such a will, or that they would pay such a sum for doing anything so simple as copying out the Encyclopædia Britannica. Vincent Spaulding did what he could to cheer me up, but by bedtime I had reasoned myself out of the whole thing. However, in the morning I determined to have a look at it anyhow, so I bought a penny bottle of ink, and with a quill-pen, and seven sheets of foolscap paper, I started off for Pope’s Court.
“Well, to my surprise and delight, everything was as right as possible. The table was set out ready for me, and Mr. Duncan Ross was there to see that I got fairly to work. He started me off upon the letter A, and then he left me; but he would drop in from time to time to see that all was right with me. At two o’clock he bade me good-day, complimented me upon the amount that I had written, and locked the door of the office after me.
“This went on day after day, Mr. Holmes, and on Saturday the manager came in and planked down four golden sovereigns for my week’s work. It was the same next week, and the same the week after. Every morning I was there at ten, and every afternoon I left at two. By degrees Mr. Duncan Ross took to coming in only once of a morning, and then, after a time, he did not come in at all. Still, of course, I never dared to leave the room for an instant, for I was not sure when he might come, and the billet was such a good one, and suited me so well, that I would not risk the loss of it.
“Eight weeks passed away like this, and I had written about Abbots and Archery and Armour and Architecture and Attica, and hoped with diligence that I might get on to the B’s before very long. It cost me something in foolscap, and I had pretty nearly filled a shelf with my writings. And then suddenly the whole business came to an end.”
“To an end?”
“Yes, sir. And no later than this morning. I went to my work as usual at ten o’clock, but the door was shut and locked, with a little square of cardboard hammered on to the middle of the panel with a tack. Here it is, and you can read for yourself.”

"Well, I thought over the matter all day, and by evening I was in low spirits again; for I had quite persuaded myself that the whole affair must be some great hoax or fraud, though what its object might be I could not imagine. I was on the point of going to the police, when my assistant, Vincent Spaulding, who is a most valuable fellow, and a man of excellent character, said to me, 'Now, look here, Mr. Wilson, you must not be so downhearted. I have been in the city all day, and I have made inquiries, and I find that the Red-Headed League is a perfectly legitimate institution. I have seen the advertisement myself, and I have spoken to the secretary, a Mr. Duncan Ross, who is a very respectable man.' This reassured me a little, and I determined to go to the office in Pope's Court the next morning and see for myself.

When I arrived there, I found the place exactly as I had been told. The door was open, and a table was set up with writing materials. Mr. Duncan Ross was there, and he gave me the task of copying out the Encyclopaedia Britannica, starting from the letter 'A.' At first, he came to see me every hour or so, but as the days went by, his visits became less frequent, and eventually he ceased to come at all.

I worked diligently from ten in the morning until two in the afternoon, never daring to leave the office, and I filled nearly a whole shelf with my copied pages. Every Saturday, I received my four gold sovereigns, and I was content with my simple but steady employment.

After eight weeks of this routine, having copied entries such as 'Abbots,' 'Archery,' 'Armour,' 'Architecture,' and 'Attica,' I arrived one morning to find the door of the office shut and locked. A small cardboard notice was tacked to the door, which I have brought here for you to see."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
I was sitting in my armchair, with the firelight flickering on the walls, when Holmes entered the room, his eyes bright with excitement. "Watson," he said, "I believe we are on the verge of a most singular adventure. The case of the Speckled Band is far from a hoax. There is a very real danger here, and it is our duty to uncover the truth."

I looked up at him, my curiosity piqued despite my earlier doubts. "What makes you so certain, Holmes?"

He smiled faintly. "The details Miss Stoner provided, the strange noises, the mysterious death of her sister—these are not the fabrications of a troubled mind. There is a method to this madness, and I intend to find it."

The next morning, we set out for Stoke Moran, the ancestral home of the Roylott family. The house was a grim and forbidding place, with an air of decay and menace that seemed to seep from its very walls. As we approached, Holmes's keen eyes took in every detail—the barred windows, the heavy iron gates, the wild garden overgrown with weeds.

Inside, we were greeted by the housekeeper, a stern woman who seemed wary of our presence. Holmes questioned her carefully, gathering information about the household and its inhabitants. He was particularly interested in the room where Julia Stoner had died, noting the peculiar ventilator connecting it to the adjoining room, and the bell-pull that did not seem to function as a bell.

That night, Holmes and I took up our vigil in Julia's room, determined to uncover the secret that had claimed her life. Hours passed in tense silence, broken only by the occasional creak of the old house settling. Suddenly, a low, hissing sound filled the room, and a strange, glistening creature slithered from the ventilator toward the bed.

Holmes sprang into action, striking the creature with his cane and sending it recoiling. A light revealed the deadly serpent—the speckled band—that had been used as a weapon to murder Julia. The mystery was solved, and justice would be served.

As dawn broke over Stoke Moran, I reflected on the night's events and the brilliance of my friend's deductive powers. The case of the Speckled Band was a testament to the dangers that lurk beneath the surface of even the most ordinary lives, and to the courage required to confront them.

events.title: Investigation Attempts and Holmes Takes the Case
detailed_summary: The sign read: "THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE IS DISSOLVED. October 9, 1890."
Holmes and Watson burst into laughter at the abrupt notice and Wilson's dismayed expression.
Wilson, offended, threatens to leave if they only intend to laugh.
Holmes reassures him, finding the case refreshingly unusual despite its comical aspect, and urges him to continue.
Wilson explains his confusion and subsequent actions: inquiring at neighboring offices (none knew of the League) and questioning the landlord.
The landlord had never heard of the Red-Headed League and didn't know Duncan Ross.
When Wilson described the red-headed man in Room 4, the landlord identified him as William Morris, a solicitor who rented the room temporarily and had moved out the previous day.
The landlord provided Morris's new address: 17 King Edward Street.
Wilson went there but found a manufactory of artificial knee-caps, where no one knew Morris or Ross.
He returned home and consulted Spaulding, who offered no help beyond suggesting Wilson wait for news by post.
Unwilling to lose the position without answers, Wilson sought Holmes's advice.
Holmes commends Wilson's decision, acknowledging the case's remarkableness and potential gravity beyond the lost income.
Wilson laments the loss of £4 per week.
Holmes points out Wilson has actually gained about £30 and encyclopedic knowledge, having no real grievance against the League.
Wilson insists he wants to understand the perpetrators and their motive for the apparent prank.
Holmes agrees to investigate and asks about Spaulding: he'd been with Wilson about a month before the ad, hired cheaply from a dozen applicants.
Wilson describes Spaulding: small, stout, quick, clean-shaven despite being around thirty, with a white acid splash on his forehead.
Holmes becomes excited, confirming his suspicion, and asks if Spaulding's ears are pierced.
Wilson confirms, recalling Spaulding claimed a gypsy pierced them.
Holmes falls into deep thought, confirms Spaulding is still there, and asks if the business ran smoothly during Wilson's absences (it did, being quiet in the mornings).
Holmes concludes the interview, promising an opinion in a day or two, by Monday.

events.text_segment:
He held up a piece of white cardboard about the size of a sheet of note-paper. It read in this fashion:
“THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE IS DISSOLVED. October 9, 1890.”
Sherlock Holmes and I surveyed this curt announcement and the rueful face behind it, until the comical side of the affair so completely overtopped every other consideration that we both burst out into a roar of laughter.
“I cannot see that there is anything very funny,” cried our client, flushing up to the roots of his flaming head. “If you can do nothing better than laugh at me, I can go elsewhere.”
“No, no,” cried Holmes, shoving him back into the chair from which he had half risen. “I really wouldn’t miss your case for the world. It is most refreshingly unusual. But there is, if you will excuse my saying so, something just a little funny about it. Pray what steps did you take when you found the card upon the door?”
“I was staggered, sir. I did not know what to do. Then I called at the offices round, but none of them seemed to know anything about it. Finally, I went to the landlord, who is an accountant living on the ground floor, and I asked him if he could tell me what had become of the Red-headed League. He said that he had never heard of any such body. Then I asked him who Mr. Duncan Ross was. He answered that the name was new to him.
“‘Well,’ said I, ‘the gentleman at No. 4.’
“‘What, the red-headed man?’
“‘Yes.’
“‘Oh,’ said he, ‘his name was William Morris. He was a solicitor and was using my room as a temporary convenience until his new premises were ready. He moved out yesterday.’
“‘Where could I find him?’
“‘Oh, at his new offices. He did tell me the address. Yes, 17 King Edward Street, near St. Paul’s.’
“I started off, Mr. Holmes, but when I got to that address it was a manufactory of artificial knee-caps, and no one in it had ever heard of either Mr. William Morris or Mr. Duncan Ross.”
“And what did you do then?” asked Holmes.
“I went home to Saxe-Coburg Square, and I took the advice of my assistant. But he could not help me in any way. He could only say that if I waited I should hear by post. But that was not quite good enough, Mr. Holmes. I did not wish to lose such a place without a struggle, so, as I had heard that you were good enough to give advice to poor folk who were in need of it, I came right away to you.”
“And you did very wisely,” said Holmes. “Your case is an exceedingly remarkable one, and I shall be happy to look into it. From what you have told me I think that it is possible that graver issues hang from it than might at first sight appear.”
“Grave enough!” said Mr. Jabez Wilson. “Why, I have lost four pound a week.”
“As far as you are personally concerned,” remarked Holmes, “I do not see that you have any grievance against this extraordinary league. On the contrary, you are, as I understand, richer by some £ 30, to say nothing of the minute knowledge which you have gained on every subject which comes under the letter A. You have lost nothing by them.”
“No, sir. But I want to find out about them, and who they are, and what their object was in playing this prank—if it was a prank—upon me. It was a pretty expensive joke for them, for it cost them two and thirty pounds.”
“We shall endeavour to clear up these points for you. And, first, one or two questions, Mr. Wilson. This assistant of yours who first called your attention to the advertisement—how long had he been with you?”
“About a month then.”
“How did he come?”
“In answer to an advertisement.”
“Was he the only applicant?”
“No, I had a dozen.”
“Why did you pick him?”
“Because he was handy and would come cheap.”
“At half wages, in fact.”
“Yes.”
“What is he like, this Vincent Spaulding?”
“Small, stout-built, very quick in his ways, no hair on his face, though he’s not short of thirty. Has a white splash of acid upon his forehead.”
Holmes sat up in his chair in considerable excitement. “I thought as much,” said he. “Have you ever observed that his ears are pierced for earrings?”
“Yes, sir. He told me that a gipsy had done it for him when he was a lad.”
“Hum!” said Holmes, sinking back in deep thought. “He is still with you?”
“Oh, yes, sir; I have only just left him.”
“And has your business been attended to in your absence?”
“Nothing to complain of, sir. There’s never very much to do of a morning.”
“That will do, Mr. Wilson. I shall be happy to give you an opinion upon the subject in the course of a day or two. To-day is Saturday, and I hope that by Monday we may come to a conclusion.”

He held up a piece of white cardboard about the size of a sheet of note-paper. Upon it was printed in red ink the words:—

"THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE IS DISSOLVED. October 9, 1890."

"What on earth does it mean?" I asked.

"I cannot make it out," said Wilson, looking very glum. "I came here this morning to get my work, and found the office all locked up. I asked the landlord what it meant, and he showed me this notice."

Holmes and I burst into a laugh. Wilson looked at us with some indignation.

"If you are going to laugh at me," said he, "I had better be going."

"No, no," said Holmes, "I assure you that I find the whole thing most interesting. It is not every day that one comes across a case which is remarkable and original. Pray continue your story."

Wilson explained that he had been a pawnbroker in a small shop in a quiet street in London. One day, he had seen an advertisement in the newspaper offering a position in the Red-Headed League, which was open only to men with red hair. The work was simple and paid well. He had applied and been accepted. For several weeks, he had gone to the League's office every day and copied the Encyclopaedia Britannica. Then, suddenly, the League was dissolved, and the notice was posted.

He had tried to find out more about the League by asking the neighboring offices, but no one had heard of it. The landlord had never heard of the Red-Headed League or of Duncan Ross, the man who had hired Wilson. When Wilson described the red-headed man who had occupied the office, the landlord identified him as William Morris, a solicitor who had rented the room temporarily and had moved out the previous day. The landlord gave Wilson Morris's new address, 17 King Edward Street.

Wilson had gone there, but found only a manufactory of artificial knee-caps, where no one knew Morris or Ross. He had returned home and consulted his assistant, Vincent Spaulding, who had been with him about a month before the advertisement appeared. Spaulding had offered no help beyond suggesting that Wilson wait for news by post.

Unwilling to lose the position without answers, Wilson had come to Holmes for advice.

Holmes commended Wilson's decision, acknowledging the case's remarkableness and potential gravity beyond the lost income. Wilson lamented the loss of four pounds a week. Holmes pointed out that Wilson had actually gained about thirty pounds and encyclopaedic knowledge, having no real grievance against the League.

Wilson insisted he wanted to understand the perpetrators and their motive for the apparent prank. Holmes agreed to investigate and asked about Spaulding. Wilson described Spaulding as small, stout, quick, clean-shaven despite being around thirty, with a white acid splash on his forehead.

Holmes became excited, confirming his suspicion, and asked if Spaulding's ears were pierced. Wilson confirmed, recalling Spaulding claimed a gypsy had pierced them.

Holmes fell into deep thought, confirmed Spaulding was still there, and asked if the business ran smoothly during Wilson's absences. Wilson said it did, being quiet in the mornings.

Holmes concluded the interview, promising an opinion in a day or two, by Monday.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
He held up a piece of white cardboard about the size of a sheet of note-paper. Upon it was printed in red ink the words:—

"THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE IS DISSOLVED. October 9, 1890."

"What on earth does it mean?" I asked.

"I cannot make it out," said Wilson, looking very glum. "I came here this morning to get my work, and found the office all locked up. I asked the landlord what it meant, and he showed me this notice."

Holmes and I burst into a laugh. Wilson looked at us with some indignation.

"If you are going to laugh at me," said he, "I had better be going."

"No, no," said Holmes, "I assure you that I find the whole thing most interesting. It is not every day that one comes across a case which is remarkable and original. Pray continue your story."

"Well, sir," said Wilson, "I went round to the offices next door, but no one had ever heard of the Red-Headed League. Then I asked the landlord, and he said he had never heard of it, and did not know any Duncan Ross. When I described the red-headed man who used to occupy the room, he said it was a solicitor named William Morris, who had rented the room for a few weeks, but had moved out yesterday. He gave me the address where he had gone, 17 King Edward Street."

"And did you go there?"

"Yes, sir. But it was a manufactory of artificial knee-caps, and no one there knew anything of Morris or Ross."

"And what did you do then?"

"I came back here, and I asked my assistant, Vincent Spaulding, if he knew anything about it. But he said he did not. He told me to wait and see if I got any letters."

"And you have had none?"

"None at all."

"And you have lost your position?"

"Yes, sir."

"And you have come to me for advice?"

"Yes, sir."

"I think you have done very wisely. It is a most singular business, and I should like to have a look at your assistant."

"He is in the shop now, sir."

"Show him in."

Vincent Spaulding entered, a small, stout, quick, alert man, with a very red face and a splash of white paint upon his forehead.

"How long have you been with Mr. Wilson?"

"About a month, sir."

"And how did you come to be engaged?"

"I answered an advertisement, sir."

"And were you the only applicant?"

"No, sir. There were a dozen."

"And why were you chosen?"

"Because I was the cheapest."

"I see. And you have been working steadily?"

"Yes, sir."

"And you have no idea what this Red-Headed League was?"

"No, sir."

"Have you any distinguishing marks?"

"Only that my ears are pierced."

"Indeed!" said Holmes, with a smile. "I think I have made up my mind."

He turned to Wilson.

"Is your business very quiet in the mornings?"

"Yes, sir."

"And you have no other assistants?"

"No, sir."

"Very good. I shall give you my opinion in a day or two. By Monday, at latest."

"Thank you, sir," said Wilson, rising.

"You are quite welcome. Good morning."
