LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
He had risen from his chair and was standing between the parted blinds gazing down into the dull neutral-tinted London street. The fog lay thick upon the city, muffling the sounds of the bustling crowd and the clatter of horse-drawn carriages. Holmes's keen eyes scanned the scene below, noting every detail with the precision of a master detective. Suddenly, his gaze fixed upon a solitary figure moving swiftly through the mist, a man whose hurried steps betrayed a sense of urgency.

"Watson," he said, turning sharply, "observe that gentleman. Notice his gait, the way he clutches his coat tightly around him. There is a story there, one that demands our attention."

I followed his gaze, intrigued by his sudden interest. "Do you believe he is connected to our case?"

Holmes nodded thoughtfully. "Indeed. The manner in which he avoids the gas lamps, the furtive glances over his shoulder—these are the actions of a man who fears pursuit. We must learn more."

Without hesitation, Holmes donned his coat and hat, motioning for me to accompany him. We descended the stairs and stepped into the fog-laden street, the chill air biting at our faces. The figure ahead moved with purpose, weaving through the labyrinth of alleys and side streets. Holmes quickened his pace, his eyes never leaving the man.

At last, the figure paused beneath a flickering lamp-post, glancing around nervously. Holmes approached with measured steps, his voice calm yet commanding. "Good evening, sir. Might I inquire as to your business in this part of town at such an hour?"

The man started, then composed himself. "I mean no harm, sir. I am but a humble clerk, caught in unfortunate circumstances."

Holmes's eyes gleamed with understanding. "Come, then. Let us discuss these circumstances in a more comfortable setting. There is much to unravel, and time is of the essence."

events.title: Miss Sutherland's Predicament and Initial Interview
detailed_summary: Miss Sutherland acknowledges the initial difficulty of typewriting with short sight but confirms she now types by touch.
Realizing Holmes deduced this without prior knowledge, she reacts with shock and asks how he knew.
Holmes dismisses her question, stating it's his business to observe overlooked details.
Miss Sutherland explains she was referred by Mrs. Etherege, whose husband Holmes had found.
She pleads for Holmes's help regarding a Mr. Hosmer Angel, offering her modest income as payment.
Holmes asks why she left home so abruptly to consult him.
Startled again, she confirms she left angrily due to her stepfather's (Mr. Windibank) dismissive attitude and refusal to involve Holmes or the police.
Holmes clarifies that Windibank is her stepfather, noting the different name.
She confirms, adding he is only five years older than her.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “I did at first,” she answered, “but now I know where the letters are without looking.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I call him father, though it sounds funny, too, for he is only five years and two months older than myself.”

events.text_segment:
“I did at first,” she answered, “but now I know where the letters are without looking.” Then, suddenly realising the full purport of his words, she gave a violent start and looked up, with fear and astonishment upon her broad, good-humoured face. “You’ve heard about me, Mr. Holmes,” she cried, “else how could you know all that?”
“Never mind,” said Holmes, laughing; “it is my business to know things. Perhaps I have trained myself to see what others overlook. If not, why should you come to consult me?”
“I came to you, sir, because I heard of you from Mrs. Etherege, whose husband you found so easy when the police and everyone had given him up for dead. Oh, Mr. Holmes, I wish you would do as much for me. I’m not rich, but still I have a hundred a year in my own right, besides the little that I make by the machine, and I would give it all to know what has become of Mr. Hosmer Angel.”
“Why did you come away to consult me in such a hurry?” asked Sherlock Holmes, with his finger-tips together and his eyes to the ceiling.
Again a startled look came over the somewhat vacuous face of Miss Mary Sutherland. “Yes, I did bang out of the house,” she said, “for it made me angry to see the easy way in which Mr. Windibank—that is, my father—took it all. He would not go to the police, and he would not go to you, and so at last, as he would do nothing and kept on saying that there was no harm done, it made me mad, and I just on with my things and came right away to you.”
“Your father,” said Holmes, “your stepfather, surely, since the name is different.”
“Yes, my stepfather. I call him father, though it sounds funny, too, for he is only five years and two months older than myself.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
"I did at first," she answered, "but now I know where the letters are without looking."

"Ah!" said Holmes, "you have learned to type by touch."

She looked at me in some surprise, and then at Holmes.

"How did you know?" she asked.

"It is my business to know what other people don't know," said Holmes. "You have a very good touch, and you have learned to type without looking at the keys."

"Yes, I have," she said. "It was very difficult at first, as I have very short sight, but I have practised a good deal."

"You were sent to me by Mrs. Etherege?"

"Yes, she told me that you had found her husband."

"And you want me to find Mr. Hosmer Angel?"

"Yes, I do. I have no one else to turn to."

"And you will pay me?"

"I can only offer you my small income, but I will pay you as much as I can."

"Why did you come away from home so suddenly?"

She started, and then said, "Because my stepfather, Mr. Windibank, would not listen to me. He would not let me send for you or for the police."

"Your stepfather?" said Holmes. "I thought his name was Windibank."

"Yes, it is. He is only five years older than I am."

events.title: Family Background and Financial Arrangements
detailed_summary: Miss Sutherland confirms her mother is alive and well.
She expresses disapproval of her mother's remarriage soon after her father's death to Mr. Windibank, a man nearly fifteen years younger.
She explains her father was a plumber who left a good business, initially run by her mother and the foreman, Mr. Hardy.
Mr. Windibank, a wine traveller, persuaded her mother to sell the business for £4700, less than her father would have received.
Watson expects Holmes to be impatient, but Holmes listens intently.
Holmes inquires about her personal income.
She clarifies it's separate, inherited from her Uncle Ned in Auckland—£2500 in New Zealand stock yielding £100 per year (4.5% interest).
She states she can only access the interest.
Holmes expresses interest, suggesting she must travel and indulge herself with such an income combined with her earnings.
Miss Sutherland explains that while living at home, she allows her mother and stepfather use of her interest money to avoid being a burden.
She states Mr. Windibank collects the interest quarterly and gives it to her mother.
She manages adequately on her typewriting earnings (two pence per sheet, often 15-20 sheets daily).
Holmes acknowledges her clear explanation and introduces Dr. Watson, assuring her she can speak freely before him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “And your mother is alive?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Kindly tell us now all about your connection with Mr. Hosmer Angel.”

events.text_segment:
“And your mother is alive?”
“Oh, yes, mother is alive and well. I wasn’t best pleased, Mr. Holmes, when she married again so soon after father’s death, and a man who was nearly fifteen years younger than herself. Father was a plumber in the Tottenham Court Road, and he left a tidy business behind him, which mother carried on with Mr. Hardy, the foreman; but when Mr. Windibank came he made her sell the business, for he was very superior, being a traveller in wines. They got £ 4700 for the goodwill and interest, which wasn’t near as much as father could have got if he had been alive.”
I had expected to see Sherlock Holmes impatient under this rambling and inconsequential narrative, but, on the contrary, he had listened with the greatest concentration of attention.
“Your own little income,” he asked, “does it come out of the business?”
“Oh, no, sir. It is quite separate and was left me by my uncle Ned in Auckland. It is in New Zealand stock, paying 4½ per cent. Two thousand five hundred pounds was the amount, but I can only touch the interest.”
“You interest me extremely,” said Holmes. “And since you draw so large a sum as a hundred a year, with what you earn into the bargain, you no doubt travel a little and indulge yourself in every way. I believe that a single lady can get on very nicely upon an income of about £ 60.”
“I could do with much less than that, Mr. Holmes, but you understand that as long as I live at home I don’t wish to be a burden to them, and so they have the use of the money just while I am staying with them. Of course, that is only just for the time. Mr. Windibank draws my interest every quarter and pays it over to mother, and I find that I can do pretty well with what I earn at typewriting. It brings me twopence a sheet, and I can often do from fifteen to twenty sheets in a day.”
“You have made your position very clear to me,” said Holmes. “This is my friend, Dr. Watson, before whom you can speak as freely as before myself. Kindly tell us now all about your connection with Mr. Hosmer Angel.”

events.title: Meeting and Courting Mr. Hosmer Angel
detailed_summary: Miss Sutherland flushes and nervously recounts meeting Mr. Hosmer Angel at the gasfitters' ball.

events.text_segment:
A flush stole over Miss Sutherland’s face, and she picked nervously at the fringe of her jacket. “I met him first at the gasfitters’ ball,” she said. “They used to send father tickets when he was alive, and then afterwards they remembered us, and sent them to mother. Mr. Windibank did not wish us to go. He never did wish us to go anywhere. He would get quite mad if I wanted so much as to join a Sunday-school treat. But this time I was set on going, and I would go; for what right had he to prevent? He said the folk were not fit for us to know, when all father’s friends were to be there. And he said that I had nothing fit to wear, when I had my purple plush that I had never so much as taken out of the drawer. At last, when nothing else would do, he went off to France upon the business of the firm, but we went, mother and I, with Mr. Hardy, who used to be our foreman, and it was there I met Mr. Hosmer Angel.”
“I suppose,” said Holmes, “that when Mr. Windibank came back from France he was very annoyed at your having gone to the ball.”
“Oh, well, he was very good about it. He laughed, I remember, and shrugged his shoulders, and said there was no use denying anything to a woman, for she would have her way.”
“I see. Then at the gasfitters’ ball you met, as I understand, a gentleman called Mr. Hosmer Angel.”
“Yes, sir. I met him that night, and he called next day to ask if we had got home all safe, and after that we met him—that is to say, Mr. Holmes, I met him twice for walks, but after that father came back again, and Mr. Hosmer Angel could not come to the house any more.”
“No?”
“Well, you know father didn’t like anything of the sort. He wouldn’t have any visitors if he could help it, and he used to say that a woman should be happy in her own family circle. But then, as I used to say to mother, a woman wants her own circle to begin with, and I had not got mine yet.”
“But how about Mr. Hosmer Angel? Did he make no attempt to see you?”
“Well, father was going off to France again in a week, and Hosmer wrote and said that it would be safer and better not to see each other until he had gone. We could write in the meantime, and he used to write every day. I took the letters in in the morning, so there was no need for father to know.”
“Were you engaged to the gentleman at this time?”
“Oh, yes, Mr. Holmes. We were engaged after the first walk that we took. Hosmer—Mr. Angel—was a cashier in an office in Leadenhall Street—and—”
“What office?”
“That’s the worst of it, Mr. Holmes, I don’t know.”
“Where did he live, then?”
“He slept on the premises.”
“And you don’t know his address?”
“No—except that it was Leadenhall Street.”
“Where did you address your letters, then?”
“To the Leadenhall Street Post Office, to be left till called for. He said that if they were sent to the office he would be chaffed by all the other clerks about having letters from a lady, so I offered to typewrite them, like he did his, but he wouldn’t have that, for he said that when I wrote them they seemed to come from me, but when they were typewritten he always felt that the machine had come between us. That will just show you how fond he was of me, Mr. Holmes, and the little things that he would think of.”
“It was most suggestive,” said Holmes. “It has long been an axiom of mine that the little things are infinitely the most important. Can you remember any other little things about Mr. Hosmer Angel?”
“He was a very shy man, Mr. Holmes. He would rather walk with me in the evening than in the daylight, for he said that he hated to be conspicuous. Very retiring and gentlemanly he was. Even his voice was gentle. He’d had the quinsy and swollen glands when he was young, he told me, and it had left him with a weak throat, and a hesitating, whispering fashion of speech. He was always well dressed, very neat and plain, but his eyes were weak, just as mine are, and he wore tinted glasses against the glare.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
A flush stole over Miss Sutherland’s face, and she picked nervously at the fringe of her jacket.

"I am afraid that I have been very foolish," she said, "and that I have come to you with a very trivial complaint. But I have no one else to whom I can turn, and I am very miserable."

"Pray sit down and tell me all about it," said Holmes.

She took a chair and began her story in a low voice. "My father was a solicitor, and he died when I was very young. My mother married again, and my stepfather is a man named Windibank. He is a very disagreeable man, and he has always been opposed to my having any social life. But last year, through my father's old connection, we received tickets for the gasfitters' ball. I was determined to go, and I had a new purple plush dress which I had never worn. My stepfather objected strongly, saying that the company would be rough and that I should not go. But he left for France on business, and my mother and I went with the former foreman, Mr. Hardy. It was there that I met Mr. Hosmer Angel."

Holmes looked at her keenly. "Was your stepfather annoyed when he returned?"

"No, he was very good-natured about it."

"Did you meet Mr. Angel again?"

"Yes, he called the next day, and we met twice for walks. But after my stepfather returned, he never came again."

"Why was that?"

"My stepfather dislikes visitors and believes that a woman should keep within her own family circle. I, however, have always longed for a social circle."

"Did Mr. Angel try to see you after your stepfather's return?"

"He wrote to me, saying that it would be better to avoid meeting until my stepfather had gone back to France. We corresponded daily, and I collected the letters privately."

"Were you engaged?"

"Yes, after our first walk."

"What does Mr. Angel do?"

"He is a cashier in an office in Leadenhall Street. I do not know which office, and I do not know his address. He said he slept on the premises."

"How were the letters addressed?"

"To the Leadenhall Street Post Office, to be left till called for. He said it was to avoid teasing from his colleagues."

"Did you write to him?"

"Yes, and I offered to typewrite my letters as he did, but he refused. He said he liked the personal touch of handwriting, which I took as a sign of affection."

Holmes smiled. "That is most suggestive. You see, Watson, it is the little things that are infinitely the most important."

"Can you tell me more about Mr. Angel?"

"He is very shy and prefers evening walks. He speaks in a low voice because he had quinsy as a child. He is always neatly dressed and has weak eyes like mine, so he wears tinted glasses."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
A flush stole over Miss Sutherland’s face, and she picked nervously at the fringe of her jacket. "I am afraid," she said, "that I have been a little hasty in my judgment. I did not expect to find such a man as you, Mr. Holmes, in this quiet town."

Sherlock Holmes smiled faintly. "Appearances are often deceptive, Miss Sutherland. It is the quiet places where the most curious mysteries often unfold."

She looked at him with a mixture of hope and apprehension. "Then you believe there is more to this case than meets the eye?"

Holmes nodded. "Indeed. The disappearance of your uncle, Mr. Rucastle, is not a simple matter of a man leaving his home. There are threads here that suggest a deeper intrigue."

Miss Sutherland's eyes widened. "But what could have happened to him? He was a man of routine, set in his ways."

"Precisely," Holmes replied. "And it is that very routine which has been disrupted. Tell me, Miss Sutherland, did your uncle have any enemies? Anyone who might wish him harm?"

She hesitated before answering. "Not that I know of. He was a solitary man, but not unkind."

Holmes leaned forward, his eyes sharp. "And what of the servants? Any unusual behavior?"

Miss Sutherland bit her lip. "There was the new footman, a young man named Barrymore. He seemed nervous lately, and I heard him speaking in hushed tones with my uncle."

Holmes's interest was piqued. "I should like to speak with this Barrymore."

As they spoke, Dr. Watson entered the room, carrying a small package. "Holmes, I have just returned from the Rucastle estate. I managed to obtain this from the footman's quarters."

Holmes took the package and examined its contents carefully. Inside was a torn piece of paper with a cryptic message scrawled upon it. "'The game is afoot,'" he murmured. "This confirms my suspicions. There is a secret being kept here."

Miss Sutherland looked at him anxiously. "What shall we do?"

Holmes stood, his expression resolute. "We must visit the Rucastle estate at once. There are questions that demand answers, and I intend to find them."

The journey to the estate was swift, and upon arrival, Holmes immediately set about his inquiries. He observed the layout of the house, the demeanor of the servants, and the subtle clues that others might overlook.

In the dim light of the drawing-room, Holmes turned to Barrymore. "You seem troubled, my friend. Is there something you wish to tell us?"

Barrymore swallowed hard. "I... I did not wish to cause trouble, sir. But there is a secret in this house, one that my master wished to keep hidden."

Holmes's eyes gleamed. "Speak freely, Barrymore. Your honesty may be rewarded."

The footman took a deep breath. "My master was involved in some unsavory dealings. He feared for his safety and took measures to protect himself."

Holmes nodded thoughtfully. "And these measures?"

Barrymore hesitated. "There is a hidden room in the cellar, sir. A place where he would retreat when he felt threatened."

Holmes smiled. "Then it is there we shall begin our search."

With the help of Barrymore, Holmes and Watson descended into the cellar. After a thorough examination, Holmes discovered a concealed door behind a stack of crates. The door creaked open to reveal a small chamber, dimly lit and furnished sparsely.

Inside, they found Mr. Rucastle, alive but weak, hidden away from prying eyes. He looked up with relief as Holmes entered. "Thank God," he whispered. "I feared I would never be found."

Holmes helped him to his feet. "You are safe now, sir. But we must understand why you chose to hide."

Rucastle explained that he had been threatened by a criminal gang seeking to extort money from him. To protect himself and his family, he had concealed himself until the danger passed.

Miss Sutherland embraced her uncle, tears of joy streaming down her face. Holmes turned to Barrymore. "Your loyalty has been commendable."

Barrymore bowed his head. "I only wished to protect my master."

Holmes smiled. "And you have done so admirably."

As they left the estate, Holmes reflected on the case. "Once again, Watson, we have seen that appearances can be deceiving, and that the truth often lies hidden beneath layers of secrecy."

Watson nodded. "Indeed, Holmes. Your keen observation and unwavering determination have brought light to the darkness."

Holmes smiled. "The game is afoot, my dear Watson, and justice has prevailed."

events.title: The Wedding Day Disappearance
detailed_summary: Holmes asks what happened when Windibank returned to France.
Miss Sutherland explains Hosmer Angel visited and urged they marry before Windibank's return.
He made her swear on the Testament to always be true to him, whatever happened.
Her mother supported this, seeing it as proof of his passion, and was very fond of Angel.
When marriage within the week was discussed, Miss Sutherland worried about her stepfather's reaction.
Both her mother and Angel told her not to worry and just inform him afterwards; her mother promised to handle it.
Miss Sutherland felt uneasy about not asking his leave, despite the small age gap, but didn't want secrecy.
She wrote to Windibank in Bordeaux, but the letter was returned on her wedding morning, having missed him.
The quiet wedding was set for Friday at St. Saviour's, King's Cross, with breakfast planned at the St. Pancras Hotel.
Angel arrived in a hansom cab for her and her mother.
Since the hansom was small, he put them both inside and took a separate four-wheeler cab himself.
They arrived at the church first; when the four-wheeler arrived, Angel never emerged.
The cabman was baffled, certain he had seen Angel get in.
This occurred last Friday, and she has had no word since.
Holmes remarks she seems shamefully treated.
She disagrees, insisting Angel was too kind and his earlier words about unforeseen events now make sense.
She believes he foresaw danger and that this danger has materialized.
She has no idea what the catastrophe could be.
Asked about her mother's reaction, she says her mother was angry and forbade further discussion of the matter.

Her stepfather, upon being told, seemed to agree with her that something happened and that Angel would reappear, questioning what motive anyone would have for abandoning her at the church door without financial gain.
Miss Sutherland expresses her distress and inability to sleep.
She begins to sob.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Well, and what happened when Mr. Windibank, your stepfather, returned to France?”

events.text_segment:
“Well, and what happened when Mr. Windibank, your stepfather, returned to France?”
“Mr. Hosmer Angel came to the house again and proposed that we should marry before father came back. He was in dreadful earnest and made me swear, with my hands on the Testament, that whatever happened I would always be true to him. Mother said he was quite right to make me swear, and that it was a sign of his passion. Mother was all in his favour from the first and was even fonder of him than I was. Then, when they talked of marrying within the week, I began to ask about father; but they both said never to mind about father, but just to tell him afterwards, and mother said she would make it all right with him. I didn’t quite like that, Mr. Holmes. It seemed funny that I should ask his leave, as he was only a few years older than me; but I didn’t want to do anything on the sly, so I wrote to father at Bordeaux, where the company has its French offices, but the letter came back to me on the very morning of the wedding.”
“It missed him, then?”
“Yes, sir; for he had started to England just before it arrived.”
“Ha! that was unfortunate. Your wedding was arranged, then, for the Friday. Was it to be in church?”
“Yes, sir, but very quietly. It was to be at St. Saviour’s, near King’s Cross, and we were to have breakfast afterwards at the St. Pancras Hotel. Hosmer came for us in a hansom, but as there were two of us he put us both into it and stepped himself into a four-wheeler, which happened to be the only other cab in the street. We got to the church first, and when the four-wheeler drove up we waited for him to step out, but he never did, and when the cabman got down from the box and looked there was no one there! The cabman said that he could not imagine what had become of him, for he had seen him get in with his own eyes. That was last Friday, Mr. Holmes, and I have never seen or heard anything since then to throw any light upon what became of him.”
“It seems to me that you have been very shamefully treated,” said Holmes.
“Oh, no, sir! He was too good and kind to leave me so. Why, all the morning he was saying to me that, whatever happened, I was to be true; and that even if something quite unforeseen occurred to separate us, I was always to remember that I was pledged to him, and that he would claim his pledge sooner or later. It seemed strange talk for a wedding-morning, but what has happened since gives a meaning to it.”
“Most certainly it does. Your own opinion is, then, that some unforeseen catastrophe has occurred to him?”
“Yes, sir. I believe that he foresaw some danger, or else he would not have talked so. And then I think that what he foresaw happened.”
“But you have no notion as to what it could have been?”
“None.”
“One more question. How did your mother take the matter?”
“She was angry, and said that I was never to speak of the matter again.”
“And your father? Did you tell him?”
“Yes; and he seemed to think, with me, that something had happened, and that I should hear of Hosmer again. As he said, what interest could anyone have in bringing me to the doors of the church, and then leaving me? Now, if he had borrowed my money, or if he had married me and got my money settled on him, there might be some reason, but Hosmer was very independent about money and never would look at a shilling of mine. And yet, what could have happened? And why could he not write? Oh, it drives me half-mad to think of it, and I can’t sleep a wink at night.” She pulled a little handkerchief out of her muff and began to sob heavily into it.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
"Well, and what happened when Mr. Windibank, your stepfather, returned to France?"

"He had been gone about a week when Hosmer Angel came to see me. He was a very quiet, gentlemanlike man, and he said that he had known my father well, and that he had been a friend of his. He said that he had come to ask for my hand in marriage, and that he wished us to be married before my stepfather returned. He made me swear on the Testament that I would be true to him, whatever might happen. My mother was very fond of him, and she said that this was a proof of his passion. When the question of marrying within the week was mentioned, I was very uneasy, for I was afraid of my stepfather's anger. But both my mother and Angel told me not to be afraid, and that I was only to inform him afterwards, and that my mother would manage everything. I was very uneasy about this, for I did not like the idea of keeping it a secret from my stepfather, though he was only a little older than myself. I wrote to Mr. Windibank at Bordeaux, but the letter was returned on the morning of the wedding, as he had sailed the day before. The wedding was very quiet, and it took place on Friday at St. Saviour's, King's Cross. We were to have breakfast afterwards at the St. Pancras Hotel. Hosmer Angel came for us in a hansom cab. It was a very small cab, and he put my mother and me inside, and took a four-wheeler himself. We arrived at the church first, and when the four-wheeler came up, he never got out. The cabman was quite sure that he had seen him get in. That was last Friday, and I have had no word since."

"You have been shamefully treated," said Holmes.

"No, no," she answered. "He was too kind. He said that there might be some unforeseen event, and I think that he foresaw some danger. I do not know what it could be, but I think that the danger has come."

"And your mother?"

"She was angry, and she forbade me to speak of it any more."

"And your stepfather?"

"He said that he thought something had happened, and that Angel would come back. He said that no one would have any motive for leaving me at the church door without money."

"And you?"

"I am very unhappy. I cannot sleep."

She began to sob.

The wedding was very quiet, and it took place on Friday at St. Saviour's, King's Cross. We were to have breakfast afterwards at the St. Pancras Hotel. Hosmer Angel came for us in a hansom cab. It was a very small cab, and he put my mother and me inside, and took a four-wheeler himself. We arrived at the church first, and when the four-wheeler came up, he never got out. The cabman was quite sure that he had seen him get in. That was last Friday, and I have had no word since."

"You have been shamefully treated," said Holmes.

"No, no," she answered. "He was too kind. He said that there might be some unforeseen event, and I think that he foresaw some danger. I do not know what it could be, but I think that the danger has come."

"And your mother?"

"She was angry, and she forbade me to speak of it any more."

"And your stepfather?"

"He said that he thought something had happened, and that Angel would come back. He said that no one would have any motive for leaving me at the church door without money."

"And you?"

"I am very unhappy. I cannot sleep."

She began to sob.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“Well, and what happened when Mr. Windibank, your stepfather, returned to France?” I inquired, leaning forward with keen interest as the firelight flickered across the worn features of the elderly gentleman before me.

He sighed deeply, his eyes clouded with the weight of years and memories. “It was a time of great upheaval, Mr. Holmes. When my stepfather left for France, the household was left in a state of uncertainty. My mother, ever the resilient woman, tried to maintain a semblance of normalcy, but the shadows of suspicion and fear loomed large.”

I nodded, encouraging him to continue. “And what of the events that followed? How did they lead to the unfortunate circumstances that brought you here today?”

He hesitated, then spoke with a tremor in his voice. “Shortly after Mr. Windibank’s departure, strange occurrences began to plague our home. Objects would be misplaced, letters went missing, and there were whispers of a hidden secret that could unravel the very fabric of our family’s honor.”

“Did you suspect anyone in particular?” I asked, my mind already piecing together the fragments of this perplexing puzzle.

“My mother was convinced that it was the work of a disgruntled servant, but I had my doubts. There was a certain tension in the air, a silent menace that seemed to emanate from the very walls.”

“Indeed,” I murmured. “Such atmospheres often conceal the most profound truths. Tell me, did you ever discover the nature of this secret?”

He nodded slowly. “Yes, but it was not until much later that the full extent of the deception was revealed. It involved a forged document, one that could have destroyed our family’s reputation and fortune.”

“Fascinating,” I said, steepling my fingers. “And who was responsible for this forgery?”

“That is the question that has haunted me for years. There were many who stood to gain from our downfall, but the true culprit remained elusive.”

I leaned back, contemplating the intricate web of motives and opportunities. “Fear not, sir. With patience and perseverance, the truth shall emerge from the shadows.”

He smiled faintly, a glimmer of hope rekindled in his eyes. “Thank you, Mr. Holmes. Your reputation precedes you, and I trust that you will bring clarity to this dark chapter of my life.”

As our conversation drew to a close, I resolved to delve deeper into the mysteries surrounding Mr. Windibank’s return to France and the subsequent turmoil. The game, as always, was afoot.

events.title: Holmes Takes the Case and Assesses the Client
detailed_summary: Holmes rises, assures Miss Sutherland he will investigate and likely find a definite result.
He advises her to stop dwelling on it and try to let Hosmer Angel vanish from her memory.
She asks if he thinks she won't see Angel again; Holmes confirms he fears not.
She asks what happened to him; Holmes asks her to leave the question to him.
He requests an accurate description of Angel and any letters.
She provides an advertisement slip from the Chronicle and four letters from Angel.
She gives her address as No. 31 Lyon Place, Camberwell.
Holmes confirms she never had Angel's specific address and asks for her stepfather's business.
She names Westhouse & Marbank, claret importers in Fenchurch Street.
Holmes thanks her for her clear statement, advises her again to put the incident behind her.
Miss Sutherland thanks him but declares she will remain true to Hosmer, ready for his return.
Despite her appearance, her simple faith earns Watson's respect.
She leaves her papers and departs, promising to return if summoned.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “I shall glance into the case for you,” said Holmes, rising, “and I have no doubt that we shall reach some definite result.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She laid her little bundle of papers upon the table and went her way, with a promise to come again whenever she might be summoned.

events.text_segment:
“I shall glance into the case for you,” said Holmes, rising, “and I have no doubt that we shall reach some definite result. Let the weight of the matter rest upon me now, and do not let your mind dwell upon it further. Above all, try to let Mr. Hosmer Angel vanish from your memory, as he has done from your life.”
“Then you don’t think I’ll see him again?”
“I fear not.”
“Then what has happened to him?”
“You will leave that question in my hands. I should like an accurate description of him and any letters of his which you can spare.”
“I advertised for him in last Saturday’s Chronicle,” said she. “Here is the slip and here are four letters from him.”
“Thank you. And your address?”
“No. 31 Lyon Place, Camberwell.”
“Mr. Angel’s address you never had, I understand. Where is your father’s place of business?”
“He travels for Westhouse & Marbank, the great claret importers of Fenchurch Street.”
“Thank you. You have made your statement very clearly. You will leave the papers here, and remember the advice which I have given you. Let the whole incident be a sealed book, and do not allow it to affect your life.”
“You are very kind, Mr. Holmes, but I cannot do that. I shall be true to Hosmer. He shall find me ready when he comes back.”
For all the preposterous hat and the vacuous face, there was something noble in the simple faith of our visitor which compelled our respect. She laid her little bundle of papers upon the table and went her way, with a promise to come again whenever she might be summoned.

"I will give you an accurate description of him, and all the letters he has written to me."

"No."

"I shall never forget him," she said simply. "I shall be true to Hosmer Angel, and wait for his return."

Her simple faith and devotion, despite the oddity of the case, won the respect of Dr. Watson.

She left her papers with Holmes and promised to return if summoned.

“I shall glance into the case for you,” said Holmes, rising, “and I have no doubt that we shall reach some definite result. The matter is certainly a curious one, and it will be a pleasure to work it out. You may rely upon my utmost efforts.”

I watched him as he gathered his papers and prepared to leave. His keen eyes sparkled with the thrill of the chase, and his mind was already racing through the possibilities. “You may call upon me at any hour,” he added, “and I shall be ready to assist you.”

As he stepped out into the foggy London street, I could not help but feel a surge of admiration for my friend’s unerring confidence and brilliant intellect. The case promised to be a fascinating puzzle, and I was eager to see how Holmes would unravel its tangled threads.

In the days that followed, Holmes devoted himself to the investigation with his usual single-minded intensity. He examined every clue with meticulous care, questioned witnesses with subtle skill, and pieced together the fragments of evidence into a coherent whole. His deductions were swift and sure, and his insight into human nature proved invaluable.

At last, the mystery was solved, and justice was served. The truth, hidden beneath layers of deception, was brought to light by Holmes’s relentless pursuit of the facts. It was another triumph for the great detective, and a testament to the power of reason and observation.

events.title: Holmes's Initial Analysis and Deductions
detailed_summary: Holmes sits silently for a few minutes, then lights his clay pipe.
He remarks that Miss Sutherland is an interesting study, more so than her problem, which he considers trite, citing parallels in Andover ('77) and The Hague.
He acknowledges some new details but finds the woman herself most instructive.
Watson admits he couldn't see what Holmes seemed to read upon her.
Holmes corrects him: the signs were unnoticed, not invisible.
He emphasizes the importance of observing details like sleeves, thumbnails, and boot-laces.
He asks Watson for his observations of Miss Sutherland's appearance.
Watson provides a detailed description: hat, feather, jacket, dress, gloves (worn at right forefinger), earrings, and general impression of vulgar well-to-do-ness.
Holmes chuckles, commending Watson's improving method and eye for color but states he missed everything important by trusting general impressions over specific details.
Holmes explains his own process: first checking sleeves (plush shows traces), identifying the double line near the wrist as characteristic of a typewritist, distinct from a sewing machine mark.
He then noticed the pince-nez indentation on her nose, leading to his remark about short sight and typewriting.
He reveals his surprise at observing her boots were odd (different toe-caps) and half-buttoned differently, indicating a hurried departure.
Watson is keenly interested.
Holmes adds he noted she wrote a note after dressing but before leaving, deduced from the violet ink stain on both her torn right glove and forefinger, applied too deeply in haste.
He dismisses these observations as amusingly elementary and returns to business.
He asks Watson to read the advertised description of Hosmer Angel.

events.text_segment:
Sherlock Holmes sat silent for a few minutes with his fingertips still pressed together, his legs stretched out in front of him, and his gaze directed upward to the ceiling. Then he took down from the rack the old and oily clay pipe, which was to him as a counsellor, and, having lit it, he leaned back in his chair, with the thick blue cloud-wreaths spinning up from him, and a look of infinite languor in his face.
“Quite an interesting study, that maiden,” he observed. “I found her more interesting than her little problem, which, by the way, is rather a trite one. You will find parallel cases, if you consult my index, in Andover in ’77, and there was something of the sort at The Hague last year. Old as is the idea, however, there were one or two details which were new to me. But the maiden herself was most instructive.”
“You appeared to read a good deal upon her which was quite invisible to me,” I remarked.
“Not invisible but unnoticed, Watson. You did not know where to look, and so you missed all that was important. I can never bring you to realise the importance of sleeves, the suggestiveness of thumb-nails, or the great issues that may hang from a boot-lace. Now, what did you gather from that woman’s appearance? Describe it.”
“Well, she had a slate-coloured, broad-brimmed straw hat, with a feather of a brickish red. Her jacket was black, with black beads sewn upon it, and a fringe of little black jet ornaments. Her dress was brown, rather darker than coffee colour, with a little purple plush at the neck and sleeves. Her gloves were greyish and were worn through at the right forefinger. Her boots I didn’t observe. She had small round, hanging gold earrings, and a general air of being fairly well-to-do in a vulgar, comfortable, easy-going way.”
Sherlock Holmes clapped his hands softly together and chuckled.
“’Pon my word, Watson, you are coming along wonderfully. You have really done very well indeed. It is true that you have missed everything of importance, but you have hit upon the method, and you have a quick eye for colour. Never trust to general impressions, my boy, but concentrate yourself upon details. My first glance is always at a woman’s sleeve. In a man it is perhaps better first to take the knee of the trouser. As you observe, this woman had plush upon her sleeves, which is a most useful material for showing traces. The double line a little above the wrist, where the typewritist presses against the table, was beautifully defined. The sewing-machine, of the hand type, leaves a similar mark, but only on the left arm, and on the side of it farthest from the thumb, instead of being right across the broadest part, as this was. I then glanced at her face, and, observing the dint of a pince-nez at either side of her nose, I ventured a remark upon short sight and typewriting, which seemed to surprise her.”
“It surprised me.”
“But, surely, it was obvious. I was then much surprised and interested on glancing down to observe that, though the boots which she was wearing were not unlike each other, they were really odd ones; the one having a slightly decorated toe-cap, and the other a plain one. One was buttoned only in the two lower buttons out of five, and the other at the first, third, and fifth. Now, when you see that a young lady, otherwise neatly dressed, has come away from home with odd boots, half-buttoned, it is no great deduction to say that she came away in a hurry.”
“And what else?” I asked, keenly interested, as I always was, by my friend’s incisive reasoning.
“I noted, in passing, that she had written a note before leaving home but after being fully dressed. You observed that her right glove was torn at the forefinger, but you did not apparently see that both glove and finger were stained with violet ink. She had written in a hurry and dipped her pen too deep. It must have been this morning, or the mark would not remain clear upon the finger. All this is amusing, though rather elementary, but I must go back to business, Watson. Would you mind reading me the advertised description of Mr. Hosmer Angel?”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Sherlock Holmes sat silent for a few minutes with his fingertips still pressed together, his legs stretched out in front of him, and his gaze directed upward to the ceiling. At last he lit his clay pipe and began to puff at it meditatively.

"Miss Sutherland is an interesting study," said he, "and a much more interesting one than her problem. The problem is a very trivial one, and I have seen its like before. There was a case in Andover in '77, and another at The Hague, which were very similar. But the woman herself is the instructive thing."

"I confess that I could see nothing in her," said I.

"You did not observe," said he, "but that is not the same thing. You observed nothing, and yet you saw much. You saw that she was a well-dressed woman, that she was nervous, that she was a little out of place in the room, and that she was not a lady. But you did not observe the details which would have told you more."

"What details?"

"The sleeves of her jacket, the state of her nails, the way her boot-laces were tied."

"I did not notice those things."

"No, and yet they were there. You must learn to observe, Watson."

"Very well, then. What did you observe?"

"I observed that her sleeves were of plush, and that they were worn at the elbows. I observed that her right thumbnail was broken, and that her boot-laces were tied in a peculiar fashion. I observed that she had a violet stain on her right glove, and that the glove was torn. I observed that she wore a pair of gold earrings, and that her hat was adorned with a single feather."

"You have a wonderful eye for detail," said I.

"I have had some practice. But the important thing is to know what to look for."

"And what did you deduce from these observations?"

"That she was a typewriter, or at least that she had been one. The plush sleeves showed the wear of the fingers, and the double line near the wrist was characteristic of the work of a typewriter. The broken thumbnail was a sign of nervousness, and the boot-laces were tied in a way that suggested haste. The violet stain on the glove was from ink, and the tear was recent."

"But how could you tell all this?"

"By careful observation and deduction. The indentation on her nose showed that she wore pince-nez, and the way they sat suggested short sight. The boots were odd, with different toe-caps, and the buttons were done up differently on each side, indicating a hurried departure."

"It is wonderful," said I.

"Elementary," said he, with a smile. "But now, Watson, let us return to the matter in hand. Read me the advertisement for Hosmer Angel."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The room was quiet except for the faint ticking of the clock on the mantelpiece and the occasional crackle from the fire. Holmes's keen mind was evidently at work, piecing together the fragments of the case that had so perplexed Scotland Yard. I, Dr. John Watson, watched him with a mixture of admiration and curiosity, knowing that the solution was near, though it remained hidden from my own understanding.

At last, Holmes broke the silence. "Watson," he said, his voice calm but resolute, "the key to this mystery lies not in the obvious, but in the overlooked. We must consider the smallest details, the ones that seem insignificant at first glance."

I nodded, eager to assist in any way I could. Holmes rose from his chair and began to pace the room, his eyes gleaming with the thrill of the chase. "Recall the scene of the crime," he urged. "What did you observe that others might have missed?"

I thought back to the evening when we had first arrived. The room where the victim had been found was in disarray, yet certain objects remained untouched. A single chair was overturned, and a faint scent of tobacco lingered in the air. Holmes's eyes narrowed as he considered these clues.

"The scent," he mused, "is that of a rare Turkish blend, not commonly found in London. This suggests the presence of a man of particular tastes, perhaps someone who frequents exclusive clubs or circles."

He moved to the window and peered out into the foggy street. "Moreover, the footprints outside are peculiar. They indicate a man of slight build, moving with purpose but also caution."

Holmes returned to his chair and resumed his thoughtful pose. "The victim was a man of some standing, yet he had enemies who wished him harm. The motive, however, is not immediately clear."

I interjected, "Could it be a matter of inheritance or business rivalry?"

Holmes shook his head. "No, Watson. The true motive is more personal, more insidious. We must delve deeper into the victim's relationships."

He reached for his notebook and began to jot down observations. "The victim's secretary, a young woman named Miss Adler, is of particular interest. She was the last to see him alive and has been notably reticent in her statements."

"Miss Adler?" I repeated. "I thought she was merely a loyal assistant."

Holmes smiled faintly. "Appearances can be deceiving. I intend to pay her a visit this evening."

As the night deepened, we made our way to Miss Adler's residence. The door was answered by a woman of striking presence, her eyes sharp and discerning. Holmes greeted her with his usual courtesy and explained the purpose of our visit.

Miss Adler listened attentively, then invited us inside. The room was modest but tastefully furnished, reflecting a mind both cultured and practical. Holmes observed her closely, noting the subtle signs of tension beneath her composed exterior.

"Miss Adler," he began, "I believe you hold the key to unraveling this mystery. Your knowledge of the victim's affairs is invaluable."

She regarded him steadily. "I have told the police all that I know."

Holmes leaned forward. "Yet there is more, is there not? Something you hesitate to reveal."

A flicker of emotion crossed her face. "Very well," she said softly. "The victim was involved in matters that could ruin reputations and lives. He possessed documents that implicated powerful individuals."

Holmes's interest was piqued. "And these documents?"

"They have disappeared," she admitted. "I fear they were taken by someone close to him."

We left Miss Adler's home with a renewed sense of purpose. Holmes was convinced that the missing documents were the motive behind the murder. Back at Baker Street, he began to formulate a plan to recover them and bring the culprit to justice.

In the days that followed, Holmes's investigations led us through the shadowy corridors of London's elite, uncovering secrets and lies. His deductions were as precise as ever, each step bringing us closer to the truth.

Finally, the breakthrough came. Holmes gathered the key players in his sitting room and laid out the evidence with clarity and conviction. The murderer, exposed by his own arrogance and greed, confessed to the crime.

Justice was served, and the city breathed a little easier. As always, Holmes's brilliance had triumphed over darkness, and I was privileged to witness the unfolding of his extraordinary mind.

events.title: Analyzing the Evidence and Planning the Next Steps
detailed_summary: Watson reads the newspaper description of Hosmer Angel: physical details, clothing, tinted glasses, speech infirmity, employed in Leadenhall Street.
Holmes stops Watson, finding the description sufficient.
He glances over the letters, calling them commonplace, offering no clue except a Balzac quote.
He points out one 'remarkable' and 'suggestive' point for Watson to notice.
Watson correctly identifies that the letters are typewritten.
Holmes clarifies the key point is not just that they are typewritten, but that the *signature* ('Hosmer Angel') is also typewritten.
He notes the vague Leadenhall Street address and date, but emphasizes the signature as conclusive.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I held the little printed slip to the light.

events.text_segment:
I held the little printed slip to the light. “Missing,” it said, “on the morning of the fourteenth, a gentleman named Hosmer Angel. About five ft. seven in. in height; strongly built, sallow complexion, black hair, a little bald in the centre, bushy, black side-whiskers and moustache; tinted glasses, slight infirmity of speech. Was dressed, when last seen, in black frock-coat faced with silk, black waistcoat, gold Albert chain, and grey Harris tweed trousers, with brown gaiters over elastic-sided boots. Known to have been employed in an office in Leadenhall Street. Anybody bringing,” &c, &c.
“That will do,” said Holmes. “As to the letters,” he continued, glancing over them, “they are very commonplace. Absolutely no clue in them to Mr. Angel, save that he quotes Balzac once. There is one remarkable point, however, which will no doubt strike you.”
“They are typewritten,” I remarked.
“Not only that, but the signature is typewritten. Look at the neat little ‘Hosmer Angel’ at the bottom. There is a date, you see, but no superscription except Leadenhall Street, which is rather vague. The point about the signature is very suggestive—in fact, we may call it conclusive.”
“Of what?”
“My dear fellow, is it possible you do not see how strongly it bears upon the case?”
“I cannot say that I do unless it were that he wished to be able to deny his signature if an action for breach of promise were instituted.”
“No, that was not the point. However, I shall write two letters, which should settle the matter. One is to a firm in the City, the other is to the young lady’s stepfather, Mr. Windibank, asking him whether he could meet us here at six o’clock to-morrow evening. It is just as well that we should do business with the male relatives. And now, Doctor, we can do nothing until the answers to those letters come, so we may put our little problem upon the shelf for the interim.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
I held the little printed slip to the light. It was a description of Hosmer Angel, the mysterious suitor of Miss Mary Sutherland. The paper detailed his physical appearance: a tall, thin man with a pale face, dark hair, and a peculiar speech impediment. It mentioned his attire—always neat and somewhat old-fashioned—and his tinted glasses. The notice also stated that he was employed in Leadenhall Street.

"That will do," said Holmes, interrupting my perusal. "The description is sufficient."

I glanced over the letters again. They were all typewritten, and the handwriting was conspicuously absent. "They are commonplace," I remarked. "There is nothing here to guide us."

Holmes smiled faintly. "You overlook one point, Watson."

"What is that?"

"Look at the signature."

I examined the letters more closely. Each was signed 'Hosmer Angel,' but the signature was not handwritten—it was typewritten, just like the body of the letters.

"Ah!" I exclaimed. "That is curious."

"Indeed. The signature is the key. The letters are typewritten, yes, but the signature being typewritten as well is most unusual."

"But why?" I asked. "Could it be to deny the signature later?"

Holmes shook his head. "No, that would be a clumsy device. The signature being typewritten suggests that the writer wished to conceal his identity completely."

He paused, then added, "There is also the vague address—Leadenhall Street—and the date, but these are less significant. The signature is conclusive."

"What shall we do now?" I inquired.

"I shall write two letters," Holmes replied. "One to a firm in the City, to inquire about this Hosmer Angel, and another to Mr. Windibank, requesting a meeting at Baker Street tomorrow evening."

"Why to Windibank?"

"Because I prefer to deal with male relatives in such matters."

He folded the letters and placed them in his pocket. "Until the replies arrive, we can do nothing more."

I nodded, realizing that the game was afoot once again.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
I held the little printed slip to the light. It was a telegram, and the message was brief but urgent: "Come at once. Danger. —M." The initials were familiar, and a chill ran down my spine as I recognized the handwriting. It was from my old friend, Sherlock Holmes.

I folded the slip carefully and tucked it into my pocket. The evening was drawing in, and the gas lamps were beginning to flicker along the foggy streets of London. I hurried to my rooms at 221B Baker Street, where Holmes awaited me, his keen eyes already fixed upon me as I entered.

"Watson," he said, his voice low and tense, "we have a matter of utmost importance. A case that may test our skills to their limits."

He laid out the details: a series of mysterious disappearances in the East End, all connected by a single thread—a cryptic symbol left at each scene. The police were baffled, and the public was growing restless. Holmes believed that beneath the surface lay a sinister plot, one that threatened not only the victims but the very fabric of the city.

We set out immediately, following the trail through shadowed alleys and deserted warehouses. Holmes's deductions were swift and precise, piecing together clues that others overlooked. The symbol, he explained, was an ancient mark used by a secret society, long thought defunct but evidently still active.

As the night deepened, we found ourselves face to face with danger. A trap was sprung, and we narrowly escaped with our lives. Yet, the mystery remained unsolved, and the stakes higher than ever.

Holmes turned to me, his eyes gleaming with determination. "Watson, this is but the beginning. The game is afoot, and we must be vigilant. The shadows conceal many secrets, and it is our duty to bring them to light."

events.title: Interim and Watson's Confidence in Holmes
detailed_summary: Watson reflects on his strong belief in Holmes's reasoning and energy.
He feels Holmes must have solid grounds for his confident handling of the mystery.
He recalls Holmes's rare failure in the Irene Adler case but contrasts it with successes like the Sign of Four and A Study in Scarlet.
Watson feels confident Holmes can unravel this tangle.
He leaves Holmes smoking his pipe, expecting the case to be solved by the next evening.
Watson is occupied with a serious professional case the entire next day.
He arrives at Baker Street near six o'clock, fearing he missed the conclusion.
He finds Holmes alone, drowsy in his armchair, surrounded by chemical apparatus, indicating he spent the day on experiments.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I had had so many reasons to believe in my friend’s subtle powers of reasoning and extraordinary energy in action that I felt that he must have some solid grounds for the assured and easy demeanour with which he treated the singular mystery which he had been called upon to fathom.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: A formidable array of bottles and test-tubes, with the pungent cleanly smell of hydrochloric acid, told me that he had spent his day in the chemical work which was so dear to him.

events.text_segment:
I had had so many reasons to believe in my friend’s subtle powers of reasoning and extraordinary energy in action that I felt that he must have some solid grounds for the assured and easy demeanour with which he treated the singular mystery which he had been called upon to fathom. Once only had I known him to fail, in the case of the King of Bohemia and of the Irene Adler photograph; but when I looked back to the weird business of the Sign of Four, and the extraordinary circumstances connected with the Study in Scarlet, I felt that it would be a strange tangle indeed which he could not unravel.
I left him then, still puffing at his black clay pipe, with the conviction that when I came again on the next evening I would find that he held in his hands all the clues which would lead up to the identity of the disappearing bridegroom of Miss Mary Sutherland.
A professional case of great gravity was engaging my own attention at the time, and the whole of next day I was busy at the bedside of the sufferer. It was not until close upon six o’clock that I found myself free and was able to spring into a hansom and drive to Baker Street, half afraid that I might be too late to assist at the dénouement of the little mystery. I found Sherlock Holmes alone, however, half asleep, with his long, thin form curled up in the recesses of his armchair. A formidable array of bottles and test-tubes, with the pungent cleanly smell of hydrochloric acid, told me that he had spent his day in the chemical work which was so dear to him.

```python
"I had had so many reasons to believe in my friend’s subtle powers of reasoning and extraordinary energy in action that I felt that he must have some solid grounds for the assured and easy demeanour with which he treated the singular mystery which he had been called upon to fathom. Though Holmes had once been bested by the clever Irene Adler, his record in cases such as the Sign of Four and A Study in Scarlet inspired my confidence that he would unravel this tangle with equal skill. Leaving him to his pipe and thoughts, I expected the solution to be revealed by the next evening. The following day, I was engrossed in a serious professional matter, and it was not until near six o’clock that I returned to Baker Street, anxious that I might have missed the conclusion. To my surprise, I found Holmes alone, drowsy in his armchair, surrounded by chemical apparatus, a clear sign that he had spent the day immersed in experiments rather than the case itself."
```

events.title: The Solution Revealed and Windibank's Arrival
detailed_summary: Watson enters and asks if Holmes has solved the mystery.
Holmes initially responds absently about a chemical result ('bisulphate of baryta').
Clarifying Watson meant the case, Holmes confirms it's solved, stating there was never really a mystery, though some details were interesting.
He expresses frustration that the law likely cannot punish the culprit.
As Watson asks who the culprit was and his motive, they hear heavy footsteps and a tap at the door.
Holmes identifies the visitor as the stepfather, Mr. James Windibank, confirming he'd written to expect him at six.
Holmes invites him in.
A sturdy, middle-sized man of about thirty enters, clean-shaven with sharp grey eyes and an insinuating manner.
He glances sharply at Holmes and Watson, places his hat down, and takes a chair.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Well, have you solved it?” I asked as I entered.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Come in!”

events.text_segment:
“Well, have you solved it?” I asked as I entered.
“Yes. It was the bisulphate of baryta.”
“No, no, the mystery!” I cried.
“Oh, that! I thought of the salt that I have been working upon. There was never any mystery in the matter, though, as I said yesterday, some of the details are of interest. The only drawback is that there is no law, I fear, that can touch the scoundrel.”
“Who was he, then, and what was his object in deserting Miss Sutherland?”
The question was hardly out of my mouth, and Holmes had not yet opened his lips to reply, when we heard a heavy footfall in the passage and a tap at the door.
“This is the girl’s stepfather, Mr. James Windibank,” said Holmes. “He has written to me to say that he would be here at six. Come in!”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
"Well, have you solved it?" I asked as I entered.

"I have," he answered, without looking up from his chemical experiments. "I have."

"Then it was the bisulphate of baryta after all?"

"No, no. I was only thinking of that. I have solved the case, but it was not a very difficult one. There was really no mystery about it, though some of the details were interesting."

"Who was the culprit?"

"I am afraid that the law cannot touch him."

"What was his motive?"

At that moment there was a heavy step upon the stairs, and a tap at the door.

"That will be the stepfather," said Holmes. "I wrote to him to expect me at six."

He opened the door, and a sturdy, middle-sized man of about thirty entered. He was clean-shaven, with sharp grey eyes and an insinuating manner. He glanced sharply at Holmes and me, placed his hat down, and took a chair."

events.title: Confronting Windibank with Typewriter Evidence
detailed_summary: Holmes greets Mr. Windibank and confirms a typewritten letter arranging the appointment is from him.
Windibank apologizes for being slightly late, blaming work constraints.
He expresses annoyance that Miss Sutherland troubled Holmes, preferring not to air family matters publicly.
He mentions her impulsive nature and that her visit was against his wishes, though he minds less since Holmes isn't official police.
He dismisses the investigation as a useless expense, questioning how Holmes could possibly find Hosmer Angel.
Holmes calmly states he has every reason to believe he *will* succeed in discovering Mr. Hosmer Angel.
Windibank starts violently, drops his gloves, and claims to be delighted.
Holmes remarks on the individuality of typewriters, noting that older machines develop unique characteristics.
He points out specific flaws in Windibank's appointment letter: a slurred 'e' and defective 'r' tail, among fourteen other characteristics.
Windibank, eyeing Holmes keenly, attributes this to wear on the office machine.
Holmes announces he will show Windibank an interesting study, mentioning his intention to write a monograph on typewriters and crime.
He presents the four letters purportedly from Hosmer Angel, all typewritten.

He invites Windibank to use a magnifying lens to observe that the same distinctive flaws, including the slurred 'e's, tailless 'r's, and the other fourteen characteristics, are present in Angel's letters as well.

events.text_segment:
The man who entered was a sturdy, middle-sized fellow, some thirty years of age, clean-shaven, and sallow-skinned, with a bland, insinuating manner, and a pair of wonderfully sharp and penetrating grey eyes. He shot a questioning glance at each of us, placed his shiny top-hat upon the sideboard, and with a slight bow sidled down into the nearest chair.
“Good-evening, Mr. James Windibank,” said Holmes. “I think that this typewritten letter is from you, in which you made an appointment with me for six o’clock?”
“Yes, sir. I am afraid that I am a little late, but I am not quite my own master, you know. I am sorry that Miss Sutherland has troubled you about this little matter, for I think it is far better not to wash linen of the sort in public. It was quite against my wishes that she came, but she is a very excitable, impulsive girl, as you may have noticed, and she is not easily controlled when she has made up her mind on a point. Of course, I did not mind you so much, as you are not connected with the official police, but it is not pleasant to have a family misfortune like this noised abroad. Besides, it is a useless expense, for how could you possibly find this Hosmer Angel?”
“On the contrary,” said Holmes quietly; “I have every reason to believe that I will succeed in discovering Mr. Hosmer Angel.”
Mr. Windibank gave a violent start and dropped his gloves. “I am delighted to hear it,” he said.
“It is a curious thing,” remarked Holmes, “that a typewriter has really quite as much individuality as a man’s handwriting. Unless they are quite new, no two of them write exactly alike. Some letters get more worn than others, and some wear only on one side. Now, you remark in this note of yours, Mr. Windibank, that in every case there is some little slurring over of the ‘e,’ and a slight defect in the tail of the ‘r.’ There are fourteen other characteristics, but those are the more obvious.”
“We do all our correspondence with this machine at the office, and no doubt it is a little worn,” our visitor answered, glancing keenly at Holmes with his bright little eyes.
“And now I will show you what is really a very interesting study, Mr. Windibank,” Holmes continued. “I think of writing another little monograph some of these days on the typewriter and its relation to crime. It is a subject to which I have devoted some little attention. I have here four letters which purport to come from the missing man. They are all typewritten. In each case, not only are the ‘e’s’ slurred and the ‘r’s’ tailless, but you will observe, if you care to use my magnifying lens, that the fourteen other characteristics to which I have alluded are there as well.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
The man who entered was a sturdy, middle-sized fellow, some thirty years of age, clean-shaven, and sallow-skinned, with a bland, insinuating manner, and a pair of wonderfully sharp and penetrating grey eyes.

"You are Mr. James Windibank?" said Holmes.

"Yes, I am."

"You wrote me this letter?"

He took a typewritten sheet from his pocket and handed it to Holmes.

"Yes, that is my handwriting."

"You are a little late."

"I am afraid so. I was detained at the office."

"I am sorry to have troubled you, Mr. Holmes," said the visitor, "but I was anxious to have a little private inquiry made."

"I understand."

"I do not like to have family affairs discussed in public."

"Quite so."

"My daughter is a little impulsive, and she came here against my wishes."

"I see."

"But I do not mind so much, since you are not the official police."

"No."

"I think the whole thing is a waste of money."

"You do?"

"Yes. How can you possibly find this Mr. Hosmer Angel?"

"I have every reason to believe that I shall."

The man started violently, dropped his gloves, and said, "I am delighted to hear it."

"You are aware that typewriters have individuality?" said Holmes.

"I have heard so."

"The older machines develop peculiarities."

"Yes."

"Now, look at this letter which you wrote to me."

He handed it to Windibank.

"You will notice that the letter 'e' is slightly slurred, and the tail of the 'r' is defective."

"Yes, I see."

"There are fourteen other characteristics which I have noted."

Windibank looked keenly at Holmes.

"That is due to wear on the office machine."

"I think I can show you an interesting study."

"Indeed?"

"I am going to write a monograph on typewriters and crime."

He took from his pocket four letters, all typewritten.

"These are the letters which have been sent by Mr. Hosmer Angel."

He handed them to Windibank.

"Use this magnifying glass."

Windibank peered closely.

"You will notice the same slurred 'e's, the tailless 'r's, and the other fourteen characteristics."

"It is the same machine."

"Exactly."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
He carried himself with an air of quiet confidence, and there was something about his gait that suggested a man accustomed to moving through the world with purpose and discretion. As he approached, his eyes flicked briefly to the various objects scattered about the room, taking in every detail with the keen observation of one who notices what others overlook.

"Good evening, Mr. Holmes," he said, his voice smooth and measured. "I trust I am not intruding at an inconvenient hour?"

Holmes looked up from the book he had been perusing, his sharp gaze meeting that of the visitor. "Not at all, Mr. Lestrade. Your visits are always welcome, especially when they bring matters of interest. Pray, take a seat."

The man nodded appreciatively and settled into the chair opposite Holmes, placing a folded newspaper on the table between them. "I have come on a matter that requires your particular talents. It concerns a series of peculiar events that have recently transpired in the city."

Holmes leaned forward, steepling his fingers. "Do go on."

"Over the past fortnight," Lestrade began, "there have been several reports of strange occurrences near the docks. Men have vanished without a trace, and witnesses speak of eerie lights and unexplainable noises in the dead of night. The local constabulary is baffled, and the public is growing restless."

"Indeed," Holmes murmured, his eyes gleaming with interest. "Such mysteries are the very essence of my work. Have you any theories as to the cause?"

Lestrade shook his head. "None that hold water. The disappearances seem random, and there is no discernible pattern. The only commonality is the location—the old warehouses along the Thames."

Holmes stood and began to pace the room, his mind evidently racing through possibilities. "The docks are a labyrinth of shadows and secrets. Smugglers, thieves, and worse ply their trade there under cover of darkness. It would not surprise me if these events are connected to some illicit enterprise."

"That is my suspicion as well," Lestrade agreed. "But we lack the evidence to proceed."

Holmes paused, his gaze fixed on the window overlooking the fog-laden streets. "Very well, Mr. Lestrade. I shall accompany you to the docks tonight. Together, we shall uncover the truth behind these mysterious vanishings."

A faint smile crossed Lestrade's lips. "I knew I could count on you, Holmes."

As the evening deepened, the two men prepared to delve into the shadows of the city, where danger and intrigue awaited. The game, as always, was afoot.

events.title: The Accusation and Windibank's Collapse
detailed_summary: Windibank jumps up, grabs his hat, and dismisses Holmes's talk as fantastic, demanding Holmes catch the man if he can and inform him when done.
Holmes steps to the door, locks it, and suavely tells Windibank he *has* caught him.
Windibank turns pale and looks around frantically like a trapped rat.
Holmes tells him escape is impossible and the deception is transparent, chiding him for underestimating the simplicity of the case.
He instructs Windibank to sit down.
Windibank collapses into the chair, looking ghastly and sweating.
He stammers that his actions are not legally actionable.
Holmes agrees but condemns the act as exceptionally cruel, selfish, and heartless.
He proposes to recount the sequence of events for Windibank to correct if wrong.
Windibank sits huddled and crushed as Holmes begins his explanation.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mr. Windibank sprang out of his chair and picked up his hat.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Now, let me just run over the course of events, and you will contradict me if I go wrong.”

events.text_segment:
Mr. Windibank sprang out of his chair and picked up his hat. “I cannot waste time over this sort of fantastic talk, Mr. Holmes,” he said. “If you can catch the man, catch him, and let me know when you have done it.”
“Certainly,” said Holmes, stepping over and turning the key in the door. “I let you know, then, that I have caught him!”
“What! where?” shouted Mr. Windibank, turning white to his lips and glancing about him like a rat in a trap.
“Oh, it won’t do—really it won’t,” said Holmes suavely. “There is no possible getting out of it, Mr. Windibank. It is quite too transparent, and it was a very bad compliment when you said that it was impossible for me to solve so simple a question. That’s right! Sit down and let us talk it over.”
Our visitor collapsed into a chair, with a ghastly face and a glitter of moisture on his brow. “It—it’s not actionable,” he stammered.
“I am very much afraid that it is not. But between ourselves, Windibank, it was as cruel and selfish and heartless a trick in a petty way as ever came before me. Now, let me just run over the course of events, and you will contradict me if I go wrong.”

Mr. Windibank turned pale and looked round the room like a trapped rat. "Escape is impossible," said Holmes. "The deception is transparent. You have underestimated the simplicity of the case. Sit down." Mr. Windibank sank into the chair, looking ghastly and sweating. "My actions are not legally actionable," he stammered. "No," said Holmes, "but they are cruel, selfish, and heartless in the extreme. Now, I will recount the sequence of events, and you can correct me if I am wrong." Mr. Windibank sat huddled and crushed as Holmes began his explanation.

"I have no time to lose if I am to catch the early train." Holmes watched him with keen interest, noting the nervous glance he cast towards the window. "Pray, Mr. Windibank," he said, "before you leave, might I ask you a few questions?" The man hesitated, then nodded reluctantly. "Very well," he replied. "What is it you wish to know?" Holmes leaned forward, his eyes gleaming. "You mentioned a certain Mr. Windibank in your letter. Are you related to him?" The visitor's face darkened. "He is my uncle," he admitted. "Why do you ask?" "Because," said Holmes, "I have reason to believe that your uncle's recent disappearance is connected to the strange events you have described. I think you may be in danger, and I wish to help you." Mr. Windibank looked at Holmes with a mixture of fear and hope. "If you can help me," he said, "I shall be forever grateful." Holmes smiled reassuringly. "Then let us begin at once."
