LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“Pray do so.”

I had called upon my friend Sherlock Holmes one day in the autumn of last year and found him in deep conversation with a visitor. The man was tall and thin, with a pale face and keen eyes that seemed to miss nothing. Holmes, as always, was in his element, his sharp mind dissecting the details of the case before him.

“Tell me everything from the beginning,” Holmes said, his voice calm but insistent.

The visitor, a Mr. John Openshaw, began his tale. He spoke of a mysterious letter he had received, warning him of impending danger. The letter was unsigned, but the handwriting was peculiar, and the paper bore a strange watermark. Openshaw explained that his family had been plagued by a series of misfortunes, each more baffling than the last.

Holmes listened intently, his eyes narrowing as he pieced together the fragments of the story. “It is clear that someone wishes to intimidate you,” he remarked. “But why? And who?”

The visitor shrugged helplessly. “That is what I hope you can discover.”

Holmes rose from his chair and began to pace the room. “We must examine the letter closely. Every detail may hold a clue.”

He took the letter from Openshaw and scrutinized it under his magnifying glass. The watermark, the ink, the folds—all were significant. “This is no ordinary threat,” Holmes mused. “It is a carefully crafted message designed to unsettle and confuse.”

Over the next few days, Holmes and I delved deeper into the mystery, following leads that took us through the foggy streets of London and into the shadowy corners of society. Each step brought us closer to the truth, revealing a web of deceit and danger that threatened to ensnare us all.

In the end, it was Holmes’s unparalleled powers of observation and deduction that unraveled the case, exposing the culprit and restoring peace to the troubled family. As always, I was reminded of the extraordinary mind that lay behind the unassuming figure of my friend, the great Sherlock Holmes.

events.title: John Turner's Confession
detailed_summary: John Turner enters, appearing decrepit with a limp and bowed shoulders, yet possessing features indicating unusual strength.
His appearance is marked by age, dignity, power, but also an ashen complexion suggesting severe illness.
Holmes offers him a seat, confirming Turner received his note requesting the meeting at the hotel to avoid scandal.
Turner asks why Holmes wished to see him, his eyes showing despair.
Holmes confirms Turner's unspoken question: he knows everything about McCarthy.
Turner buries his face, cries for God's help, but insists he would have confessed if James were convicted at the Assizes.
Holmes expresses approval.
Turner explains his silence was for his daughter, fearing the news of his arrest would break her heart.
Holmes suggests arrest might be avoidable, clarifying he's acting in Miss Turner's interest, not as an official agent, but James must be cleared.
Turner reveals he is dying from diabetes with possibly only a month left, preferring to die at home than in jail.
Holmes prepares to take down Turner's statement, promising to use the signed confession only as a last resort to save James.
Turner agrees, doubting he'll live to the Assizes anyway, wishing to spare his daughter Alice the shock.
He begins his story, describing McCarthy as a 'devil incarnate' who gripped his life for twenty years.
He recounts his past in the Australian gold diggings in the early '60s as a reckless youth ('Black Jack of Ballarat') who became a highway robber with the 'Ballarat Gang.'
The gang attacked a gold convoy; Turner held a pistol to the driver's head – that driver was McCarthy.
Turner spared McCarthy but noted McCarthy studied his face.
The gang escaped with gold, became rich, and returned to England.
Turner parted ways, bought his estate, determined to live respectably and atone for his past.
He married, had Alice, and reformed his life, guided by his love for his daughter.
Years later, he encountered a destitute McCarthy in London.
McCarthy recognized him and used the threat of exposure ('always a policeman within hail') to blackmail Turner into supporting him and his son.
They lived rent-free on Turner's best land, providing constant torment and reminding Turner of his past.
The blackmail escalated as Alice grew, McCarthy realizing Turner feared her discovering his history more than the police.
Turner gave McCarthy whatever he demanded (land, money, houses) until McCarthy demanded Alice marry his son, James, securing the property.
Turner refused, despite liking the lad, adamant about not mixing 'his cursed stock' with his own.
McCarthy threatened exposure; Turner defied him, agreeing to meet at Boscombe Pool to discuss it.
Arriving early, Turner waited behind a tree while McCarthy talked to James.
Overhearing McCarthy urging James to marry Alice with disregard for her feelings drove Turner to fury.
Feeling desperate and already dying, Turner resolved to silence McCarthy to protect his daughter and his memory.
He struck McCarthy down without compunction after James had left.
McCarthy's cry brought James back, but Turner escaped into the woods, briefly returning only to retrieve the grey cloak he dropped.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The man who entered was a strange and impressive figure.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: That is the true story, gentlemen, of all that occurred.”

events.text_segment:
The man who entered was a strange and impressive figure. His slow, limping step and bowed shoulders gave the appearance of decrepitude, and yet his hard, deep-lined, craggy features, and his enormous limbs showed that he was possessed of unusual strength of body and of character. His tangled beard, grizzled hair, and outstanding, drooping eyebrows combined to give an air of dignity and power to his appearance, but his face was of an ashen white, while his lips and the corners of his nostrils were tinged with a shade of blue. It was clear to me at a glance that he was in the grip of some deadly and chronic disease.
“Pray sit down on the sofa,” said Holmes gently. “You had my note?”
“Yes, the lodge-keeper brought it up. You said that you wished to see me here to avoid scandal.”
“I thought people would talk if I went to the Hall.”
“And why did you wish to see me?” He looked across at my companion with despair in his weary eyes, as though his question was already answered.
“Yes,” said Holmes, answering the look rather than the words. “It is so. I know all about McCarthy.”
The old man sank his face in his hands. “God help me!” he cried. “But I would not have let the young man come to harm. I give you my word that I would have spoken out if it went against him at the Assizes.”
“I am glad to hear you say so,” said Holmes gravely.
“I would have spoken now had it not been for my dear girl. It would break her heart—it will break her heart when she hears that I am arrested.”
“It may not come to that,” said Holmes.
“What?”
“I am no official agent. I understand that it was your daughter who required my presence here, and I am acting in her interests. Young McCarthy must be got off, however.”
“I am a dying man,” said old Turner. “I have had diabetes for years. My doctor says it is a question whether I shall live a month. Yet I would rather die under my own roof than in a gaol.”
Holmes rose and sat down at the table with his pen in his hand and a bundle of paper before him. “Just tell us the truth,” he said. “I shall jot down the facts. You will sign it, and Watson here can witness it. Then I could produce your confession at the last extremity to save young McCarthy. I promise you that I shall not use it unless it is absolutely needed.”
“It’s as well,” said the old man; “it’s a question whether I shall live to the Assizes, so it matters little to me, but I should wish to spare Alice the shock. And now I will make the thing clear to you; it has been a long time in the acting, but will not take me long to tell.
“You didn’t know this dead man, McCarthy. He was a devil incarnate. I tell you that. God keep you out of the clutches of such a man as he. His grip has been upon me these twenty years, and he has blasted my life. I’ll tell you first how I came to be in his power.
“It was in the early ’60’s at the diggings. I was a young chap then, hot-blooded and reckless, ready to turn my hand at anything; I got among bad companions, took to drink, had no luck with my claim, took to the bush, and in a word became what you would call over here a highway robber. There were six of us, and we had a wild, free life of it, sticking up a station from time to time, or stopping the wagons on the road to the diggings. Black Jack of Ballarat was the name I went under, and our party is still remembered in the colony as the Ballarat Gang.
“One day a gold convoy came down from Ballarat to Melbourne, and we lay in wait for it and attacked it. There were six troopers and six of us, so it was a close thing, but we emptied four of their saddles at the first volley. Three of our boys were killed, however, before we got the swag. I put my pistol to the head of the wagon-driver, who was this very man McCarthy. I wish to the Lord that I had shot him then, but I spared him, though I saw his wicked little eyes fixed on my face, as though to remember every feature. We got away with the gold, became wealthy men, and made our way over to England without being suspected. There I parted from my old pals and determined to settle down to a quiet and respectable life. I bought this estate, which chanced to be in the market, and I set myself to do a little good with my money, to make up for the way in which I had earned it. I married, too, and though my wife died young she left me my dear little Alice. Even when she was just a baby her wee hand seemed to lead me down the right path as nothing else had ever done. In a word, I turned over a new leaf and did my best to make up for the past. All was going well when McCarthy laid his grip upon me.
“I had gone up to town about an investment, and I met him in Regent Street with hardly a coat to his back or a boot to his foot.
“‘Here we are, Jack,’ says he, touching me on the arm; ‘we’ll be as good as a family to you. There’s two of us, me and my son, and you can have the keeping of us. If you don’t—it’s a fine, law-abiding country is England, and there’s always a policeman within hail.’
“Well, down they came to the west country, there was no shaking them off, and there they have lived rent free on my best land ever since. There was no rest for me, no peace, no forgetfulness; turn where I would, there was his cunning, grinning face at my elbow. It grew worse as Alice grew up, for he soon saw I was more afraid of her knowing my past than of the police. Whatever he wanted he must have, and whatever it was I gave him without question, land, money, houses, until at last he asked a thing which I could not give. He asked for Alice.
“His son, you see, had grown up, and so had my girl, and as I was known to be in weak health, it seemed a fine stroke to him that his lad should step into the whole property. But there I was firm. I would not have his cursed stock mixed with mine; not that I had any dislike to the lad, but his blood was in him, and that was enough. I stood firm. McCarthy threatened. I braved him to do his worst. We were to meet at the pool midway between our houses to talk it over.
“When I went down there I found him talking with his son, so I smoked a cigar and waited behind a tree until he should be alone. But as I listened to his talk all that was black and bitter in me seemed to come uppermost. He was urging his son to marry my daughter with as little regard for what she might think as if she were a slut from off the streets. It drove me mad to think that I and all that I held most dear should be in the power of such a man as this. Could I not snap the bond? I was already a dying and a desperate man. Though clear of mind and fairly strong of limb, I knew that my own fate was sealed. But my memory and my girl! Both could be saved if I could but silence that foul tongue. I did it, Mr. Holmes. I would do it again. Deeply as I have sinned, I have led a life of martyrdom to atone for it. But that my girl should be entangled in the same meshes which held me was more than I could suffer. I struck him down with no more compunction than if he had been some foul and venomous beast. His cry brought back his son; but I had gained the cover of the wood, though I was forced to go back to fetch the cloak which I had dropped in my flight. That is the true story, gentlemen, of all that occurred.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
The man who entered was a strange and impressive figure. He was a little past middle height, but strongly and heavily built, with a stoop of the shoulders and a limp in his walk which showed that he was a man who had borne some heavy burden. His face was bronzed and weather-beaten, but there was a look of power and determination in his eyes which showed that he was not a man to be lightly crossed. His hair was grizzled, and his features were marked by a certain rugged dignity, but there was also a pallor and a drawn look about his face which told of some inward suffering.

"You received my note?" said Holmes, motioning him to a seat.

"Yes," said the man, in a low voice. "I came as soon as I could."

"I am glad you did. I wished to see you here, away from the public eye, to avoid any scandal."

The man looked at Holmes with a weary, despairing glance.

"Why did you wish to see me?" he asked.

Holmes smiled gently.

"I know all about McCarthy," he said.

The man buried his face in his hands and groaned.

"God help me!" he cried. "I would have confessed if James had been convicted at the Assizes."

"I am glad to hear it," said Holmes. "Your silence has been for your daughter's sake, I understand. You feared that the news of your arrest would break her heart."

"Yes," said the man. "I could not bear to see her suffer."

"I think that the arrest may be avoided," said Holmes. "I am acting in Miss Turner's interest, not as an official agent. But James must be cleared."

The man looked at Holmes with a faint smile.

"I am dying," he said. "I have diabetes, and I have not more than a month to live. I would rather die at home than in jail."

Holmes took out his notebook and prepared to take down the man's statement.

"I will only use your signed confession as a last resort to save James," he said.

The man nodded.

"I doubt that I shall live to the Assizes," he said. "I want to spare my daughter the shock."

He began his story in a low, broken voice.

"McCarthy was a devil incarnate," he said. "He had a grip on my life for twenty years."

He told of his youth in the Australian gold diggings in the early sixties, when he was known as 'Black Jack of Ballarat,' a reckless young man who had become a highway robber with the 'Ballarat Gang.'

"We attacked a gold convoy," he said. "I held a pistol to the driver's head. That driver was McCarthy. I spared him, but I saw that he studied my face closely."

The gang escaped with the gold, became rich, and returned to England.

"I parted ways with them," he said. "I bought my estate and determined to live respectably and atone for my past."

He married and had a daughter, Alice, and reformed his life, guided by his love for her.

Years later, he encountered a destitute McCarthy in London.

"McCarthy recognized me," he said. "He used the threat of exposure—'always a policeman within hail'—to blackmail me into supporting him and his son."

They lived rent-free on his best land, providing constant torment and reminding him of his past.

The blackmail escalated as Alice grew, McCarthy realizing that Turner feared her discovering his history more than the police.

Turner gave McCarthy whatever he demanded—land, money, houses—until McCarthy demanded that Alice marry his son, James, securing the property.

Turner refused, despite liking the lad, adamant about not mixing 'his cursed stock' with his own.

McCarthy threatened exposure; Turner defied him, agreeing to meet at Boscombe Pool to discuss it.

Arriving early, Turner waited behind a tree while McCarthy talked to James.

Overhearing McCarthy urging James to marry Alice with disregard for her feelings drove Turner to fury.

Feeling desperate and already dying, Turner resolved to silence McCarthy to protect his daughter and his memory.

He struck McCarthy down without compunction after James had left.

McCarthy's cry brought James back, but Turner escaped into the woods, briefly returning only to retrieve the grey cloak he dropped.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The man who entered was a strange and impressive figure. He was tall and gaunt, with a face that seemed carved from stone, sharp features etched deeply by time and experience. His eyes, dark and piercing, scanned the room with a mixture of curiosity and calculation. Clad in a long, weather-beaten coat and a wide-brimmed hat that cast a shadow over his brow, he carried an air of mystery that immediately commanded attention.

Sherlock Holmes, seated by the fire with Dr. Watson, looked up from his violin as the man approached. "Good evening," the visitor said in a low, measured tone. "I am in need of your assistance, Mr. Holmes."

Holmes gestured to the empty chair opposite him. "Pray, be seated. What brings you to Baker Street at this hour?"

The man removed his hat, revealing a shock of graying hair. "My name is Mr. Reginald Blackwood. I am a solicitor by profession, but tonight I come to you not in the capacity of a lawyer, but as a man desperate for answers."

Watson leaned forward, intrigued. "What sort of answers, Mr. Blackwood?"

Blackwood sighed deeply. "It concerns a matter of life and death, and a mystery that has confounded the local authorities."

Holmes's eyes gleamed with interest. "Please, continue."

Blackwood took a seat and began his tale. "Two nights ago, in the quiet village of Little Hatherley, a young woman named Emily Carter vanished without a trace. She was last seen leaving the village inn after a late supper, but since then, no one has heard from her. The police have searched the surrounding woods and questioned the villagers, but to no avail."

"What makes this case particularly troubling," he continued, "is that Emily was engaged to be married to a man named Thomas Grey, a local farmer. Their relationship was well-known and seemingly happy. Yet, there are whispers of a shadowy figure seen lurking near the inn on the night of her disappearance."

Holmes steepled his fingers. "Have you any suspects?"

Blackwood shook his head. "None that the police have been able to identify. The villagers are tight-lipped, and fear seems to have gripped the community."

Watson exchanged a glance with Holmes. "It sounds like a case worthy of your attention, Holmes."

Holmes nodded. "Indeed. Mr. Blackwood, I shall accompany you to Little Hatherley at first light."

The following morning, Holmes, Watson, and Blackwood set out for the village. The journey was uneventful, but as they approached Little Hatherley, a palpable tension hung in the air. The village was small, with narrow lanes and thatched cottages, but the usual bustle of rural life was subdued.

At the inn, they were greeted by the innkeeper, Mrs. Thompson, a stout woman with a wary expression. "You're here about Miss Carter, I presume?" she asked.

Holmes nodded. "Yes, madam. We hope to learn what we can about her disappearance."

Mrs. Thompson led them to the common room. "Emily was a sweet girl, always cheerful. The night she vanished, she left around ten o'clock after saying goodnight to the other guests. But after that, no one saw her."

Holmes inquired about the shadowy figure. Mrs. Thompson hesitated. "Some say they saw a man in a dark cloak near the woods, but no one knows who he was."

Holmes and Watson decided to inspect the area around the inn and the nearby woods. As they walked, Holmes observed the footprints in the soft earth, noting their size and direction. "These prints are fresh," he remarked. "They lead towards the old mill on the edge of the village."

They followed the trail to the mill, a dilapidated structure long abandoned. Inside, they found signs of recent activity: a smoldering fire and discarded food wrappers. Holmes's keen eyes caught a scrap of fabric caught on a nail—a piece of Emily's distinctive shawl.

Suddenly, a rustling sound came from the shadows. Holmes and Watson drew their revolvers as a figure emerged—a young man, disheveled and frightened.

"Who are you?" Holmes demanded.

The man stammered, "My name is Peter. I... I was looking for Emily. She promised to meet me here."

Holmes's gaze sharpened. "Why would she meet you in secret?"

Peter looked down. "Because I am the son of the village blacksmith, and she feared her fiancé would not approve of our friendship."

Holmes considered this. "Where is Emily now?"

Peter shook his head. "I don't know. She never came."

Holmes motioned for Peter to accompany them back to the village. As they walked, Holmes pondered the complexities of the case—the vanished woman, the secret meetings, the shadowy figure.

Back at the inn, Holmes requested to see Thomas Grey. The farmer was a burly man with a stern demeanor. "I want to find Emily as much as anyone," he said gruffly. "But I fear she has run off with that blacksmith's son."

Holmes studied Thomas carefully. "Is there any reason you would wish to harm her?"

Thomas bristled. "Of course not! But if she has betrayed me, I will not stand for it."

Holmes nodded. "We shall uncover the truth."

That night, Holmes and Watson kept watch near the woods. As the moon rose, a figure appeared—a man in a dark cloak, moving stealthily. Holmes signaled to Watson, and they followed at a distance.

The figure led them to a hidden cave beneath the cliffs. Inside, they found Emily Carter, alive but frightened. She explained that she had fled to escape an arranged marriage and sought refuge with Peter.

Holmes confronted Thomas Grey, who confessed to threatening Emily to keep her from leaving. The villagers, relieved by the resolution, thanked Holmes and Watson.

As they departed Little Hatherley, Holmes reflected on the case. "Sometimes, the greatest mysteries are not of crime, but of the human heart."

Watson smiled. "And you, Holmes, are the greatest detective of them all."

events.title: Resolution and Aftermath
detailed_summary: After Turner signs his confession, Holmes refrains from judgment, acknowledging the immense temptation Turner faced.
Turner expresses hope Holmes and Watson never face such trials and asks about Holmes's intentions.
Holmes states that due to Turner's health, he will do nothing.
He reminds Turner he will soon face a higher judgment.
Holmes promises to keep the confession secret unless James McCarthy is condemned, ensuring Turner's secret remains safe, whether he lives or dies.
Turner bids them farewell, stating their actions have brought peace to his deathbed.
He stumbles weakly from the room.
After a long silence, Holmes reflects on the cruelty of fate, quoting Baxter: 'There, but for the grace of God, goes Sherlock Holmes.'
An epilogue reveals James McCarthy was acquitted at the Assizes, thanks to Holmes's objections provided to the defense.
Old Turner died seven months later.
The narrative concludes with the prospect of James McCarthy and Alice Turner potentially finding future happiness together, unaware of the dark secrets connecting their fathers.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Well, it is not for me to judge you,” said Holmes as the old man signed the statement which had been drawn out.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Old Turner lived for seven months after our interview, but he is now dead; and there is every prospect that the son and daughter may come to live happily together in ignorance of the black cloud which rests upon their past.

events.text_segment:
“Well, it is not for me to judge you,” said Holmes as the old man signed the statement which had been drawn out. “I pray that we may never be exposed to such a temptation.”
“I pray not, sir. And what do you intend to do?”
“In view of your health, nothing. You are yourself aware that you will soon have to answer for your deed at a higher court than the Assizes. I will keep your confession, and if McCarthy is condemned I shall be forced to use it. If not, it shall never be seen by mortal eye; and your secret, whether you be alive or dead, shall be safe with us.”
“Farewell, then,” said the old man solemnly. “Your own deathbeds, when they come, will be the easier for the thought of the peace which you have given to mine.” Tottering and shaking in all his giant frame, he stumbled slowly from the room.
“God help us!” said Holmes after a long silence. “Why does fate play such tricks with poor, helpless worms? I never hear of such a case as this that I do not think of Baxter’s words, and say, ‘There, but for the grace of God, goes Sherlock Holmes.’”
James McCarthy was acquitted at the Assizes on the strength of a number of objections which had been drawn out by Holmes and submitted to the defending counsel. Old Turner lived for seven months after our interview, but he is now dead; and there is every prospect that the son and daughter may come to live happily together in ignorance of the black cloud which rests upon their past.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
"Well, it is not for me to judge you," said Holmes as the old man signed the statement which had been drawn out. "You have had a great temptation, and you have yielded to it. I hope that neither Dr. Watson nor I may ever be called upon to face such a trial."

"I hope not," said Turner, with a faint smile. "What will you do now?"

"Nothing," said Holmes. "Your health is too poor to allow me to take any action. But remember, you will soon have to answer to a higher tribunal."

"I know," said Turner. "I only ask that you keep my secret. If James McCarthy is condemned, then you may reveal the truth. But if he is acquitted, let my confession die with me."

"You have my word," said Holmes. "Whether you live or die, your secret is safe with us."

Turner shook hands with Holmes and Watson, and with a faint smile, he bade them farewell. He stumbled weakly from the room, leaving the two men in silence.

After a long pause, Holmes broke the stillness. "It is a cruel fate," he said softly, "but as Baxter said, 'There, but for the grace of God, goes Sherlock Holmes.'"

An epilogue reveals that James McCarthy was acquitted at the Assizes, thanks to Holmes's objections which were passed to the defense. Old Turner died seven months later. The narrative closes with the hopeful prospect that James McCarthy and Alice Turner may find happiness together, unaware of the dark secrets that once bound their fathers.

“Well, it is not for me to judge you,” said Holmes as the old man signed the statement which had been drawn out. “But I must say, your courage in facing the truth is commendable.” The old man looked up, his eyes reflecting a mixture of relief and sorrow. “I only wish I had come forward sooner,” he murmured. Holmes nodded thoughtfully, folding the paper carefully. “Better late than never, sir. Your testimony will be invaluable in bringing the culprit to justice.”

Holmes tapped his finger against his temple. “Observation, my dear Watson. The faint ink stains on his fingers, the subtle hesitation in his voice, and the peculiar way he avoided direct eye contact—all pointed to a man burdened by guilt yet yearning for redemption.” 

With the statement secured, Holmes prepared to present the evidence to the authorities. The case, once shrouded in mystery, was now on the path to resolution, thanks to the keen intellect and unwavering determination of Sherlock Holmes.

events.title: Watson Introduces a Remarkable and Unresolved Case
detailed_summary: The narrator, Watson, reflects on his extensive records of Sherlock Holmes's cases from 1882 to 1890, noting the difficulty in selecting which ones to share.
He explains that some cases are already public, some didn't showcase Holmes's unique skills, some remained unsolved, and others relied on conjecture rather than Holmes's preferred logical proof.
Despite this, Watson chooses to recount a particularly striking case from this last category, acknowledging that some aspects were never fully clarified.

He mentions other notable cases from 1887, including the Paradol Chamber, the Amateur Mendicant Society, the Sophy Anderson, the Grice Patersons, and the Camberwell poisoning, briefly detailing Holmes's deduction involving the victim's watch in the latter.
Watson emphasizes that the current case possesses features more singular than any of these others.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When I glance over my notes and records of the Sherlock Holmes cases between the years ’82 and ’90, I am faced by so many which present strange and interesting features that it is no easy matter to know which to choose and which to leave.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: All these I may sketch out at some future date, but none of them present such singular features as the strange train of circumstances which I have now taken up my pen to describe.

events.text_segment:
When I glance over my notes and records of the Sherlock Holmes cases between the years ’82 and ’90, I am faced by so many which present strange and interesting features that it is no easy matter to know which to choose and which to leave. Some, however, have already gained publicity through the papers, and others have not offered a field for those peculiar qualities which my friend possessed in so high a degree, and which it is the object of these papers to illustrate. Some, too, have baffled his analytical skill, and would be, as narratives, beginnings without an ending, while others have been but partially cleared up, and have their explanations founded rather upon conjecture and surmise than on that absolute logical proof which was so dear to him. There is, however, one of these last which was so remarkable in its details and so startling in its results that I am tempted to give some account of it in spite of the fact that there are points in connection with it which never have been, and probably never will be, entirely cleared up.
The year ’87 furnished us with a long series of cases of greater or less interest, of which I retain the records. Among my headings under this one twelve months I find an account of the adventure of the Paradol Chamber, of the Amateur Mendicant Society, who held a luxurious club in the lower vault of a furniture warehouse, of the facts connected with the loss of the British barque Sophy Anderson, of the singular adventures of the Grice Patersons in the island of Uffa, and finally of the Camberwell poisoning case. In the latter, as may be remembered, Sherlock Holmes was able, by winding up the dead man’s watch, to prove that it had been wound up two hours before, and that therefore the deceased had gone to bed within that time—a deduction which was of the greatest importance in clearing up the case. All these I may sketch out at some future date, but none of them present such singular features as the strange train of circumstances which I have now taken up my pen to describe.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
When I glance over my notes and records of the Sherlock Holmes cases between the years ’82 and ’90, I am faced by so many which present strange and interesting features that it is no easy matter to know which to choose and which to leave. Some, indeed, have already been made public, and others again did not seem to me to illustrate any special quality of the great reasoner. There are some, too, which have remained in my portfolio for years, and which I have never ventured to lay before the public, for the reason that they were not, in the strictest sense, cases which Sherlock Holmes had solved. They were rather problems which he had attempted, and which had baffled him, and which, therefore, did not show to the best advantage the wonderful powers of deduction which he possessed. There are others, again, which I have omitted because they were based upon conjecture rather than upon proof, and I have always held that the true test of a detective story is that it should be founded upon fact and not upon fancy.

Yet, in spite of these difficulties, I have decided to give an account of one of these latter cases, which, though it did not end in the complete solution of the mystery, was yet so singular and so striking that I cannot resist the temptation of placing it on record. It is a case which, in some respects, is more remarkable than any other which I have ever had the good fortune to chronicle.

In the year 1887, I had the opportunity of witnessing several curious adventures in which Holmes was engaged. There was the case of the Paradol Chamber, in which a man was found dead in a locked room with no apparent cause of death; the Amateur Mendicant Society, which involved a curious imposture; the Sophy Anderson case, which was a study in domestic tragedy; the Grice Patersons, which was a tale of mistaken identity; and the Camberwell poisoning, in which Holmes’s keen observation of a watch led to the discovery of the murderer.

But the case which I am about to relate possesses features more singular than any of these, and it is one which, though it baffled Holmes in some respects, yet remains a monument to his extraordinary powers of reasoning.

IMPROVEMENT GUIDANCE:
1. MAJOR STRUCTURAL ISSUES:
- The completion invents several reflective passages about the narrator's reluctance to publish certain cases, which are not present in the original. This includes extended commentary on why some cases were omitted and the narrator's philosophy about detective stories.
- The completion adds invented details about the nature of the cases (e.g., a man found dead in a locked room, mistaken identity, domestic tragedy) that are not present in the original passage.

2. MISSING ELEMENTS:
- The completion omits the original's specific mention that some cases had already gained publicity through the papers, and that others did not offer a field for Holmes's unique qualities, which the papers aim to illustrate.
- The completion does not include the original's point that some cases were only partially cleared up and that their explanations were based on conjecture and surmise rather than logical proof.
- The completion leaves out the original's detailed description of the Camberwell poisoning case, specifically the deduction involving the dead man's watch and its significance in solving the case.
- The completion does not mention the narrator's intention to possibly sketch out the other cases at a future date, as in the original.

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:
- The completion provides inaccurate or invented summaries for the cases listed (e.g., the nature of the Paradol Chamber, the Amateur Mendicant Society, the Sophy Anderson case, and the Grice Patersons), which do not match the original content.
- The completion gives an inaccurate time reference by stating "In the year 1887," rather than reflecting the original's phrasing and context about the year.
- The sequence of events is altered: the completion introduces the list of cases and their summaries before establishing the narrator's reasoning for choosing the case to recount, whereas the original first discusses the selection process and then lists the cases.
- The completion attributes a discovery of the murderer in the Camberwell poisoning case, which is not specified in the original passage.

To improve, the LLM should avoid inventing reflective commentary and case details not present in the source, ensure all key categories of information from the original are included, and maintain the correct sequence and focus of the original narrative.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
When I glance over my notes and records of the Sherlock Holmes cases between the years ’82 and ’90, I am faced by so many which present strange and interesting features that it is no easy matter to know which to choose and which to leave. Some, indeed, have such a singular and dramatic interest that I am tempted to give them a place in these pages, even though they may not be of the first rank in point of intellectual difficulty. Others, again, are so intricate and involved that they would require a volume to themselves, and would be out of place in a brief collection. Yet, it is the very variety of these cases which makes the record so fascinating, for they show the wide range of human character and the endless ingenuity of crime.

Among the many adventures which I might relate, there is one which stands out for its curious combination of the commonplace and the extraordinary. It was in the early spring of 1887 that a young woman came to consult Holmes upon a matter which at first seemed trivial, but which soon unfolded into a mystery of the deepest interest. The case involved a missing heirloom, a secret message, and a series of events which led us through the foggy streets of London to the quiet lanes of the countryside.

Holmes, with his usual keen eye for detail and his unparalleled powers of deduction, was able to unravel the tangled threads of the case with remarkable speed. His methods, though sometimes unorthodox, always led to the truth, and in this instance, the truth was stranger than fiction. The case not only tested his intellect but also revealed the depths of human passion and the lengths to which some will go to protect their secrets.

As I recount these adventures, I am reminded of the words of my friend: "When you have eliminated the impossible, whatever remains, however improbable, must be the truth." It is this principle that guided us through the labyrinth of clues and red herrings, and it is this principle that I hope will guide the reader through the tales which follow.

events.title: A Stormy Night and an Unexpected Visitor
detailed_summary: The narrative shifts to a late September evening marked by violent equinoctial gales.
The intense wind and rain outside emphasized the power of nature even within London.
Inside 221B Baker Street, Holmes was occupied with indexing his crime records by the fire, while Watson read a sea story, the storm outside merging with the text's atmosphere.
Watson notes his temporary return to Baker Street as his wife was visiting her mother.
The doorbell rings unexpectedly through the storm.
Watson speculates about the visitor, suggesting a friend of Holmes.
Holmes dismisses the idea, stating he has no friends besides Watson and doesn't encourage visitors.

Watson then suggests a client, to which Holmes agrees, reasoning that only a serious case would bring someone out in such weather and at such an hour, though he initially suspects it might be an acquaintance of the landlady.
Contrary to Holmes's guess, footsteps approach, and someone knocks.
Holmes adjusts the lamp to illuminate the visitor's chair while keeping himself in shadow.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was in the latter days of September, and the equinoctial gales had set in with exceptional violence.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Come in!” said he.

events.text_segment:
It was in the latter days of September, and the equinoctial gales had set in with exceptional violence. All day the wind had screamed and the rain had beaten against the windows, so that even here in the heart of great, hand-made London we were forced to raise our minds for the instant from the routine of life and to recognise the presence of those great elemental forces which shriek at mankind through the bars of his civilisation, like untamed beasts in a cage. As evening drew in, the storm grew higher and louder, and the wind cried and sobbed like a child in the chimney. Sherlock Holmes sat moodily at one side of the fireplace cross-indexing his records of crime, while I at the other was deep in one of Clark Russell’s fine sea-stories until the howl of the gale from without seemed to blend with the text, and the splash of the rain to lengthen out into the long swash of the sea waves. My wife was on a visit to her mother’s, and for a few days I was a dweller once more in my old quarters at Baker Street.
“Why,” said I, glancing up at my companion, “that was surely the bell. Who could come to-night? Some friend of yours, perhaps?”
“Except yourself I have none,” he answered. “I do not encourage visitors.”
“A client, then?”
“If so, it is a serious case. Nothing less would bring a man out on such a day and at such an hour. But I take it that it is more likely to be some crony of the landlady’s.”
Sherlock Holmes was wrong in his conjecture, however, for there came a step in the passage and a tapping at the door. He stretched out his long arm to turn the lamp away from himself and towards the vacant chair upon which a newcomer must sit.
“Come in!” said he.

It was in the latter days of September, and the equinoctial gales had set in with exceptional violence. The streets of London were wet and slippery, and the wind howled through the gas lamps, making the shadows dance upon the walls. I was sitting by the fire in our rooms at Baker Street, reading a sea story, while Holmes was busily engaged in indexing his vast collection of crime records. The storm outside seemed to mingle with the narrative, lending it a vividness which I had never before experienced.

My wife was visiting her mother, and I had returned to Baker Street for a few days. The familiar surroundings and the presence of Holmes were a comfort to me.

Suddenly, the doorbell rang sharply through the storm. I looked up from my book and speculated, "That must be a friend of yours, Holmes."

Holmes shook his head. "I have no friends, Watson, and I do not encourage visitors."

"Then perhaps a client," I suggested.

Holmes nodded thoughtfully. "Yes, it must be a serious case to bring someone out in such weather and at this hour. But I suspect it may be an acquaintance of Mrs. Hudson's."

Footsteps approached, and a knock sounded at the door. Holmes adjusted the lamp so that the visitor's chair was illuminated, while he himself remained in shadow. "Pray come in," he said.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
It was in the latter days of September, and the equinoctial gales had set in with exceptional violence. The streets of London were drenched with rain, and the wind howled through the narrow alleys like a living thing. Sherlock Holmes and I were seated by the fire in our Baker Street lodgings, the flickering flames casting long shadows upon the walls. Holmes was deep in thought, his keen eyes fixed upon the dancing embers, while I busied myself with the morning paper.

Suddenly, the door burst open, and a tall, gaunt man entered, his face pale and drawn with anxiety. "Mr. Holmes," he exclaimed, "I am in desperate need of your assistance."

Holmes motioned him to sit, and the man introduced himself as Mr. John Openshaw. He proceeded to recount a most peculiar and troubling tale. Several years prior, his uncle had been found dead under mysterious circumstances, clutching a scrap of paper with the words "The Speckled Band" scrawled upon it. Since then, members of his family had been dying one by one, each under strange and inexplicable conditions.

Holmes listened intently, his eyes narrowing as he pieced together the fragments of the story. "This 'Speckled Band'—have you any idea what it might signify?" he inquired.

"No, sir," replied Mr. Openshaw, "but I fear it is connected to the deaths."

Holmes rose abruptly. "Watson, we must visit the estate at once. There is a mystery here that demands our immediate attention."

As we prepared to depart, I could not help but feel a thrill of anticipation. The game was afoot, and once more, we were plunged into the shadowy world of crime and intrigue that so fascinated my friend and companion.

events.title: John Openshaw Arrives Seeking Help
detailed_summary: A young man, around twenty-two, well-dressed but soaked from the storm, enters the room.
He appears refined but pale and anxious under the lamplight.
He apologizes for intruding and bringing the weather inside.
Holmes offers to take his wet coat and umbrella, deducing from the mud on his shoes that he has traveled from Horsham in the south-west.
The visitor confirms he is from Horsham and states the clay and chalk mixture on his shoes is indeed distinctive.
He declares he has come seeking advice and help.
Holmes remarks that advice is easily obtained, but help is not always so simple.
The young man reveals he has heard of Holmes through Major Prendergast, whom Holmes saved during the Tankerville Club scandal involving cheating at cards.
He relays the Major's assertion that Holmes can solve anything, which Holmes modestly disputes, admitting he has been defeated four times.

The visitor contrasts these few failures with Holmes's many successes, prompting Holmes to invite him to share the details of his case, assuring him that unusual cases are his specialty as the 'last court of appeal'.
The young man expresses doubt that even Holmes has encountered a mystery as strange as his family's experiences.
Holmes's interest is piqued, and he asks for the essential facts from the beginning.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The man who entered was young, some two-and-twenty at the outside, well-groomed and trimly clad, with something of refinement and delicacy in his bearing.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Pray give us the essential facts from the commencement, and I can afterwards question you as to those details which seem to me to be most important.”

events.text_segment:
The man who entered was young, some two-and-twenty at the outside, well-groomed and trimly clad, with something of refinement and delicacy in his bearing. The streaming umbrella which he held in his hand, and his long shining waterproof told of the fierce weather through which he had come. He looked about him anxiously in the glare of the lamp, and I could see that his face was pale and his eyes heavy, like those of a man who is weighed down with some great anxiety.
“I owe you an apology,” he said, raising his golden pince-nez to his eyes. “I trust that I am not intruding. I fear that I have brought some traces of the storm and rain into your snug chamber.”
“Give me your coat and umbrella,” said Holmes. “They may rest here on the hook and will be dry presently. You have come up from the south-west, I see.”
“Yes, from Horsham.”
“That clay and chalk mixture which I see upon your toe caps is quite distinctive.”
“I have come for advice.”
“That is easily got.”
“And help.”
“That is not always so easy.”
“I have heard of you, Mr. Holmes. I heard from Major Prendergast how you saved him in the Tankerville Club scandal.”
“Ah, of course. He was wrongfully accused of cheating at cards.”
“He said that you could solve anything.”
“He said too much.”
“That you are never beaten.”
“I have been beaten four times—three times by men, and once by a woman.”
“But what is that compared with the number of your successes?”
“It is true that I have been generally successful.”
“Then you may be so with me.”
“I beg that you will draw your chair up to the fire and favour me with some details as to your case.”
“It is no ordinary one.”
“None of those which come to me are. I am the last court of appeal.”
“And yet I question, sir, whether, in all your experience, you have ever listened to a more mysterious and inexplicable chain of events than those which have happened in my own family.”
“You fill me with interest,” said Holmes. “Pray give us the essential facts from the commencement, and I can afterwards question you as to those details which seem to me to be most important.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
The man who entered was young, some two-and-twenty at the outside, well-groomed and trimly clad, with something of refinement and delicacy in his bearing. He was wet to the skin, and his clothes were clinging to him, but he carried himself with a certain quiet dignity. His face was pale and his eyes restless, as if he had come through some mental storm as well as the physical one without. He apologized for the intrusion and for bringing the weather with him, but he had come a long way and was in urgent need of advice and assistance.

Holmes, with his usual quickness of observation, took the young man's coat and umbrella, noting the mud on his shoes. "You have come from Horsham," he said.

The visitor looked surprised but confirmed the deduction. "Yes, I have just come from Horsham. The mixture of clay and chalk on my shoes is quite distinctive."

"And you have come to me for help?"

"Yes," said the young man. "I have heard of you through Major Prendergast, whom you once helped in a difficult matter at the Tankerville Club. He told me that you are the man to see when all other resources fail."

Holmes smiled modestly. "I have been beaten four times, but I have had many more successes."

The visitor nodded. "That is why I have come. I have a case which I believe to be beyond the ordinary, and I hope you will be able to assist me."

Holmes leaned forward with interest. "You have come to the right place. I am the last court of appeal in such matters. Pray, tell me the facts from the beginning."

The young man hesitated, then began to relate the strange and troubling events that had befallen his family, events so unusual that even Holmes's keen mind was intrigued.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
He carried himself with an air of quiet confidence, yet there was a subtle nervousness in his eyes that betrayed a deeper turmoil. His gaze swept the room briefly before settling upon Sherlock Holmes, who was seated by the fire, his keen eyes already assessing the newcomer. The young man approached with measured steps, his voice steady but tinged with urgency as he spoke.

"Mr. Holmes," he began, "I have come to seek your assistance in a matter most perplexing and distressing."

Holmes inclined his head slightly, inviting the man to continue. "Pray, be seated and tell me all that troubles you."

The visitor took a seat, clasping his hands tightly. "My name is John Openshaw," he said. "I am a clerk in a respectable firm, and until recently, my life was unremarkable. But now, I find myself ensnared in a mystery that defies explanation."

Holmes leaned forward, his interest piqued. "Proceed, Mr. Openshaw."

"It began with a letter," the young man explained. "An anonymous note warning me to beware the consequences of my actions. At first, I dismissed it as a prank, but soon, strange occurrences followed. I was followed by shadowy figures, and my home was ransacked, though nothing was taken."

"Have you any idea who might wish you harm?" Holmes inquired.

"None," Openshaw replied. "But I fear it is connected to a family secret, one that has been buried for generations."

Holmes nodded thoughtfully. "Family secrets often cast long shadows. Tell me more about this secret."

Openshaw hesitated, then spoke of a tragic event involving his ancestors, a tale of betrayal and lost fortunes. "I believe someone is trying to prevent me from uncovering the truth."

Holmes smiled faintly. "Fear not, Mr. Openshaw. We shall unravel this mystery together. The game is afoot."

events.title: Openshaw Details His Uncle Elias's History
detailed_summary: The young man introduces himself as John Openshaw and explains the problem is hereditary, requiring him to start his story with his family history.
He describes his grandfather's two sons: his Uncle Elias and his father Joseph.
His father Joseph ran a successful bicycle tire factory in Coventry before retiring.
Uncle Elias emigrated to America, became a successful planter in Florida, and served as a colonel in the Confederate army.
After the Civil War, Elias returned to his plantation for a few years before moving back to Europe around 1869 or 1870, settling near Horsham, Sussex.

events.text_segment:
The young man pulled his chair up and pushed his wet feet out towards the blaze.
“My name,” said he, “is John Openshaw, but my own affairs have, as far as I can understand, little to do with this awful business. It is a hereditary matter; so in order to give you an idea of the facts, I must go back to the commencement of the affair.
“You must know that my grandfather had two sons—my uncle Elias and my father Joseph. My father had a small factory at Coventry, which he enlarged at the time of the invention of bicycling. He was a patentee of the Openshaw unbreakable tire, and his business met with such success that he was able to sell it and to retire upon a handsome competence.
“My uncle Elias emigrated to America when he was a young man and became a planter in Florida, where he was reported to have done very well. At the time of the war he fought in Jackson’s army, and afterwards under Hood, where he rose to be a colonel. When Lee laid down his arms my uncle returned to his plantation, where he remained for three or four years. About 1869 or 1870 he came back to Europe and took a small estate in Sussex, near Horsham. He had made a very considerable fortune in the States, and his reason for leaving them was his aversion to the negroes, and his dislike of the Republican policy in extending the franchise to them. He was a singular man, fierce and quick-tempered, very foul-mouthed when he was angry, and of a most retiring disposition. During all the years that he lived at Horsham, I doubt if ever he set foot in the town. He had a garden and two or three fields round his house, and there he would take his exercise, though very often for weeks on end he would never leave his room. He drank a great deal of brandy and smoked very heavily, but he would see no society and did not want any friends, not even his own brother.
“He didn’t mind me; in fact, he took a fancy to me, for at the time when he saw me first I was a youngster of twelve or so. This would be in the year 1878, after he had been eight or nine years in England. He begged my father to let me live with him and he was very kind to me in his way. When he was sober he used to be fond of playing backgammon and draughts with me, and he would make me his representative both with the servants and with the tradespeople, so that by the time that I was sixteen I was quite master of the house. I kept all the keys and could go where I liked and do what I liked, so long as I did not disturb him in his privacy. There was one singular exception, however, for he had a single room, a lumber-room up among the attics, which was invariably locked, and which he would never permit either me or anyone else to enter. With a boy’s curiosity I have peeped through the keyhole, but I was never able to see more than such a collection of old trunks and bundles as would be expected in such a room.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
The young man pulled his chair up and pushed his wet feet out towards the blaze. "My name is John Openshaw," he said, "and I have come to you, Mr. Holmes, because I am in great trouble. The matter is one which has been in my family for some years, and it is a hereditary trouble, so that I must begin by telling you something of my family history."

"My grandfather had two sons, my uncle Elias and my father Joseph. My father was a man of business, and he ran a successful bicycle tire factory in Coventry before he retired. My uncle Elias, however, emigrated to America, where he became a planter in Florida and served as a colonel in the Confederate army during the Civil War. After the war, he returned to his plantation for a few years, but around 1869 or 1870 he came back to Europe and settled near Horsham in Sussex. The reason for his leaving America was said to be his aversion to the Black people and the Republican policies which extended suffrage to them.

"In England, he lived as a recluse. He was a fierce, quick-tempered man, foul-mouthed and solitary. He rarely left his house, preferring to spend his time in his garden or in his room. He drank heavily and smoked constantly, and he avoided all society, including that of his brother."

"When I was about twelve years old, in 1878, my uncle took a liking to me and invited me to live with him. He was kind to me in his own way, and when I was sixteen he made me the master of the house, giving me the keys and entrusting me with its care. I had access to everything except one locked lumber-room in the attic, which he forbade anyone to enter. My curiosity was great, and I once peeped through the keyhole, but I could see only old trunks and bundles."

"That is the beginning of my story, Mr. Holmes, and I hope you will be able to help me with the trouble which has come upon me and my family."

He drank heavily and smoked constantly."

"For about ten years he lived in this way, a recluse in England. When I was twelve years old, in 1878, he took a liking to me and invited me to live with him. At first, he was kind in his own way, playing games with me when he was sober. As I grew older, he gradually entrusted me with more responsibility. By the time I was sixteen, he had made me the master of the house, giving me the keys and making me the representative to the servants and tradespeople. I was allowed to do as I liked so long as I did not disturb his privacy."

"There was only one room in the house which was forbidden to me — a lumber-room in the attic, locked and barred. My uncle would not allow anyone to enter it. My curiosity was great, and once I peeped through the keyhole, but I could see only old trunks and bundles."

The young man pulled his chair up and pushed his wet feet out towards the blaze. The fire crackled and spat, casting flickering shadows across the room, which was otherwise dim and filled with the scent of damp earth and burning wood. He sighed deeply, the weight of the day's events pressing heavily upon his shoulders. Outside, the rain continued to fall in relentless sheets, drumming against the windowpanes and turning the streets into rivers.

He was a stranger in this part of London, having arrived only that morning with little more than a small bag and a heart full of hope. Yet, the city had greeted him with its usual indifference, and the cold had seeped into his bones despite the warmth of the fire. His thoughts drifted back to the letter he had received, the one that had brought him here—a plea for help from a friend long thought lost.

As he sat there, the door creaked open, and a tall figure stepped inside, shaking off the rain from his coat. The newcomer’s eyes were sharp and observant, taking in the room and its occupant with a practiced gaze. He removed his hat and hung it on a nearby hook before settling into a chair opposite the young man.

"I trust the journey was not too arduous?" the visitor inquired, his voice calm and measured.

The young man nodded. "The rain was relentless, but I managed. I am grateful for your hospitality."

"No need for thanks," the visitor replied. "We have much to discuss, and time is of the essence."

He reached into his coat pocket and produced a small, folded piece of paper, which he handed across the table. The young man unfolded it carefully, revealing a hastily sketched map and a series of cryptic notes.

"This is what I have uncovered so far," the visitor explained. "The case is more complex than it first appeared. There are layers of deception and danger that we must navigate with caution."

The young man studied the map, tracing the routes and landmarks with his finger. "I see. And you believe the key lies here, in this district?"

"Precisely," the visitor confirmed. "But we must be discreet. There are eyes and ears everywhere, and not all are friendly."

A sudden knock at the door interrupted their conversation. The visitor rose swiftly, moving to answer it. A woman entered, her expression grave and her eyes filled with urgency.

"I bring news," she said, her voice barely above a whisper. "The situation has escalated. We have little time."

The visitor nodded, gesturing for her to join them. "Then we must act quickly. The game is afoot, and every moment counts."

Together, the three of them poured over the details, formulating a plan to unravel the mystery that had brought them together. The fire continued to burn, its light a beacon against the encroaching darkness, as they prepared to face the challenges ahead with determination and resolve.

events.title: The First Warning and Uncle Elias's Demise
detailed_summary: In March 1883, Uncle Elias received a rare letter with a Pondicherry postmark.
Upon opening it, five dried orange pips fell out.

John's initial amusement turned to horror at his uncle's reaction: Elias's face turned putty-colored, his eyes bulged, and he shrieked 'K. K. K.!', followed by 'My God, my God, my sins have overtaken me!'
When John asked what was wrong, Elias responded 'Death' and retreated to his room.
John examined the envelope and found 'K K K' scrawled in red ink on the inner flap.
Later, John encountered his uncle coming downstairs with an old key (likely for the attic room) and a small brass cashbox.
Elias defiantly declared he would 'checkmate them' and instructed John to light a fire in his room and summon Fordham, the lawyer.
When the lawyer arrived, John was called into the room, where the fire blazed and a mass of burned paper ashes lay in the grate next to the open, empty brass box.
John noticed with a start that the box lid bore the same 'K K K' inscription as the envelope.

Elias had John witness his will, leaving his estate (with all 'advantages and disadvantages') to John's father, advising that if it couldn't be enjoyed peacefully, it should be given to one's worst enemy.
John signed the will, deeply disturbed by the incident and filled with a lingering sense of dread.
Elias's behavior worsened; he drank more, became more reclusive, and had episodes of drunken frenzy, rushing outside with a revolver, shouting defiance, only to retreat back indoors in terror.
One night, during such an episode, Elias disappeared.
He was found dead, face down in a shallow, green-scummed garden pool.
With no signs of violence and considering Elias's eccentricity, the verdict was suicide.
John, however, doubted this, knowing his uncle's fear of death.
John's father inherited the estate and about £14,000.
Holmes interrupts to ask for the dates: the letter arrived March 10, 1883, and Elias died seven weeks later on May 2nd.
Holmes thanks Openshaw and asks him to continue.

events.text_segment:
“One day—it was in March, 1883—a letter with a foreign stamp lay upon the table in front of the colonel’s plate. It was not a common thing for him to receive letters, for his bills were all paid in ready money, and he had no friends of any sort. ‘From India!’ said he as he took it up, ‘Pondicherry postmark! What can this be?’ Opening it hurriedly, out there jumped five little dried orange pips, which pattered down upon his plate. I began to laugh at this, but the laugh was struck from my lips at the sight of his face. His lip had fallen, his eyes were protruding, his skin the colour of putty, and he glared at the envelope which he still held in his trembling hand, ‘K. K. K.!’ he shrieked, and then, ‘My God, my God, my sins have overtaken me!’
“‘What is it, uncle?’ I cried.
“‘Death,’ said he, and rising from the table he retired to his room, leaving me palpitating with horror. I took up the envelope and saw scrawled in red ink upon the inner flap, just above the gum, the letter K three times repeated. There was nothing else save the five dried pips. What could be the reason of his overpowering terror? I left the breakfast-table, and as I ascended the stair I met him coming down with an old rusty key, which must have belonged to the attic, in one hand, and a small brass box, like a cashbox, in the other.
“‘They may do what they like, but I’ll checkmate them still,’ said he with an oath. ‘Tell Mary that I shall want a fire in my room to-day, and send down to Fordham, the Horsham lawyer.’
“I did as he ordered, and when the lawyer arrived I was asked to step up to the room. The fire was burning brightly, and in the grate there was a mass of black, fluffy ashes, as of burned paper, while the brass box stood open and empty beside it. As I glanced at the box I noticed, with a start, that upon the lid was printed the treble K which I had read in the morning upon the envelope.
“‘I wish you, John,’ said my uncle, ‘to witness my will. I leave my estate, with all its advantages and all its disadvantages, to my brother, your father, whence it will, no doubt, descend to you. If you can enjoy it in peace, well and good! If you find you cannot, take my advice, my boy, and leave it to your deadliest enemy. I am sorry to give you such a two-edged thing, but I can’t say what turn things are going to take. Kindly sign the paper where Mr. Fordham shows you.’
“I signed the paper as directed, and the lawyer took it away with him. The singular incident made, as you may think, the deepest impression upon me, and I pondered over it and turned it every way in my mind without being able to make anything of it. Yet I could not shake off the vague feeling of dread which it left behind, though the sensation grew less keen as the weeks passed and nothing happened to disturb the usual routine of our lives. I could see a change in my uncle, however. He drank more than ever, and he was less inclined for any sort of society. Most of his time he would spend in his room, with the door locked upon the inside, but sometimes he would emerge in a sort of drunken frenzy and would burst out of the house and tear about the garden with a revolver in his hand, screaming out that he was afraid of no man, and that he was not to be cooped up, like a sheep in a pen, by man or devil. When these hot fits were over, however, he would rush tumultuously in at the door and lock and bar it behind him, like a man who can brazen it out no longer against the terror which lies at the roots of his soul. At such times I have seen his face, even on a cold day, glisten with moisture, as though it were new raised from a basin.
“Well, to come to an end of the matter, Mr. Holmes, and not to abuse your patience, there came a night when he made one of those drunken sallies from which he never came back. We found him, when we went to search for him, face downward in a little green-scummed pool, which lay at the foot of the garden. There was no sign of any violence, and the water was but two feet deep, so that the jury, having regard to his known eccentricity, brought in a verdict of ‘suicide.’ But I, who knew how he winced from the very thought of death, had much ado to persuade myself that he had gone out of his way to meet it. The matter passed, however, and my father entered into possession of the estate, and of some £ 14,000, which lay to his credit at the bank.”
“One moment,” Holmes interposed, “your statement is, I foresee, one of the most remarkable to which I have ever listened. Let me have the date of the reception by your uncle of the letter, and the date of his supposed suicide.”
“The letter arrived on March 10, 1883. His death was seven weeks later, upon the night of May 2nd.”
“Thank you. Pray proceed.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
One day—it was in March, 1883—a letter with a foreign stamp lay upon the table in front of the colonel’s plate. It was a curious letter, for it bore the postmark of Pondicherry, and when my uncle opened it, five dried orange pips fluttered out upon the floor. At first he laughed, but the next moment his face turned ashen, his eyes bulged, and he shrieked, “K. K. K.!” Then, clutching his head, he cried, “My God, my God, my sins have overtaken me!”

I asked him what was the matter, but he only answered, “Death,” and hurried away to his room. I examined the envelope and found the letters “K K K” scrawled in red ink upon the inner flap. Later, I saw him coming down the stairs with an old key in his hand and a small brass cashbox. He declared that he would “checkmate them,” and bade me light a fire in his room and send for Fordham, the lawyer.

When the lawyer arrived, I was called into the room, where a fire was blazing in the grate, and a mass of burned paper ashes lay upon the hearth beside the open, empty brass box. I noticed with a start that the lid bore the same “K K K” inscription as the envelope. My uncle made me witness his will, leaving his estate, with all its advantages and disadvantages, to my father, and advising that if it could not be enjoyed in peace, it should be given to one’s worst enemy. I signed the will, deeply disturbed and filled with a lingering sense of dread.

After that, my uncle’s behavior grew worse. He drank more heavily, became more reclusive, and had episodes of drunken frenzy, rushing outside with a revolver, shouting defiance, only to retreat back indoors in terror. One night, during such an episode, he disappeared. He was found dead, face down in a shallow, green-scummed garden pool. There were no signs of violence, and considering his eccentricity, the verdict was suicide. But I doubted this, knowing my uncle’s fear of death.

My father inherited the estate and about fourteen thousand pounds. Holmes interrupted to ask for the dates: the letter arrived on March 10, 1883, and my uncle died seven weeks later, on May 2nd. Holmes thanked me and asked me to continue.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
It was a curious letter, for it bore no address, and the handwriting was strange and unfamiliar. The colonel, a man of keen observation and a mind sharpened by years of military service, picked it up with a puzzled frown. He turned it over, examining the seal, which was a curious emblem of a lion rampant, and then broke it open with a practiced hand.

Inside was a single sheet of paper, upon which was written a brief but urgent message:

"Dear Colonel,

I write to you from the heart of the Balkans, where a matter of great importance has come to my attention. Your expertise and discretion are required at once. I cannot divulge more in this letter, but I implore you to meet me at the old mill by the river at midnight tomorrow. Come alone, and bring no one with you.

Yours in confidence,

A Friend"

The colonel's eyes narrowed as he read the note. The handwriting was unfamiliar, but the tone was unmistakably urgent. He glanced around the room, noting the curious glances of his guests, who had been gathered for a quiet dinner. The letter was addressed to him alone, and the foreign stamp suggested it had traveled some distance.

After a moment's hesitation, the colonel folded the letter carefully and placed it in his breast pocket. "Gentlemen," he said, rising from his seat, "it appears I have a matter of some urgency to attend to. I must beg your pardon, but I shall have to take my leave early this evening."

His guests murmured their understanding, though curiosity was plainly written on their faces. The colonel donned his coat and hat, and with a nod to the butler, he stepped out into the chill March evening.

The streets were quiet as he made his way to the old mill, a dilapidated structure that had long been abandoned. The moon cast a pale light over the river, and the air was thick with the scent of damp earth and budding spring.

As he approached the mill, a shadow detached itself from the darkness. A tall figure stepped forward, cloaked and hooded, face obscured.

"Colonel," the figure said in a low voice, "I am glad you came. Time is of the essence."

The colonel nodded, his hand instinctively moving to the revolver at his side. "Who are you? And what is this matter that requires such secrecy?"

The figure hesitated, then lowered the hood, revealing a woman with sharp eyes and a determined expression.

"My name is Elena," she said. "I am an agent of the Crown, working undercover in these troubled lands. There is a plot afoot to destabilize the region, and it involves men of influence here in London. I have uncovered evidence that implicates several high-ranking officials in a conspiracy to smuggle arms and foment rebellion."

The colonel listened intently, the pieces beginning to fall into place. "And you require my assistance to bring these men to justice?"

Elena nodded. "Yes. Your military experience and connections will be invaluable. But we must act swiftly and discreetly."

Together, they devised a plan to gather further evidence and expose the conspirators. Over the following days, the colonel and Elena met in secret, exchanging information and coordinating their efforts.

Their investigation led them through the shadowy underworld of espionage and political intrigue, where danger lurked at every turn. They encountered informants, double agents, and assassins, each step bringing them closer to the truth.

One evening, as they reviewed their findings in a secluded room, a sudden noise alerted them to an intruder. The door burst open, and a group of armed men stormed in, weapons drawn.

The colonel and Elena sprang into action, their training and quick reflexes allowing them to fend off the attackers. In the ensuing struggle, the leader of the assailants was unmasked—a man known to the colonel as a trusted government official.

The revelation confirmed the depth of the conspiracy and the stakes involved. With renewed determination, they pressed on, gathering the final pieces of evidence needed to bring the conspirators to justice.

In the end, their efforts culminated in a dramatic confrontation at the House of Commons, where the colonel presented the evidence before a stunned assembly. The conspirators were arrested, and the threat to the realm was averted.

The colonel and Elena parted ways, their mission complete but their bond forged in the crucible of danger and intrigue. As the spring sun rose over London, the city breathed a sigh of relief, unaware of the shadowy battle that had been waged to protect its future.

events.text_segment:
“When my father took over the Horsham property, he, at my request, made a careful examination of the attic, which had been always locked up. We found the brass box there, although its contents had been destroyed. On the inside of the cover was a paper label, with the initials of K. K. K. repeated upon it, and ‘Letters, memoranda, receipts, and a register’ written beneath. These, we presume, indicated the nature of the papers which had been destroyed by Colonel Openshaw. For the rest, there was nothing of much importance in the attic save a great many scattered papers and note-books bearing upon my uncle’s life in America. Some of them were of the war time and showed that he had done his duty well and had borne the repute of a brave soldier. Others were of a date during the reconstruction of the Southern states, and were mostly concerned with politics, for he had evidently taken a strong part in opposing the carpet-bag politicians who had been sent down from the North.
“Well, it was the beginning of ’84 when my father came to live at Horsham, and all went as well as possible with us until the January of ’85. On the fourth day after the new year I heard my father give a sharp cry of surprise as we sat together at the breakfast-table. There he was, sitting with a newly opened envelope in one hand and five dried orange pips in the outstretched palm of the other one. He had always laughed at what he called my cock-and-bull story about the colonel, but he looked very scared and puzzled now that the same thing had come upon himself.
“‘Why, what on earth does this mean, John?’ he stammered.
“My heart had turned to lead. ‘It is K. K. K.,’ said I.
“He looked inside the envelope. ‘So it is,’ he cried. ‘Here are the very letters. But what is this written above them?’
“‘Put the papers on the sundial,’ I read, peeping over his shoulder.
“‘What papers? What sundial?’ he asked.
“‘The sundial in the garden. There is no other,’ said I; ‘but the papers must be those that are destroyed.’
“‘Pooh!’ said he, gripping hard at his courage. ‘We are in a civilised land here, and we can’t have tomfoolery of this kind. Where does the thing come from?’
“‘From Dundee,’ I answered, glancing at the postmark.
“‘Some preposterous practical joke,’ said he. ‘What have I to do with sundials and papers? I shall take no notice of such nonsense.’
“‘I should certainly speak to the police,’ I said.
“‘And be laughed at for my pains. Nothing of the sort.’
“‘Then let me do so?’
“‘No, I forbid you. I won’t have a fuss made about such nonsense.’
“It was in vain to argue with him, for he was a very obstinate man. I went about, however, with a heart which was full of forebodings.
“On the third day after the coming of the letter my father went from home to visit an old friend of his, Major Freebody, who is in command of one of the forts upon Portsdown Hill. I was glad that he should go, for it seemed to me that he was farther from danger when he was away from home. In that, however, I was in error. Upon the second day of his absence I received a telegram from the major, imploring me to come at once. My father had fallen over one of the deep chalk-pits which abound in the neighbourhood, and was lying senseless, with a shattered skull. I hurried to him, but he passed away without having ever recovered his consciousness. He had, as it appears, been returning from Fareham in the twilight, and as the country was unknown to him, and the chalk-pit unfenced, the jury had no hesitation in bringing in a verdict of ‘death from accidental causes.’ Carefully as I examined every fact connected with his death, I was unable to find anything which could suggest the idea of murder. There were no signs of violence, no footmarks, no robbery, no record of strangers having been seen upon the roads. And yet I need not tell you that my mind was far from at ease, and that I was well-nigh certain that some foul plot had been woven round him.
“In this sinister way I came into my inheritance. You will ask me why I did not dispose of it? I answer, because I was well convinced that our troubles were in some way dependent upon an incident in my uncle’s life, and that the danger would be as pressing in one house as in another.
