**Simulated Output (Excerpt):**

“When my father took over the Horsham property, he, at my request, made a careful examination of the attic, which had been always locked up. In that room, he found a brass box, empty save for a label inscribed with the initials ‘K.K.K.’ Beneath this, a note indicated that the letters, memoranda, receipts, and a register once contained therein had been destroyed. Among the remnants were papers relating to my late uncle’s time in America—documents that spoke of his honorable service during the war and his opposition to certain Southern politicians in the turbulent post-war years.

Life at Horsham proceeded quietly after my father’s move there in early 1884, until the morning of January 4th, 1885. At breakfast, he suddenly cried out, holding an opened envelope from which five orange pips had spilled. Though he had previously dismissed my tales of the Colonel’s mysterious past, a look of genuine fear crossed his face. The envelope bore the ominous initials ‘K.K.K.’ Above them was scrawled the chilling instruction: ‘Put the papers on the sundial.’

Perplexed as to which papers and sundial were meant, I suggested the sundial in the garden and the destroyed documents. Yet my father scoffed at the message as mere tomfoolery from Dundee and forbade me from involving the police, fearing ridicule. Despite his orders, my anxiety deepened.

Three days later, he journeyed to visit Major Freebody at Portsdown Hill. I felt some relief, believing him safer away from home, but that hope was shattered when, on the second day of his absence, I received a telegram urging me to come at once. My father had fallen into a deep, unfenced chalk pit near Fareham during twilight and was found unconscious with a fractured skull. He never regained consciousness.

The inquest returned a verdict of accidental death, citing the unfamiliar and hazardous terrain. Though I searched thoroughly, I found no sign of foul play—no footprints, no struggle, no strangers. Yet I remained convinced that my father had been the victim of a sinister plot, one that traced back to my uncle’s dark past. Thus, I inherited the estate, resolved to keep it, for I knew the danger would follow me wherever I went.”

“When my father took over the Horsham property, he, at my request, made a careful examination of the attic, which had been always locked up. In that room, he found a brass box, empty save for a label inscribed with the initials ‘K.K.K.’ Beneath this, a note indicated that the letters, memoranda, receipts, and a register once contained therein had been destroyed. Among the remnants were papers relating to my late uncle’s time in America—documents that spoke of his honorable service during the war and his opposition to certain Southern politicians in the turbulent post-war years.

Life at Horsham proceeded quietly after my father’s move there in early 1884, until the morning of January 4th, 1885. At breakfast, he suddenly cried out, holding an opened envelope from which five orange pips had spilled. Though he had previously dismissed my tales of the Colonel’s mysterious past, a look of genuine fear crossed his face. The envelope bore the ominous initials ‘K.K.K.’ Above them was scrawled the chilling instruction: ‘Put the papers on the sundial.’

Perplexed as to which papers and sundial were meant, I suggested the sundial in the garden and the destroyed documents. Yet my father scoffed at the message as mere tomfoolery from Dundee and forbade me from involving the police, fearing ridicule. Despite his orders, my anxiety deepened.

Three days later, he journeyed to visit Major Freebody at Portsdown Hill. I felt some relief, believing him safer away from home, but that hope was shattered when, on the second day of his absence, I received a telegram urging me to come at once. My father had fallen into a deep, unfenced chalk pit near Fareham during twilight and was found unconscious with a fractured skull. He never regained consciousness.

The inquest returned a verdict of accidental death, citing the unfamiliar and hazardous terrain. Though I searched thoroughly, I found no sign of foul play—no footprints, no struggle, no strangers. Yet I remained convinced that my father had been the victim of a sinister plot, one that traced back to my uncle’s dark past. Thus, I inherited the estate, resolved to keep it, for I knew the danger would follow me wherever I went.”

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
“When my father took over the Horsham property, he, at my request, made a careful examination of the attic, which had been always locked up. In that room he found a large number of papers and note-books scattered about in great disorder. Among these were many relating to my uncle’s life in America. The brass box which had borne the initials ‘K.K.K.’ was empty, but inside was a label which indicated that the letters, memoranda, receipts, and a register which it had contained had been destroyed. This I took to mean that the papers had been deliberately destroyed, for the label was still there, though the contents were gone.

Some of the papers related to my uncle’s creditable service during the war, while others concerned the period of reconstruction, during which he had taken a prominent part in opposing certain politicians in the South. My father moved to Horsham at the beginning of 1884, and all went well until the January of 1885.

On the morning of the 4th of January, while at breakfast, my father suddenly cried out in surprise, holding in his hand an envelope which he had just opened. Five orange pips fell out upon the table. Though he had previously treated my story of the Colonel with some incredulity, I saw that his face had changed, and that he looked frightened.

I took the envelope from him and read the initials ‘K.K.K.’ upon it. Above these was a message in pencil: ‘Put the papers on the sundial.’ I asked him which papers and which sundial were meant, and I suggested the sundial in the garden and the papers which had been destroyed. But he laughed bitterly and said it was all tomfoolery from Dundee. He refused to have the police called in, for fear of ridicule, and forbade me from communicating with them on the matter.

I was deeply troubled, but could do nothing. Three days later, my father went to visit an old friend, Major Freebody, who was in command of a fort at Portsdown Hill. I was glad that he was away from home, thinking that he would be safer, but my relief was short-lived.

On the second day of his absence, I received a telegram from the Major, urging me to come at once. My father had fallen into a deep chalk-pit near Fareham while returning in the twilight. The pit was unfenced, and the country unfamiliar to him. He was found senseless with a shattered skull and never regained consciousness.

The jury, after a careful inquiry, brought in a verdict of death from accidental causes without hesitation. I searched the scene myself, but found no evidence of violence, no footmarks, no sign of robbery, and no strangers had been seen in the neighborhood. Yet I was convinced that my father had been the victim of a foul plot.

I inherited the estate, and I have kept it, for I believe that the danger which threatened my uncle and my father would follow me wherever I might go, and that it would be as pressing in another house as in this.”

events.text_segment:
“It was in January, ’85, that my poor father met his end, and two years and eight months have elapsed since then. During that time I have lived happily at Horsham, and I had begun to hope that this curse had passed away from the family, and that it had ended with the last generation. I had begun to take comfort too soon, however; yesterday morning the blow fell in the very shape in which it had come upon my father.”
The young man took from his waistcoat a crumpled envelope, and turning to the table he shook out upon it five little dried orange pips.
“This is the envelope,” he continued. “The postmark is London—eastern division. Within are the very words which were upon my father’s last message: ‘K. K. K.’; and then ‘Put the papers on the sundial.’”
“What have you done?” asked Holmes.
“Nothing.”
“Nothing?”
“To tell the truth”—he sank his face into his thin, white hands—“I have felt helpless. I have felt like one of those poor rabbits when the snake is writhing towards it. I seem to be in the grasp of some resistless, inexorable evil, which no foresight and no precautions can guard against.”
“Tut! tut!” cried Sherlock Holmes. “You must act, man, or you are lost. Nothing but energy can save you. This is no time for despair.”
“I have seen the police.”
“Ah!”
“But they listened to my story with a smile. I am convinced that the inspector has formed the opinion that the letters are all practical jokes, and that the deaths of my relations were really accidents, as the jury stated, and were not to be connected with the warnings.”
Holmes shook his clenched hands in the air. “Incredible imbecility!” he cried.
“They have, however, allowed me a policeman, who may remain in the house with me.”
“Has he come with you to-night?”
“No. His orders were to stay in the house.”
Again Holmes raved in the air.
“Why did you come to me?” he said, “and, above all, why did you not come at once?”
“I did not know. It was only to-day that I spoke to Major Prendergast about my troubles and was advised by him to come to you.”
“It is really two days since you had the letter. We should have acted before this. You have no further evidence, I suppose, than that which you have placed before us—no suggestive detail which might help us?”
“There is one thing,” said John Openshaw. He rummaged in his coat pocket, and, drawing out a piece of discoloured, blue-tinted paper, he laid it out upon the table. “I have some remembrance,” said he, “that on the day when my uncle burned the papers I observed that the small, unburned margins which lay amid the ashes were of this particular colour. I found this single sheet upon the floor of his room, and I am inclined to think that it may be one of the papers which has, perhaps, fluttered out from among the others, and in that way has escaped destruction. Beyond the mention of pips, I do not see that it helps us much. I think myself that it is a page from some private diary. The writing is undoubtedly my uncle’s.”
Holmes moved the lamp, and we both bent over the sheet of paper, which showed by its ragged edge that it had indeed been torn from a book. It was headed, “March, 1869,” and beneath were the following enigmatical notices:
“4th. Hudson came. Same old platform.
“7th. Set the pips on McCauley, Paramore, and John Swain of St. Augustine.
“9th. McCauley cleared.
“10th. John Swain cleared.
“12th. Visited Paramore. All well.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
"It was in January, ’85, that my poor father met his end, and two years and eight months have elapsed since then. For a long time I had begun to hope that the family curse had been at last exhausted. But yesterday morning the threat reappeared in the same form as before."

He drew from his pocket a crumpled and discoloured envelope, and shook out upon the table five dried orange pips.

"This came to me yesterday by post, with the message 'K. K. K.' and the words 'Put the papers on the sundial.' It was postmarked London eastern division."

"And what have you done?"

"Nothing."

"Nothing!"

"I have felt helpless, like a man who is caught in a trap and cannot escape."

"You must not be so weak," said Holmes sharply. "You must act at once, or you are lost."

"I went to the police."

"And what did they say?"

"They laughed at me. They said it was a practical joke, and that my uncle and my father had died by accident."

"The incredible imbecility of the police!" said Holmes.

"They did send an officer to stay at my house, but I did not accompany him to London."

"Why did you not come to me at once?"

"I only spoke to Major Prendergast today, and he advised me to consult you."

"Two days have passed since the letter arrived," said Holmes. "You have lost precious time. Have you any other details which might be of use?"

"Yes," said Openshaw. "On the day my uncle burned the papers, I noticed that the edges which were not consumed were of a peculiar blue tint. I have here a single sheet of paper which I found on the floor of his room. It must have escaped the fire. It is discoloured and blue-tinted, and I believe it may be a page from my uncle's private diary, written in his own hand. I do not know if it will be of any help, but it mentions the pips."

Holmes took the torn page and examined it carefully. It was headed 'March, 1869,' and contained the following entries:

"4th. Hudson came. Same old platform."

"7th. Set the pips on McCauley, Paramore, and John Swain of St. Augustine."

"9th. McCauley cleared."

"10th. John Swain cleared."

"12th. Visited Paramore. All well."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
It was in January, ’85, that my poor father met his end, and two years and eight months have elapsed since then. The circumstances of his death were as mysterious as they were tragic, and they have haunted me ever since. My father, a man of great intellect and unwavering principle, had been engaged in a matter of some delicacy, one that involved the highest echelons of society and the most shadowy corners of London. It was this very matter that led to his untimely demise.

I remember the day vividly. The air was crisp and biting, the kind of cold that seeps into your bones and refuses to leave. Father had been summoned to a meeting at a secluded estate on the outskirts of the city, a place shrouded in secrecy and whispered rumors. He left with a determined look in his eyes, a resolve that I had seldom seen before. That was the last time I saw him alive.

In the days that followed, the official reports spoke of an accident—a fall from a great height, they said. But I knew better. The signs were all there: the absence of any witnesses, the strange behavior of those who had been present, and the subtle but unmistakable traces of foul play. I was convinced that my father had been murdered, silenced for reasons that were yet to be uncovered.

It was then that I sought the assistance of Mr. Sherlock Holmes, the renowned detective whose reputation for unraveling the most perplexing mysteries was unmatched. I had heard of his keen intellect and his uncanny ability to see what others could not. Desperate for answers, I turned to him, hoping that he could shed light on the dark shadows that had enveloped my family.

Holmes listened intently as I recounted the events leading up to my father’s death. His piercing eyes never wavered, absorbing every detail with meticulous care. When I finished, he leaned back in his chair, steepling his fingers thoughtfully.

"Watson," he said, "this case is fraught with complexities, but I believe we can uncover the truth. The key lies in understanding the motives of those who stood to gain from your father’s silence."

Together, we began to piece together the puzzle. We delved into my father’s correspondences, his recent acquaintances, and the nature of the secret he had been guarding. Each clue brought us closer to a revelation that was as shocking as it was inevitable.

One evening, as the gas lamps flickered outside our window, Holmes revealed his findings. "Your father was on the verge of exposing a conspiracy that threatened the very fabric of our society. His death was orchestrated to prevent this exposure."

The weight of his words settled heavily upon me. Yet, amidst the sorrow, there was a glimmer of hope. With Holmes by my side, I was determined to see justice served and to honor my father’s memory by bringing the truth to light.

Our investigation led us through the labyrinthine streets of London, from the opulent drawing rooms of the aristocracy to the grimy back alleys where secrets festered. Along the way, we encountered danger and deception, but also unexpected allies who shared our quest for justice.

In the end, it was Holmes’s unparalleled deductive skills that unraveled the conspiracy. The culprits were brought to justice, and the truth was laid bare for all to see. Though my father’s life was cut short, his legacy endured, a testament to courage and integrity in the face of darkness.

As I reflect on those harrowing days, I am reminded of the profound impact one man can have, even in death. My father’s story is one of sacrifice and resilience, and it is a story that I am honored to share, with the hope that it may inspire others to seek truth and justice, no matter the cost.

events.title: Holmes Gives Urgent Instructions and Warnings
detailed_summary: Holmes quickly returns the diary page to Openshaw, stressing the need for immediate action without further discussion.
He instructs Openshaw to return home instantly.
The plan: place the diary page into the brass box along with a convincing note stating all other papers were burned by his uncle and this is the sole remaining one.
This box must then be placed immediately on the sundial as directed.
Holmes advises against seeking revenge for now, focusing first on removing the immediate danger to Openshaw.
The secondary goals are solving the mystery and punishing the culprits.
Openshaw, revitalized with hope, agrees to follow the advice precisely.
Holmes reiterates the urgency and warns Openshaw to be extremely careful, as he is undoubtedly in real and imminent danger.
Openshaw confirms he will travel back by train from Waterloo and that he is armed.
Holmes notes the streets will be crowded before 9 PM, offering some safety, but urges extreme caution.
Holmes states he will begin working on the case tomorrow, investigating in London, not Horsham, as the secret lies there.
Openshaw promises to report back in a day or two about the box and papers.
He shakes hands and departs into the stormy night.
Watson reflects on the wild story feeling as if it blew in with the storm and was reabsorbed by it.
Holmes sits silently by the fire for some time.

events.text_segment:
“Thank you!” said Holmes, folding up the paper and returning it to our visitor. “And now you must on no account lose another instant. We cannot spare time even to discuss what you have told me. You must get home instantly and act.”
“What shall I do?”
“There is but one thing to do. It must be done at once. You must put this piece of paper which you have shown us into the brass box which you have described. You must also put in a note to say that all the other papers were burned by your uncle, and that this is the only one which remains. You must assert that in such words as will carry conviction with them. Having done this, you must at once put the box out upon the sundial, as directed. Do you understand?”
“Entirely.”
“Do not think of revenge, or anything of the sort, at present. I think that we may gain that by means of the law; but we have our web to weave, while theirs is already woven. The first consideration is to remove the pressing danger which threatens you. The second is to clear up the mystery and to punish the guilty parties.”
“I thank you,” said the young man, rising and pulling on his overcoat. “You have given me fresh life and hope. I shall certainly do as you advise.”
“Do not lose an instant. And, above all, take care of yourself in the meanwhile, for I do not think that there can be a doubt that you are threatened by a very real and imminent danger. How do you go back?”
“By train from Waterloo.”
“It is not yet nine. The streets will be crowded, so I trust that you may be in safety. And yet you cannot guard yourself too closely.”
“I am armed.”
“That is well. To-morrow I shall set to work upon your case.”
“I shall see you at Horsham, then?”
“No, your secret lies in London. It is there that I shall seek it.”
“Then I shall call upon you in a day, or in two days, with news as to the box and the papers. I shall take your advice in every particular.” He shook hands with us and took his leave. Outside the wind still screamed and the rain splashed and pattered against the windows. This strange, wild story seemed to have come to us from amid the mad elements—blown in upon us like a sheet of sea-weed in a gale—and now to have been reabsorbed by them once more.

There is no time for discussion.” He pressed the diary page into Openshaw’s hand. “Go straight home. Place this paper in the brass box along with a note explaining that all other documents were destroyed by your uncle, and this is the only one left. Then, without delay, set the box upon the sundial as instructed. Do not seek revenge yet; your safety is paramount. Once the immediate danger has passed, we will pursue the mystery and bring the culprits to justice.” Openshaw’s eyes brightened with renewed hope. “I will follow your instructions exactly,” he said firmly. Holmes fixed him with a grave look. “Be extremely careful. You are in real and imminent danger. Travel back by train from Waterloo, and remember you are armed. The streets will be crowded before nine o’clock, which may offer some protection, but do not let your guard down.” “I understand,” replied Openshaw. “I will report back in a day or two about the box and the papers.” They shook hands, and Openshaw stepped out into the stormy night. Watson watched him go, reflecting on the wild tale that seemed to have blown in with the tempest and would be swallowed up by it once more. Holmes sat silently by the fire for some time, lost in thought."

“Thank you!” said Holmes, folding up the paper and returning it to our visitor. “This will be of great assistance in our inquiries.”

The man, a tall, gaunt figure with a nervous twitch about his left eye, nodded gratefully. “I am at your service, Mr. Holmes. I only wish I had come to you sooner.”

Holmes smiled faintly. “Better late than never, my friend. Now, please, tell me everything you know about the matter.”

He settled back into his chair, steepling his fingers as he listened intently. The visitor began to recount the strange events that had led him to seek our help—a series of mysterious disappearances in the quiet village of Little Hangleton, where he had recently taken up residence.

“People have been vanishing without a trace,” he explained. “No signs of struggle, no clues left behind. The local constabulary is baffled, and the villagers are growing fearful.”

Holmes’s eyes gleamed with interest. “And you believe these disappearances are connected?”

“Indeed. There is talk of a curse, but I suspect something more tangible.”

I glanced at Holmes, noting the familiar spark of excitement in his gaze. This was the kind of puzzle that thrilled him—the interplay of human nature and the art of deduction.

“Have you noticed any patterns?” Holmes inquired.

“Each disappearance occurred on a foggy night, near the old mill on the outskirts of the village.”

Holmes nodded thoughtfully. “The fog may provide cover for the perpetrator. We must visit this mill at once.”

Without delay, we gathered our coats and set out into the misty evening. The village was eerily silent, the usual sounds of nocturnal life muted beneath the heavy shroud of fog.

As we approached the mill, a faint light flickered within. Holmes motioned for silence and crept forward, his keen eyes scanning the surroundings.

Suddenly, a shadow moved across the window. Holmes signaled for me to follow as he slipped inside through a side door left ajar.

Inside, the air was thick with dust and the scent of damp wood. We could hear muffled voices coming from the upper floor.

Holmes led the way up the creaking stairs, his footsteps light and deliberate. At the top, we found a small room where a group of men huddled around a table, their faces obscured by the dim light.

Holmes stepped forward boldly. “Gentlemen, I believe you have some explaining to do.”

The men startled, reaching for weapons, but Holmes’s commanding presence and quick reflexes kept them at bay.

“Release the captives,” he demanded.

From the shadows emerged several villagers, bound but unharmed. The men had been kidnapping them for ransom, exploiting the fog to conceal their crimes.

With the mystery unraveled, the local authorities were summoned, and the culprits apprehended. The village of Little Hangleton could finally breathe easy once more.

As we returned to Baker Street, Holmes reflected, “It is often the simplest explanation, Watson, that holds the key. A foggy night, a secluded mill, and human greed—ingredients for a tale as old as time.”

I nodded, grateful to have witnessed yet another triumph of deduction and justice at the hands of my remarkable friend.

events.text_segment:
Sherlock Holmes sat for some time in silence, with his head sunk forward and his eyes bent upon the red glow of the fire. Then he lit his pipe, and leaning back in his chair he watched the blue smoke-rings as they chased each other up to the ceiling.
“I think, Watson,” he remarked at last, “that of all our cases we have had none more fantastic than this.”
“Save, perhaps, the Sign of Four.”
“Well, yes. Save, perhaps, that. And yet this John Openshaw seems to me to be walking amid even greater perils than did the Sholtos.”
“But have you,” I asked, “formed any definite conception as to what these perils are?”
“There can be no question as to their nature,” he answered.
“Then what are they? Who is this K. K. K., and why does he pursue this unhappy family?”
Sherlock Holmes closed his eyes and placed his elbows upon the arms of his chair, with his finger-tips together. “The ideal reasoner,” he remarked, “would, when he had once been shown a single fact in all its bearings, deduce from it not only all the chain of events which led up to it but also all the results which would follow from it. As Cuvier could correctly describe a whole animal by the contemplation of a single bone, so the observer who has thoroughly understood one link in a series of incidents should be able to accurately state all the other ones, both before and after. We have not yet grasped the results which the reason alone can attain to. Problems may be solved in the study which have baffled all those who have sought a solution by the aid of their senses. To carry the art, however, to its highest pitch, it is necessary that the reasoner should be able to utilise all the facts which have come to his knowledge; and this in itself implies, as you will readily see, a possession of all knowledge, which, even in these days of free education and encyclopædias, is a somewhat rare accomplishment. It is not so impossible, however, that a man should possess all knowledge which is likely to be useful to him in his work, and this I have endeavoured in my case to do. If I remember rightly, you on one occasion, in the early days of our friendship, defined my limits in a very precise fashion.”
“Yes,” I answered, laughing. “It was a singular document. Philosophy, astronomy, and politics were marked at zero, I remember. Botany variable, geology profound as regards the mud-stains from any region within fifty miles of town, chemistry eccentric, anatomy unsystematic, sensational literature and crime records unique, violin-player, boxer, swordsman, lawyer, and self-poisoner by cocaine and tobacco. Those, I think, were the main points of my analysis.”
Holmes grinned at the last item. “Well,” he said, “I say now, as I said then, that a man should keep his little brain-attic stocked with all the furniture that he is likely to use, and the rest he can put away in the lumber-room of his library, where he can get it if he wants it. Now, for such a case as the one which has been submitted to us to-night, we need certainly to muster all our resources. Kindly hand me down the letter K of the American Encyclopædia which stands upon the shelf beside you. Thank you. Now let us consider the situation and see what may be deduced from it. In the first place, we may start with a strong presumption that Colonel Openshaw had some very strong reason for leaving America. Men at his time of life do not change all their habits and exchange willingly the charming climate of Florida for the lonely life of an English provincial town. His extreme love of solitude in England suggests the idea that he was in fear of someone or something, so we may assume as a working hypothesis that it was fear of someone or something which drove him from America. As to what it was he feared, we can only deduce that by considering the formidable letters which were received by himself and his successors. Did you remark the postmarks of those letters?”
“The first was from Pondicherry, the second from Dundee, and the third from London.”
“From East London. What do you deduce from that?”
“They are all seaports. That the writer was on board of a ship.”
“Excellent. We have already a clue. There can be no doubt that the probability—the strong probability—is that the writer was on board of a ship. And now let us consider another point. In the case of Pondicherry, seven weeks elapsed between the threat and its fulfilment, in Dundee it was only some three or four days. Does that suggest anything?”
“A greater distance to travel.”
“But the letter had also a greater distance to come.”
“Then I do not see the point.”
“There is at least a presumption that the vessel in which the man or men are is a sailing-ship. It looks as if they always send their singular warning or token before them when starting upon their mission. You see how quickly the deed followed the sign when it came from Dundee. If they had come from Pondicherry in a steamer they would have arrived almost as soon as their letter. But, as a matter of fact, seven weeks elapsed. I think that those seven weeks represented the difference between the mail-boat which brought the letter and the sailing vessel which brought the writer.”
“It is possible.”
“More than that. It is probable. And now you see the deadly urgency of this new case, and why I urged young Openshaw to caution. The blow has always fallen at the end of the time which it would take the senders to travel the distance. But this one comes from London, and therefore we cannot count upon delay.”
“Good God!” I cried. “What can it mean, this relentless persecution?”
“The papers which Openshaw carried are obviously of vital importance to the person or persons in the sailing-ship. I think that it is quite clear that there must be more than one of them. A single man could not have carried out two deaths in such a way as to deceive a coroner’s jury. There must have been several in it, and they must have been men of resource and determination. Their papers they mean to have, be the holder of them who it may. In this way you see K. K. K. ceases to be the initials of an individual and becomes the badge of a society.”
“But of what society?”
“Have you never—” said Sherlock Holmes, bending forward and sinking his voice—“have you never heard of the Ku Klux Klan?”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Sherlock Holmes sat for some time in silence, with his head sunk forward and his eyes bent upon the red glow of the fire. At last he looked up and said, "This is one of the most extraordinary cases which has ever come to my hands. It is quite as remarkable as the Sign of Four, and I think that it is even more terrible."

"What do you mean?" I asked.

"I mean that poor Openshaw is in a far greater danger than the Sholtos ever were."

"What is the nature of the peril? And who are the K.K.K.?"

Holmes smiled grimly. "I will explain my method of reasoning. An ideal reasoner, like Cuvier, could reconstruct the entire animal from a single bone. But to do this, he must have at his command all the knowledge which has ever been gathered upon the subject."

"And you have endeavored to acquire all such knowledge?"

"I have tried to. You remember your analysis of my knowledge? Zero in philosophy, astronomy, and politics; variable in botany; profound in the geology of the district; eccentric in chemistry; unsystematic in anatomy; unique in crime and sensational literature; and a first-rate violinist, boxer, swordsman, lawyer, and self-poisoner."

"I remember."

"My principle is to keep only such knowledge as is useful to me in my work."

He took down the American Encyclopædia and opened the volume marked 'K.'

"Now, Watson, consider the facts. Colonel Openshaw must have had a strong reason for leaving America and his life in Florida to live in seclusion here. He was afraid. The letters which he received prove it."

"Yes, the letters."

"Note the postmarks: Pondicherry, Dundee, East London. All seaports."

"Then the writer was on a ship."

"Exactly. That is a clue."

"But what of the time? Seven weeks from Pondicherry, only days from Dundee."

"Distance alone does not explain it. The letter from Dundee also traveled faster."

"How so?"

"I believe the perpetrators are on a sailing ship, sending the warning ahead. The seven weeks from Pondicherry represent the time difference between the faster mail boat carrying the letter and the slower sailing vessel carrying the senders."

"Then the London postmark is urgent."

"Yes, it implies the senders are already present, and no delay can be expected."

I shuddered.

"These papers are vital to the K.K.K., which must be a society, not an individual, given the complexity of the two deaths that fooled the coroners."

"Have you heard of the Ku Klux Klan?" he asked.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Sherlock Holmes sat for some time in silence, with his head sunk forward and his eyes bent upon the red glow of the fire. The flickering flames cast long shadows upon the walls of the room, creating an atmosphere thick with anticipation and unspoken thoughts. At last, he raised his head and looked across at me, his keen eyes gleaming with a mixture of excitement and determination.

"Watson," he began, his voice low and measured, "the case before us is unlike any we have encountered. The subtlety of the criminal's methods and the complexity of the clues demand our utmost attention and ingenuity."

I nodded, eager to assist in unraveling the mystery that had so captivated my friend. Holmes continued, "The key lies in understanding the motives and the means, as well as the peculiar circumstances surrounding the disappearance of Miss Violet Hunter."

I recalled the details of the case: a young governess who had sought Holmes's help after encountering strange occurrences at her employer's estate. The enigmatic Mr. Rucastle had aroused suspicion, and the sudden vanishing of Miss Hunter had only deepened the intrigue.

Holmes rose from his chair and began to pace the room, his fingers steepled beneath his chin. "The first step," he mused, "is to examine the physical evidence left behind. The torn letter, the footprints in the garden, the faint scent of tobacco—all these are threads in the tapestry we must weave."

He paused by the window, peering out into the night. "The darkness conceals many secrets, Watson, but it also reveals the character of those who move within it. We must be vigilant and perceptive."

I felt a surge of admiration for Holmes's relentless pursuit of truth. His mind was a labyrinth of logic and deduction, capable of piercing through the most impenetrable veils of deception.

Suddenly, a knock at the door interrupted our reverie. Mrs. Hudson entered, bearing a telegram. Holmes took it with a swift motion, his eyes scanning the contents rapidly.

"An urgent message from Inspector Lestrade," he announced. "It appears that new developments have arisen in the case of the Baskerville estate."

My heart quickened at the mention of the Baskervilles, a case that had already tested our resolve and ingenuity. Holmes unfolded the telegram and read aloud:

"'Dear Mr. Holmes, urgent assistance required at Baskerville Hall. Strange occurrences and unexplained phenomena reported. Your expertise is indispensable."

Holmes folded the telegram and turned to me. "Watson, it seems our respite is over. We must prepare to depart at once. The moor awaits, and with it, the shadows of a mystery that threatens to engulf us all."

I gathered my belongings, my mind racing with anticipation and a hint of apprehension. The journey to Baskerville Hall promised to be fraught with danger and revelation.

As we stepped into the night, the chill air seemed to whisper secrets of the past and portents of the future. Holmes's silhouette was resolute against the moonlit sky, a beacon of reason amidst the encroaching darkness.

The train ride was swift, and upon arrival, we were greeted by the somber visage of Dr. Mortimer, whose concern for his friends was palpable.

"Mr. Holmes, Dr. Watson," he said gravely, "the legend of the Hound has cast a pall over the estate. Strange howls echo across the moor, and the family is gripped by fear."

Holmes listened intently, his mind already piecing together the fragments of the puzzle. "Fear, Dr. Mortimer, is often the greatest adversary in any investigation. We shall confront it with reason and resolve."

Our days at Baskerville Hall were filled with observation and inquiry. Holmes's keen eye missed nothing—the footprints in the damp earth, the peculiar behavior of the servants, the cryptic messages scrawled in the margins of old books.

One evening, as the fog rolled in thick and heavy, we ventured onto the moor. The eerie silence was broken only by the distant howl of a creature unseen.

Holmes's voice was barely above a whisper. "The hound is a legend, Watson, but legends often have roots in reality. We must uncover the truth behind the myth."

Suddenly, a flash of light illuminated the darkness—a spectral figure bounding across the heath. My heart pounded as I realized the danger that lurked in the shadows.

Holmes sprang into action, his deductions swift and precise. "This is no supernatural beast, but a man using fear as a weapon. We must find the source of this deception."

Through tireless investigation, we uncovered a web of greed, jealousy, and revenge. The true culprit was unmasked, and the legend of the Hound was laid to rest.

As dawn broke over the moor, I reflected on the adventure we had shared. Holmes's brilliance had once again illuminated the darkness, proving that reason and courage could triumph over fear and superstition.

Returning to Baker Street, I felt a renewed sense of purpose and admiration for my friend. The cases we had solved were more than mere puzzles—they were tests of character and intellect.

Holmes settled back into his chair, a faint smile playing upon his lips. "Watson," he said, "the game is afoot, and there will always be mysteries to unravel. But for now, we may rest, knowing that justice has prevailed."

I nodded, grateful for the companionship and the endless pursuit of truth that defined our partnership. The fire crackled softly, casting a warm glow over the room as the night deepened around us.

events.title: The Ku Klux Klan Connection Revealed
detailed_summary: Watson admits he has never heard of the Ku Klux Klan.
Holmes finds the entry in the American Encyclopædia he requested earlier.
He reads aloud the description: a terrible secret society formed by ex-Confederate soldiers post-Civil War, using terror for political ends, particularly against Black voters and opponents.
Their outrages were often preceded by symbolic warnings (oak leaves, melon seeds, orange pips).
Victims could recant or flee; defiance meant certain death, often in strange ways.
The organization was highly effective and elusive, flourishing for years despite government efforts.
It suddenly collapsed around 1869, though sporadic incidents continued.
Holmes points out the collapse coincided with Colonel Openshaw's departure from America with 'their papers', suggesting cause and effect.
He explains this makes it understandable why implacable members are tracking the family, as the register and diary likely implicate prominent Southern figures who want the documents destroyed.
He interprets the diary page Watson saw: 'sent the pips' meant sending the Klan warning; 'cleared' meant the targets left the country; 'visited' implied a sinister outcome for Paramore.
Holmes believes they can shed light on the matter and that Openshaw's only current chance is following his instructions.
Concluding the discussion for the night, Holmes asks for his violin to distract from the grim weather and human behavior.

events.text_segment:
“I never have.”
Holmes turned over the leaves of the book upon his knee. “Here it is,” said he presently:
“‘Ku Klux Klan. A name derived from the fanciful resemblance to the sound produced by cocking a rifle. This terrible secret society was formed by some ex-Confederate soldiers in the Southern states after the Civil War, and it rapidly formed local branches in different parts of the country, notably in Tennessee, Louisiana, the Carolinas, Georgia, and Florida. Its power was used for political purposes, principally for the terrorising of the negro voters and the murdering and driving from the country of those who were opposed to its views. Its outrages were usually preceded by a warning sent to the marked man in some fantastic but generally recognised shape—a sprig of oak-leaves in some parts, melon seeds or orange pips in others. On receiving this the victim might either openly abjure his former ways, or might fly from the country. If he braved the matter out, death would unfailingly come upon him, and usually in some strange and unforeseen manner. So perfect was the organisation of the society, and so systematic its methods, that there is hardly a case upon record where any man succeeded in braving it with impunity, or in which any of its outrages were traced home to the perpetrators. For some years the organisation flourished in spite of the efforts of the United States government and of the better classes of the community in the South. Eventually, in the year 1869, the movement rather suddenly collapsed, although there have been sporadic outbreaks of the same sort since that date.’
“You will observe,” said Holmes, laying down the volume, “that the sudden breaking up of the society was coincident with the disappearance of Openshaw from America with their papers. It may well have been cause and effect. It is no wonder that he and his family have some of the more implacable spirits upon their track. You can understand that this register and diary may implicate some of the first men in the South, and that there may be many who will not sleep easy at night until it is recovered.”
“Then the page we have seen—”
“Is such as we might expect. It ran, if I remember right, ‘sent the pips to A, B, and C’—that is, sent the society’s warning to them. Then there are successive entries that A and B cleared, or left the country, and finally that C was visited, with, I fear, a sinister result for C. Well, I think, Doctor, that we may let some light into this dark place, and I believe that the only chance young Openshaw has in the meantime is to do what I have told him. There is nothing more to be said or to be done to-night, so hand me over my violin and let us try to forget for half an hour the miserable weather and the still more miserable ways of our fellow men.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
"I never have."

"Then you are fortunate," said Holmes. "The Ku Klux Klan is a terrible secret society, which was formed by ex-Confederate soldiers after the American Civil War. It was a body of men who used terror and violence to achieve political ends, particularly to suppress the rights of the newly freed Black population and their allies."

Holmes took down the American Encyclopædia from the shelf and found the entry he had requested earlier. He read aloud:

"The Ku Klux Klan, a secret society, was organized in the Southern States of America in 1866. Its members wore white robes and hoods, and they used symbolic warnings such as oak leaves, melon seeds, and orange pips to threaten their victims. These outrages were often followed by acts of violence or death. Victims who recanted or fled were spared, but those who defied the Klan were marked for death, often in mysterious and brutal ways."

"The organization was highly effective and elusive," Holmes continued, "and despite government efforts, it flourished for several years. It suddenly collapsed around 1869, though sporadic incidents continued thereafter."

"This collapse," Holmes said, "coincides with the departure of Colonel Openshaw from America, who took with him 'their papers.' It is reasonable to infer that these documents were the register and diary of the Klan, which would implicate many prominent Southern figures. These men would be implacable in their desire to recover or destroy such evidence."

"The diary page you saw," he went on, "where it says 'sent the pips,' refers to the sending of the Klan's warning. 'Cleared' means the targets left the country, and 'visited' implies a sinister outcome, as in the case of Paramore."

"I believe we can shed some light on this matter," Holmes concluded. "Openshaw's only chance now is to follow the instructions he has received."

He then closed the book and, glancing out at the grim weather and reflecting on the darker aspects of human nature, asked for his violin to distract himself for the evening.

“I never have,” said Holmes, with a smile. “But the case of the Speckled Band is one that has always fascinated me. It is a singular example of the ingenuity and cunning that can be employed in the commission of a crime.”

Dr. Watson leaned forward, his interest piqued. “Pray, tell me more, Holmes. What was the nature of this peculiar case?”

Holmes settled back in his chair, his eyes gleaming with the thrill of the tale. “It began with a visit from a young lady named Helen Stoner, who was in great distress. She came to me at Baker Street, seeking help to unravel the mystery surrounding the death of her sister, Julia.”

“Julia had died under strange circumstances at their family estate, Stoke Moran. The doctors were baffled, and the local authorities had no explanation. Helen feared for her own life, as she had begun to hear the same eerie whistle that Julia had reported before her demise.”

“Indeed,” Holmes continued, “the case was marked by several curious details. The old manor was a gloomy place, with barred windows and a locked room that had not been opened for years. The stepfather, Dr. Grimesby Roylott, was a man of violent temper and strange habits, known for his interest in exotic animals and his knowledge of poisons.”

“Holmes, how did you proceed with your investigation?” asked Watson.

“I accompanied Miss Stoner to Stoke Moran,” Holmes replied. “We examined the room where Julia had died, noting the peculiar bell-pull that did not seem to function, the ventilator connecting to the adjoining room, and the bed clamped to the floor. These details suggested a hidden mechanism at work.”

“On the night of our vigil, we observed the source of the deadly threat: a venomous swamp adder, the 'speckled band' of the title, which Dr. Roylott had trained to kill. The snake was sent through the ventilator, down the bell-pull, and onto the bed, where it bit Julia, causing her death.”

“Holmes’s quick thinking led to the destruction of the snake, and the apprehension of the villain. The case was a testament to the dangers that can lurk behind closed doors and the importance of keen observation and deductive reasoning.”

Watson nodded appreciatively. “Truly, Holmes, your methods are unparalleled. The Speckled Band remains one of your most remarkable cases.”

Holmes smiled modestly. “It is the peculiarities of human nature and the complexities of crime that make our work endlessly fascinating, my dear Watson.”

events.title: Tragic News: John Openshaw Found Dead
detailed_summary: The following morning is clear and sunny.
Watson finds Holmes already at breakfast, anticipating a busy day investigating Openshaw's case.
Holmes plans to start his inquiries in the City, possibly going to Horsham later if needed.
While waiting for coffee, Watson glances at the newspaper and sees a headline that chills him.
He cries out to Holmes that he is too late.
Holmes, fearing the worst, calmly asks how it happened, though Watson sees he is deeply moved.
Watson reads the account titled 'Tragedy Near Waterloo Bridge': between 9 and 10 PM the previous night, a police constable heard a cry for help and a splash near the bridge.
Due to the dark and stormy conditions, rescue attempts by the constable and passers-by failed.
The water-police later recovered the body, identified via an envelope in his pocket as John Openshaw of Horsham.
The newspaper conjectures he was rushing for the last train, missed his path in the dark, and fell from a steamboat landing stage.
The report states no signs of violence were found, concluding it was an unfortunate accident and highlighting the poor condition of riverside landings.
Holmes and Watson sit in silence; Holmes appears more shaken than Watson has ever seen him.
Holmes admits his pride is hurt, calling it a petty feeling but stating the case has become personal.
He vows, health permitting, to bring the gang to justice, lamenting that Openshaw came for help only to be sent to his death.
He paces the room agitatedly, wondering how the 'cunning devils' lured Openshaw to the Embankment, which wasn't on his direct route to Waterloo station.
He resolves to win in the long run and declares he is going out, intending to be his own police force and only involving them once his 'web' is spun.

events.text_segment:
It had cleared in the morning, and the sun was shining with a subdued brightness through the dim veil which hangs over the great city. Sherlock Holmes was already at breakfast when I came down.
“You will excuse me for not waiting for you,” said he; “I have, I foresee, a very busy day before me in looking into this case of young Openshaw’s.”
“What steps will you take?” I asked.
“It will very much depend upon the results of my first inquiries. I may have to go down to Horsham, after all.”
“You will not go there first?”
“No, I shall commence with the City. Just ring the bell and the maid will bring up your coffee.”
As I waited, I lifted the unopened newspaper from the table and glanced my eye over it. It rested upon a heading which sent a chill to my heart.
“Holmes,” I cried, “you are too late.”
“Ah!” said he, laying down his cup, “I feared as much. How was it done?” He spoke calmly, but I could see that he was deeply moved.
“My eye caught the name of Openshaw, and the heading ‘Tragedy Near Waterloo Bridge.’ Here is the account:
“‘Between nine and ten last night Police-Constable Cook, of the H Division, on duty near Waterloo Bridge, heard a cry for help and a splash in the water. The night, however, was extremely dark and stormy, so that, in spite of the help of several passers-by, it was quite impossible to effect a rescue. The alarm, however, was given, and, by the aid of the water-police, the body was eventually recovered. It proved to be that of a young gentleman whose name, as it appears from an envelope which was found in his pocket, was John Openshaw, and whose residence is near Horsham. It is conjectured that he may have been hurrying down to catch the last train from Waterloo Station, and that in his haste and the extreme darkness he missed his path and walked over the edge of one of the small landing-places for river steamboats. The body exhibited no traces of violence, and there can be no doubt that the deceased had been the victim of an unfortunate accident, which should have the effect of calling the attention of the authorities to the condition of the riverside landing-stages.’”
We sat in silence for some minutes, Holmes more depressed and shaken than I had ever seen him.
“That hurts my pride, Watson,” he said at last. “It is a petty feeling, no doubt, but it hurts my pride. It becomes a personal matter with me now, and, if God sends me health, I shall set my hand upon this gang. That he should come to me for help, and that I should send him away to his death—!” He sprang from his chair and paced about the room in uncontrollable agitation, with a flush upon his sallow cheeks and a nervous clasping and unclasping of his long thin hands.
“They must be cunning devils,” he exclaimed at last. “How could they have decoyed him down there? The Embankment is not on the direct line to the station. The bridge, no doubt, was too crowded, even on such a night, for their purpose. Well, Watson, we shall see who will win in the long run. I am going out now!”
“To the police?”
“No; I shall be my own police. When I have spun the web they may take the flies, but not before.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
It had cleared in the morning, and the sun was shining with a subdued brightness through the dim veil which hangs over the great city. I found Holmes already at breakfast, and he was in excellent spirits, for he had been up late, and had evidently been busy with the Openshaw case. "I have a good mind to go down to Horsham," he said, "but I think I shall begin my inquiries in the City. There is a good deal to be done there, and I shall be able to get a better idea of the whole affair."

While I was waiting for the coffee, I glanced at the newspaper, and my eye was caught by a paragraph which made me cry out in a voice of horror, "Holmes, you are too late!"

He looked up with a calm face, but I could see that he was deeply moved. "How did it happen?" he asked.

I read aloud the account headed "Tragedy Near Waterloo Bridge." It stated that between nine and ten o'clock the previous night a police constable had heard a cry for help and a splash near the bridge. The night had been dark and stormy, and the constable, with the assistance of some passers-by, had tried to rescue the person, but without success. The water-police had later recovered the body, which was identified by an envelope in the pocket as that of John Openshaw of Horsham.

The newspaper conjectured that he had been hurrying for the last train, had missed his way in the darkness, and had fallen from the steamboat landing stage. No signs of violence were found, and the report concluded that it was a sad accident, emphasizing the dangerous condition of the riverside landings.

Holmes and I sat in silence. I had never seen him so shaken. "My pride is hurt," he said at last. "It is a petty feeling, but this case has become personal. I shall, health permitting, bring the gang to justice. Openshaw came to us for help, and we sent him to his death."

He paced the room with agitation. "How did those cunning devils lure him to the Embankment? It was not on his direct route to Waterloo station. But I shall win in the long run. I am going out now. I shall be my own police force, and I shall only call in the official police when my web is spun."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
It had cleared in the morning, and the sun was shining with a subdued brightness through the dim veil which hangs over the great city. The streets were already bustling with the usual crowd of early risers, the clatter of horse-drawn cabs mingling with the distant cries of street vendors. Sherlock Holmes and I had just concluded our breakfast at 221B Baker Street when a sharp rap at the door announced the arrival of a visitor.

Mrs. Hudson ushered in a tall, thin man with a nervous demeanor and a pale complexion. He introduced himself as Mr. John Openshaw, a gentleman of some standing who had come to seek Holmes's assistance in a matter of grave concern. His eyes darted anxiously about the room as he recounted the peculiar circumstances that had brought him to our door.

Mr. Openshaw explained that his family had been plagued by a series of mysterious deaths, each more baffling than the last. His great-uncle, Elias Openshaw, had vanished without a trace several years prior, leaving behind a cryptic note that hinted at a terrible secret. Since then, other members of the family had met untimely ends under circumstances that defied explanation.

Holmes listened intently, his keen eyes narrowing as he absorbed every detail. He asked probing questions about the family history, the nature of the deaths, and any possible motives or suspects. Mr. Openshaw revealed that the family estate, Lafter Hall, was situated in a remote part of the countryside, surrounded by dense woods and shrouded in local superstition.

Intrigued by the case, Holmes agreed to accompany Mr. Openshaw to Lafter Hall to investigate further. We set out that very afternoon, the city gradually giving way to rolling hills and verdant fields as we traveled by train and carriage. Upon arrival, we were greeted by the somber household staff and the remaining family members, all of whom bore the weight of recent tragedies.

Holmes immediately set about examining the scene, his methodical approach revealing subtle clues that had escaped the notice of others. He inspected the rooms where the deaths had occurred, noting peculiar marks on the walls and the arrangement of furniture. He questioned the servants and relatives, observing their reactions and inconsistencies in their accounts.

As night fell, a storm gathered outside, casting eerie shadows through the windows of the ancient manor. Holmes gathered us in the drawing-room to share his preliminary findings. He proposed that the deaths were not the result of supernatural forces, as some believed, but rather the work of a calculating individual seeking to conceal a dark secret.

Over the following days, Holmes's relentless pursuit of the truth uncovered a web of deceit, greed, and long-held grudges within the Openshaw family. He identified the murderer through a combination of forensic evidence, psychological insight, and a daring confrontation that brought the culprit to justice.

The case of the Openshaw family served as a testament to Holmes's unparalleled deductive abilities and his unwavering commitment to uncovering the truth, no matter how deeply it was buried beneath layers of mystery and fear. As we departed Lafter Hall, the sun once again broke through the clouds, illuminating the path ahead and signaling the end of a dark chapter in the family's history.

events.text_segment:
All day I was engaged in my professional work, and it was late in the evening before I returned to Baker Street. Sherlock Holmes had not come back yet. It was nearly ten o’clock before he entered, looking pale and worn. He walked up to the sideboard, and tearing a piece from the loaf he devoured it voraciously, washing it down with a long draught of water.
“You are hungry,” I remarked.
“Starving. It had escaped my memory. I have had nothing since breakfast.”
“Nothing?”
“Not a bite. I had no time to think of it.”
“And how have you succeeded?”
“Well.”
“You have a clue?”
“I have them in the hollow of my hand. Young Openshaw shall not long remain unavenged. Why, Watson, let us put their own devilish trade-mark upon them. It is well thought of!”
“What do you mean?”
He took an orange from the cupboard, and tearing it to pieces he squeezed out the pips upon the table. Of these he took five and thrust them into an envelope. On the inside of the flap he wrote “S. H. for J. O.” Then he sealed it and addressed it to “Captain James Calhoun, Barque Lone Star, Savannah, Georgia.”
“That will await him when he enters port,” said he, chuckling. “It may give him a sleepless night. He will find it as sure a precursor of his fate as Openshaw did before him.”
“And who is this Captain Calhoun?”
“The leader of the gang. I shall have the others, but he first.”
“How did you trace it, then?”
He took a large sheet of paper from his pocket, all covered with dates and names.
“I have spent the whole day,” said he, “over Lloyd’s registers and files of the old papers, following the future career of every vessel which touched at Pondicherry in January and February in ’83. There were thirty-six ships of fair tonnage which were reported there during those months. Of these, one, the Lone Star, instantly attracted my attention, since, although it was reported as having cleared from London, the name is that which is given to one of the states of the Union.”
“Texas, I think.”
“I was not and am not sure which; but I knew that the ship must have an American origin.”
“What then?”
“I searched the Dundee records, and when I found that the barque Lone Star was there in January, ’85, my suspicion became a certainty. I then inquired as to the vessels which lay at present in the port of London.”
“Yes?”
“The Lone Star had arrived here last week. I went down to the Albert Dock and found that she had been taken down the river by the early tide this morning, homeward bound to Savannah. I wired to Gravesend and learned that she had passed some time ago, and as the wind is easterly I have no doubt that she is now past the Goodwins and not very far from the Isle of Wight.”
“What will you do, then?”
“Oh, I have my hand upon him. He and the two mates, are as I learn, the only native-born Americans in the ship. The others are Finns and Germans. I know, also, that they were all three away from the ship last night. I had it from the stevedore who has been loading their cargo. By the time that their sailing-ship reaches Savannah the mail-boat will have carried this letter, and the cable will have informed the police of Savannah that these three gentlemen are badly wanted here upon a charge of murder.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
All day I was engaged in my professional work, and it was late in the evening before I returned to Baker Street. Holmes was not at home, and I found him still absent when I went to bed. I was awakened by a noise in the room below, and, looking out of my window, I saw Holmes enter the house. He was pale and haggard, and his eyes had a wild, eager look. He went straight to the sideboard, tore off a piece of bread, and ate it ravenously, washing it down with a large draught of water. "I am starving," said he, "I have not tasted food since breakfast. I forgot it in my excitement."

"Well?" I asked.

"Well," he answered, "I have them in the hollow of my hand. Openshaw will be avenged."

He took an orange from the sideboard, and, after squeezing out five pips, he placed them carefully in an envelope. On the flap he wrote, "S. H. for J. O." and sealed it. Then he addressed it to "Captain James Calhoun, Barque Lone Star, Savannah, Georgia."

He chuckled as he looked at the letter. "That will give him a sleepless night," said he. "It will be a little foretaste of the fate which awaits him, just as the five orange pips were a forewarning to Openshaw. Calhoun is the ringleader of the gang. I shall get the others, but Calhoun first."

He explained his method. He had spent the day at Lloyd's, examining the registers and old newspapers. He had traced every ship which had been in Pondicherry in January and February, 1883. One ship, the Lone Star, had attracted his attention. Though it had cleared from London, its name suggested an American origin, and he had found it in the Dundee records in January, 1885. He had then inquired about ships currently in London, and found that the Lone Star had arrived last week. He had gone down to the Albert Dock and discovered that the ship had left that very morning, bound for Savannah. A wire to Gravesend had confirmed that it had passed some time ago. With an easterly wind, Holmes believed that the ship was now past the Goodwin Sands and near the Isle of Wight.

"My plan," said he, "is this: Calhoun and his two mates, the only Americans on board, the rest being Finns and Germans, were seen ashore last night by the stevedore. By the time their sailing ship reaches Savannah, the faster mail boat will have delivered my letter with the five orange pips, and a cablegram will have informed the Savannah police that the three men are wanted in London for murder."

"Well," he answered, "I have them in the hollow of my hand. Openshaw will be avenged."

He took an orange from the sideboard, and, after squeezing out five pips, he placed them carefully in an envelope. On the flap he wrote, "S. H. for J. O." and sealed it. Then he addressed it to "Captain James Calhoun, Barque Lone Star, Savannah, Georgia."

He chuckled as he looked at the letter. "That will give him a sleepless night," said he. "It will be a little foretaste of the fate which awaits him, just as the five orange pips were a forewarning to Openshaw. Calhoun is the ringleader of the gang. I shall get the others, but Calhoun first."

He explained his method. He had spent the day at Lloyd's, examining the registers and old newspapers. He had traced every ship which had been in Pondicherry in January and February, 1883. One ship, the Lone Star, had attracted his attention. Though it had cleared from London, its name suggested an American origin, and he had found it in the Dundee records in January, 1885. He had then inquired about ships currently in London, and found that the Lone Star had arrived last week. He had gone down to the Albert Dock and discovered that the ship had left that very morning, bound for Savannah. A wire to Gravesend had confirmed that it had passed some time ago. With an easterly wind, Holmes believed that the ship was now past the Goodwin Sands and near the Isle of Wight.

"My plan," said he, "is this: Calhoun and his two mates, the only Americans on board, the rest being Finns and Germans, were seen ashore last night by the stevedore. By the time their sailing ship reaches Savannah, the faster mail boat will have delivered my letter with the five orange pips, and a cablegram will have informed the Savannah police that the three men are wanted in London for murder."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
All day I was engaged in my professional work, and it was late in the evening before I returned to Baker Street. The fog lay thick upon the city, wrapping the gas lamps in a dim, yellow haze that seemed to swallow the streets whole. As I ascended the stairs to our rooms, I could hear the faint sound of a violin drifting through the door, a sure sign that Holmes was already at his post, immersed in some new problem.

I entered to find him seated in his armchair, the violin resting against his shoulder, his eyes closed in concentration. The room was littered with papers, chemical apparatus, and various oddities collected from his many cases. He opened his eyes as I came in, a faint smile playing upon his lips.

"Ah, Watson," he said, "just in time. I have been pondering a most curious affair, one that promises to be both challenging and instructive."

I settled into my chair, eager to hear the details. Holmes proceeded to outline the case of the 'Speckled Band,' a mysterious and sinister matter involving the sudden death of a young woman named Julia Stoner. Her sister, Helen, had come to Holmes in desperation, fearing for her own life after the strange circumstances surrounding Julia's demise.

Holmes listened intently as I recounted the details Helen had provided: the eerie whistle heard in the dead of night, the locked room with no apparent means of ingress or egress, and the cryptic mention of a 'speckled band' in Julia's last words. The more Holmes considered the facts, the more his keen mind began to unravel the threads of the mystery.

"Watson," he said, "this case is a perfect example of how appearances can deceive. The locked room, the strange noises, and the sudden death all point to a carefully orchestrated plan. We must visit Stoke Moran, the estate where the sisters reside, and examine the scene ourselves."

The next morning, we set out for the countryside, the journey filled with Holmes's rapid-fire deductions and observations. Upon arrival, we were greeted by Dr. Roylott, the girls' stepfather, a man of imposing stature and a temper as volatile as the storms that often swept the moorlands.

Holmes's scrutiny of the estate revealed several peculiarities: the ventilator connecting the rooms, the bell-pull that did not ring, and the presence of a saucer of milk in the room. Each detail seemed insignificant alone, but together they formed a pattern that Holmes was eager to explore.

That night, we awaited the hour when the mysterious events were said to occur. Holmes instructed Helen to sleep in her sister's room, while he and I concealed ourselves nearby. As the clock struck two, a low, hissing sound filled the room, followed by a sudden movement near the bed.

Holmes sprang into action, seizing a small, venomous snake—the 'speckled band'—which had been trained to kill by Dr. Roylott. The villain's plan was to eliminate the sisters to secure his inheritance, using the snake as a deadly instrument.

With the danger averted and the truth revealed, justice was served, and the shadow that had hung over Stoke Moran was lifted. As we returned to London, I reflected on the brilliance of Holmes's methods and the profound impact of his unwavering dedication to uncovering the truth.

events.title: Nature's Justice: The Fate of the Lone Star
detailed_summary: Watson reflects that even the best human plans can have flaws.
The murderers of John Openshaw were destined never to receive the warning pips sent by Holmes.
The equinoctial gales that year were exceptionally long and severe.
Despite waiting, no news of the Lone Star reaching Savannah ever arrived.
Eventually, word came of a sighting far out in the Atlantic: a shattered stern-post, marked with the letters 'L. S.', was seen drifting in the waves.
Watson concludes that this fragment is the only information ever obtained regarding the final fate of the Lone Star and its crew.

S.” carved upon it, and that is all which we shall ever know of the fate of the Lone Star.

events.text_segment:
Isa Whitney, brother of the late Elias Whitney, D.D., Principal of the Theological College of St. George’s, was much addicted to opium. The habit grew upon him, as I understand, from some foolish freak when he was at college; for having read De Quincey’s description of his dreams and sensations, he had drenched his tobacco with laudanum in an attempt to produce the same effects. He found, as so many more have done, that the practice is easier to attain than to get rid of, and for many years he continued to be a slave to the drug, an object of mingled horror and pity to his friends and relatives. I can see him now, with yellow, pasty face, drooping lids, and pin-point pupils, all huddled in a chair, the wreck and ruin of a noble man.
One night—it was in June, ’89—there came a ring to my bell, about the hour when a man gives his first yawn and glances at the clock. I sat up in my chair, and my wife laid her needle-work down in her lap and made a little face of disappointment.
“A patient!” said she. “You’ll have to go out.”
I groaned, for I was newly come back from a weary day.
We heard the door open, a few hurried words, and then quick steps upon the linoleum. Our own door flew open, and a lady, clad in some dark-coloured stuff, with a black veil, entered the room.
“You will excuse my calling so late,” she began, and then, suddenly losing her self-control, she ran forward, threw her arms about my wife’s neck, and sobbed upon her shoulder. “Oh, I’m in such trouble!” she cried; “I do so want a little help.”
“Why,” said my wife, pulling up her veil, “it is Kate Whitney. How you startled me, Kate! I had not an idea who you were when you came in.”
“I didn’t know what to do, so I came straight to you.” That was always the way. Folk who were in grief came to my wife like birds to a lighthouse.
“It was very sweet of you to come. Now, you must have some wine and water, and sit here comfortably and tell us all about it. Or should you rather that I sent James off to bed?”
“Oh, no, no! I want the doctor’s advice and help, too. It’s about Isa. He has not been home for two days. I am so frightened about him!”
It was not the first time that she had spoken to us of her husband’s trouble, to me as a doctor, to my wife as an old friend and school companion. We soothed and comforted her by such words as we could find. Did she know where her husband was? Was it possible that we could bring him back to her?
It seems that it was. She had the surest information that of late he had, when the fit was on him, made use of an opium den in the farthest east of the City. Hitherto his orgies had always been confined to one day, and he had come back, twitching and shattered, in the evening. But now the spell had been upon him eight-and-forty hours, and he lay there, doubtless among the dregs of the docks, breathing in the poison or sleeping off the effects. There he was to be found, she was sure of it, at the Bar of Gold, in Upper Swandam Lane. But what was she to do? How could she, a young and timid woman, make her way into such a place and pluck her husband out from among the ruffians who surrounded him?
There was the case, and of course there was but one way out of it. Might I not escort her to this place? And then, as a second thought, why should she come at all? I was Isa Whitney’s medical adviser, and as such I had influence over him. I could manage it better if I were alone. I promised her on my word that I would send him home in a cab within two hours if he were indeed at the address which she had given me. And so in ten minutes I had left my armchair and cheery sitting-room behind me, and was speeding eastward in a hansom on a strange errand, as it seemed to me at the time, though the future only could show how strange it was to be.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Isa Whitney, brother of the late Elias Whitney, D.D., Principal of the Theological College of St. George’s, was much addicted to opium. His addiction dated back to his college days, when, as a medical student, he had experimented with the drug and had never been able to free himself from its grasp. Over the years, his habit had reduced him from a promising young man of good family and education to a pitiable wreck, wandering the streets in a state of semi-consciousness.

One June evening in 1889, Dr. Watson was enjoying a rare moment of peace in his sitting-room when the bell rang sharply. He and his wife exchanged glances, expecting a patient at this late hour. The door opened suddenly, and a veiled woman entered hurriedly. She threw back her veil and revealed a face pale with distress. She embraced Mrs. Watson with a sudden, almost desperate affection.

"It is I, Kate Whitney," she said, her voice trembling. "I have come to you because I am in trouble."

Mrs. Watson recognized her at once. Kate Whitney was the wife of Isa Whitney, and she had come to them before, seeking help for her husband's addiction.

"Sit down, dear," Mrs. Watson said gently, leading her to a chair. "Tell us what has happened."

Kate took a deep breath and began. "Isa has been missing for two days. I am afraid something terrible has happened to him. This is not like him. He always returns to the Bar of Gold in Upper Swandam Lane, the opium den he frequents when he is in his binges. But this time, he has not come back. I cannot go there myself; it is a place no respectable woman can enter. I do not know what to do."

Dr. Watson listened intently. He knew the dangers of such places and the difficulty of rescuing a man in Isa's condition. After a moment's thought, he said, "I will go to the Bar of Gold and see if I can find him. If he is there, I will bring him home within two hours."

Kate's eyes filled with tears of relief. "Oh, thank you, Dr. Watson. You are his doctor; perhaps you can reach him where I cannot."

Without delay, Watson donned his coat and hat and stepped out into the night. He hailed a cab and gave the driver the address. As the vehicle rattled through the streets towards the East End, Watson pondered the strange errand upon which he was embarking, unaware that it would lead him into one of the most curious cases of his career.
